[[File:A pangolin in defensive posture, Horniman Museum, London.jpg
column3: A pangolin in defensive posture, Horniman Museum, London]]

column9: short=x}}</ref> are [[mammals]] of the order '''Pholidota''' (from [[Ancient Greek]] [[wikt:φολίς
column11: extant]] family, '''Manidae''', has three genera: ''[[Manis]]'', ''[[Phataginus]]'' and ''[[Smutsia]]''. ''Manis'' comprises the four species found in Asia, while ''Phataginus'' and ''Smutsia'' each include two species living in Sub-Saharan Africa.<ref name=\"web2.utc.edu\">{{cite journal
column15: title=The Phylogeny of Living and Extinct Pangolins (Mammalia, Pholidota) and Associated Taxa: A Morphology Based Analysis
column24: accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> These species range in size from {{convert
column29: abbr=on}}. A number of [[extinct]] pangolin species are also known.

column1: Pangolins have large, protective [[keratin]] scales covering their skin; they are the only known mammals with this feature. They live in hollow trees or [[burrow]]s, depending on the species. Pangolins are [[nocturnal]], and their diet consists of mainly [[ants]] and [[termites]], which they capture using their long tongues. They tend to be solitary animals, meeting only to mate and produce a litter of one to three offspring, which they raise for about two years.

column2: threatened by poaching]] (for their meat and scales, which are used in [[Chinese traditional medicine]] for a variety of ailments including excessive anxiety and hysterical crying in children, women thought to be possessed by [[devil]]s and [[ogre]]s, [[malaria]]l fever, and deafness<ref>{{cite journal
column10: bibcode=1938Natur.141R..72. }}</ref>) and heavy [[deforestation]] of their natural habitats, and are the most [[wildlife smuggling
column11: trafficked]] mammals in the world.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=A Struggle to Save the Scaly Pangolin
column21: January 2020}}, of the eight species of pangolin, three (''[[Manis culionensis]]'', ''[[Manis pentadactyla
column23: M. javanica]]'') are listed as critically endangered, three (''[[Phataginus tricuspis]]'', ''[[Manis crassicaudata]]'' and ''[[Smutsia gigantea]]'') are listed as endangered and two (''[[Phataginus tetradactyla]]'' and ''[[Smutsia temminckii]]'') are listed as vulnerable on the [[Red List of Threatened Species]] of the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]].<ref name=\"IUCN Manidae\">{{cite web
column25: website=[[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]

column1: The name ''pangolin'' comes from the [[Malay language
column2: Malay]] word ''pengguling'', meaning \"one who rolls up\".<ref name=COED>{{cite book
column11: page=1030}}</ref> However, the modern name in [[Malay language
column12: Standard Malay]] is ''tenggiling''; whereas in [[Indonesian language
column13: Indonesian]] it is ''trenggiling''; and in the [[Philippine languages]] it is ''goling'', ''tanggiling'', or ''balintong'' (with the same meaning).<ref name=\"Vergara\">{{cite book

column1: The etymologies of the three generic names ''Manis'' (Linnaeus, 1758), ''Phataginus'' (Rafinesque, 1821), and ''Smutsia'' (Gray, 1865) are sometimes misunderstood.

column2: Neo-Latin]] generic name ''Manis'' apparently as a feminine singular form of the Latin masculine plural [[Manes]], the [[Ancient Rome
column3: Ancient Roman]] name for a type of [[spirit]], after the animal's strange appearance.<ref>{{cite web

column1: [[Constantine Rafinesque]] (1821) formed the Neo-Latin generic name ''Phataginus'' from the French term ''phatagin'', adopted by [[Count Buffon]] (1763) after the reported local name ''phatagin'' or ''phatagen'' used in the [[East Indies]].
The British [[naturalist]] [[John Edward Gray]] named ''Smutsia'' for the [[South Africa]]n naturalist [[Johannes Smuts]] (1808–1869),<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=S2A3 Biographical Database of Southern African Science [Johannes Smuts]
column8: title=Index Generum Mammalium: a List of the Genera and Families of Mammals
column14: access-date=May 28, 2018}}</ref> the first South African to write a [[treatise]] on mammals in 1832 (in which he described the species ''Manis temminckii'').

column1: All species of living pangolin had been assigned to the genus ''Manis'' until the late 2000s, when research prompted the splitting of extant pangolins into three genera: ''Manis'', ''Phataginus'', and ''Smutsia''.<ref name=\"web2.utc.edu\"/><ref name=\"KondrashovAgadjanian2012\"/>
** Genus †''[[Euromanis]]'' <small>(Storch & Martin, 1994) Gaudin, Emry & Wible, 2009</small> [''[[Eomanis krebsi]]'' <small>Storch & Martin, 1994</small>]
**** Family [[Patriomanidae]] <small>Szalay & Schrenk 1998 sensu Gaudin, Emry & Pogue, 2006</small>

The order Pholidota in the past was considered to be the [[sister taxon]] to [[Xenarthra]] (neotropical [[anteater]]s, [[sloth]]s, and [[armadillo]]s), but recent genetic evidence indicates their closest living relatives are the [[carnivora]]ns, with which they form a [[clade]] termed either [[Ferae]] or Ostentoria.<ref>{{cite journal
column27: title=Resolution of the Early Placental Mammal Radiation Using Bayesian Phylogenetics
column40: title = A new phylogenetic marker, apolipoprotein B, provides compelling evidence for eutherian relationships
column57: title=A higher-level MRP supertree of placental mammals
column80: title= The complete mitochondrial genome of Temminck's ground pangolin (''Smutsia temminckii''; Smuts, 1832) and phylogenetic position of the Pholidota (Weber, 1904)
column86: doi= 10.1016/j.gene.2014.08.040}}</ref> Fossil groups like the [[creodont]]s<ref>{{cite journal
column93: title=Resolving the relationships of Paleocene placental mammals
column104: palaeanodonts]] are even closer relatives to pangolins (the latter group being classified with pangolins in the clade [[Pholidotamorpha]]<ref name=\"KondrashovAgadjanian2012\">{{cite journal
column110: title=A nearly complete skeleton of ''Ernanodon'' (Mammalia, Palaeanodonta) from Mongolia: morphofunctional analysis
column117: pages=983–1001}}</ref>). The split between carnivorans and pangolins is estimated to have occurred 79-87 Ma ago.<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" /><ref name=\"Gaubert2018\">{{Cite journal
column141: title=The Complete Phylogeny of Pangolins: Scaling Up Resources for the Molecular Tracing of the Most Trafficked Mammals on Earth

column2: title=Phylogenetic position of the Pholidota in the context of the order-level cladogram of Boreoeutheria.
caption=The cladogram has been reconstructed from [[mitochondrial DNA

column1: The first dichotomy in the [[phylogeny]] of extant Manidae separates Asian pangolins (''Manis'') from African pangolins (''Smutsia'' and ''Phataginus'').

Within the former, ''Manis pentadactyla'' is the [[sister group]] to a clade comprising ''M. crassicaudata'' and ''M. javanica''. Within the latter, a split separates large taxa of genus ''Smutsia'' from small taxa of genus ''Phataginus''.<ref name=\"Gaubert2018\" />

column2: title=Phylogenetic relationships of genera and species of Manidae.
caption=The cladogram has been reconstructed from mitochondrial genomes and a handful of nuclear DNA sequences.<ref name=\"du Toit2017\"/><ref name=\"Gaubert2018\"/>

column1: Asian and African pangolins are thought to have diverged about 38-47 Ma ago.<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" /><ref name=\"Gaubert2018\" /> Moreover, the [[basal (phylogenetics)
column2: basal]] position of ''Manis'' within Pholidota<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" /><ref name=\"du Toit2017\">{{cite journal
column15: title= Mitochondrial genomes of African pangolins and insights into evolutionary patterns and phylogeny of the family Manidae
column20: doi= 10.1186/s12864-017-4140-5}}</ref> suggests the group originated in Eurasia, consistent with their [[laurasiatheria]]n phylogeny.<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" />

column1: The physical appearance of a pangolin is marked by large hardened overlapping plate-like scales, which are soft on newborn pangolins, but harden as the animal matures.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite journal
column13: title=The First Birth and Survival of Cub in Captivity of Critically Endangered Malayan Pangolin (''Mariis javanica'')
column21: pmid=}}</ref> They are made of [[keratin]], the same material from which human [[fingernails]] and [[tetrapod]] [[Claw#Tetrapods
column22: claws]] are made, and are structurally and compositionally very different from the scales of [[reptile]]s.<ref name=Spearman2008>{{Cite journal
column25: title=On the nature of the horny scales of the pangolin
column26: journal=[[Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society]]
column33: doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1967.tb00508.x}}</ref> The pangolin's scaled body is comparable in appearance to a [[pine cone]]. It can curl up into a ball when threatened, with its overlapping scales acting as [[Armour (anatomy)
column34: armor]], while it protects its face by tucking it under its tail. The scales are sharp, providing extra defense from predators.<ref name=Wang2016>{{Cite journal
column37: title=Pangolin armor: Overlapping, structure, and mechanical properties of the keratinous scales

column1: Pangolins can emit a noxious-smelling chemical from [[gland]]s near the anus, similar to the spray of a [[skunk]].<ref>{{cite web
column8: url-status= live}}</ref> They have short legs, with sharp claws which they use for burrowing into [[ant]] and [[termite]] mounds and for climbing.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The tongues of pangolins are extremely long and – like those of the [[giant anteater]] and the [[tube-lipped nectar bat]] – the root of the tongue is not attached to the [[hyoid]] bone, but is in the [[thorax]] between the [[sternum]] and the [[vertebrate trachea
column5: title = Extrinsic Lingual Musculature of Two Pangolins (Pholidota: Manidae)
column14: jstor = 1382356}}</ref> Large pangolins can extend their tongues as much as {{Convert
column18: abbr=on}}, with a diameter of only {{Convert

column10: doi= 10.1111/j.1748-1090.1994.tb03578.x }}</ref> which use their well-developed sense of smell to find insects. The [[long-tailed pangolin]] is also active by day, while other species of pangolins spend most of the daytime sleeping, curled up into a ball.<ref name=Mondadori>{{cite book
column13: title = Great Book of the Animal Kingdom

column1: [[Arboreal]] pangolins live in hollow trees, whereas the ground-dwelling species dig tunnels to a depth of {{Convert
Some pangolins walk with their front claws bent under the foot pad, although they use the entire foot pad on their rear limbs. Furthermore, some exhibit a [[Bipedalism
column2: bipedal]] stance for some behaviour and may walk a few steps bipedally.<ref name=\"Mohapatra\">{{cite journal
column8: title=Behavioural descriptions of Indian pangolins (Manis crassicaudata) in captivity.
column14: doi=10.1155/2014/795062}}</ref> Pangolins are also good swimmers.<ref name=Mondadori/>

column1: [[File:Pangolin defending itself from lions (Gir Forest, Gujarat, India).jpg

column2: insectivorous]]. Most of their diet consists of various species of ants and termites and may be supplemented by other insects, especially larvae. They are somewhat particular and tend to consume only one or two species of insects, even when many species are available to them. A pangolin can consume {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} of insects per day.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title= Rollin' With the Pangolin – Diet
column17: url-status= live}}</ref> Pangolins are an important regulator of termite populations in their natural habitats.<ref>{{cite journal
column21: title=Transcriptomic analysis identifies genes and pathways related to myrmecophagy in the Malayan pangolin (Manis javanica)

column2: vision]], so they rely heavily on [[Olfaction
column3: smell]] and [[hearing]]. Pangolins also lack teeth; therefore they have evolved other physical characteristics to help them eat ants and termites. Their skeletal structure is sturdy and they have strong front legs that are useful for tearing into termite mounds.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite book
column12: doi=10.1002/9780470015902.a0001556.pub2}}</ref> They use their powerful front claws to dig into trees, ground, and vegetation to find prey,<ref>{{Cite journal
column16: title=Foraging behaviour and ecology of the Cape pangolin (Manis temminckii) in north-western Zimbabwe
column23: via=EBSCO}}</ref> then proceed to use their long tongues to probe inside the insect tunnels and to retrieve their prey.

column1: The structure of their tongue and stomach is key to aiding pangolins in obtaining and digesting insects. Their [[saliva]] is sticky,<ref name=\":3\" /> causing ants and termites to stick to their long tongues when they are hunting through insect tunnels. Without teeth, pangolins also lack the ability to chew;<ref name=\"Gutteridge2008\">{{cite book
column4: title=The South African Bushveld: A Field Guide from the Waterberg
column10: page=36}}</ref> however, while [[foraging]], they ingest small stones ([[gastroliths]]) which accumulate in their stomachs to help to grind up ants.<ref name=\"Publishing2015\">{{cite book
column17: page=215}}</ref> This part of their stomach is called the [[gizzard]], and it is also covered in keratinous spines.<ref>{{Cite journal
column25: title=Loss of teeth and enamel in tetrapods: fossil record, genetic data and morphological adaptations
column34: pmc=2736120}}</ref> These spines further aid in the grinding up and digestion of the pangolin's prey.

column1: Some species, such as the [[tree pangolin]], use their strong, [[prehensile]] tails to hang from tree branches and strip away bark from the trunk, exposing insect nests inside.<ref name=\"Prothero2016\">{{cite book
column4: title=The Princeton Field Guide to Prehistoric Mammals

column1: Pangolins are solitary and meet only to mate. Males are larger than females, weighing up to 40% more. While the mating season is not defined, they typically mate once each year, usually during the summer or autumn. Rather than the males seeking out the females, males mark their location with urine or feces and the females will find them. If there is competition over a female, the males will use their tails as clubs to fight for the opportunity to mate with her.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Rollin' With the Pangolin - Reproduction

column1: [[Gestation]] periods differ by species, ranging from roughly 70 to 140 days.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite journal
column17: title=Captive breeding of pangolins: current status, problems and future prospects
column24: pmid=26155072}}</ref> African pangolin females usually give birth to a single offspring at a time, but the Asiatic species may give birth to from one to three.<ref name=Mondadori/> Weight at birth is {{convert
column29: abbr=on}} and the average length is {{convert
column32: abbr=on}}. At the time of birth, the scales are soft and white. After several days, they harden and darken to resemble those of an adult pangolin. During the vulnerable stage, the mother stays with her offspring in the burrow, nursing it, and wraps her body around it if she senses danger. The young cling to the mother's tail as she moves about, although in burrowing species, they remain in the burrow for the first two to four weeks of life. At one month, they first leave the burrow riding on the mother's back. [[Weaning]] takes place around three months of age, at which stage the young begin to eat insects in addition to nursing. At two years of age, the offspring are sexually mature and are abandoned by the mother.<ref name=EoM>{{cite book

column3: A [[Philippine pangolin]] pup and its mother, a [[critically endangered]] species [[endemic]] to the [[Palawan]] island group. It is threatened by illegal poaching for the [[pangolin trade]] to [[China]] and [[Vietnam]] where it is regarded as a luxury medicinal delicacy.<ref name=\"Fabro\">{{cite news
column6: title=All hope is not lost for vanishing Palawan pangolin

column1: Pangolins are in high demand for [[Chinese traditional medicine]] in southern [[China]] and [[Vietnam]] because their scales are believed to have medicinal properties. Their meat is also considered a delicacy.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Over a million pangolins slaughtered in the last decade
column25: title=Crime Blotter: Pangolin Scales, Tiger Skins, and More
column32: title=Tiger Eyes, Crocodile Penis: It's What's For Dinner in Malaysia
column37: magazine=National Geographic}}</ref> 100,000 are estimated to be trafficked a year to China and Vietnam,<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite news
column39: title=What's the secret to saving this rare creature?
column46: first2=Tom}}</ref> amounting to over one million over the past decade.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref>{{Cite journal
column70: title=Assessing Africa-Wide Pangolin Exploitation by Scaling Local Data: Assessing African pangolin exploitation
column75: doi=10.1111/conl.12389}}</ref> This makes it the most [[Wildlife trade
column76: trafficked animal]] in the world.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref>{{cite news
column80: title=The world's most-trafficked mammal – and the scaliest
column83: access-date=2018-10-10}}</ref> This, coupled with [[deforestation]], has led to a large decrease in the numbers of pangolins. Some species, such as ''[[Chinese pangolin
column84: Manis pentadactyla]]'' have become commercially extinct in certain ranges as a result of overhunting.<ref>{{cite iucn
column102: accessdate=30 January 2020}}</ref> In November 2010, pangolins were added to the [[Zoological Society of London]]'s list of evolutionarily distinct and endangered mammals.<ref>{{cite news
column105: title='Asian unicorn' and scaly anteater make endangered list
column107: url=https://www.smh.com.au//breaking-news-world/asian-unicorn-and-scaly-anteater-make-endangered-list-20101119-180sa.html}}</ref> All eight species of pangolin are assessed as threatened by the [[IUCN]], while three are classified as [[critically endangered]].<ref name=\"IUCN Manidae\"/> All pangolin species are currently listed under Appendix I of [[CITES]] which prohibits international trade, except when the product is intended for non-commercial purposes and a permit has been granted.<ref name=CITES>{{cite web
column109: website=Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora

column1: Pangolins are also hunted and eaten in Ghana and are one of the more popular types of [[bushmeat]], while local healers use the pangolin as a source of traditional medicine.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Knowledge and uses of African pangolins as a source of traditional medicine in Ghana

column1: [[File:Pangolin scale burn in Cameroon. Credit- Kenneth Cameron - USFWS (2) (32575640450).jpg
column3: Confiscated black market pangolin scales, which are in high demand in [[Chinese traditional medicine]],<ref name=cnnchangethelist>{{cite web
column5: title=Change the List: The Most Trafficked Mammal You've Never Heard Of
column9: date=April 2014}}</ref> set to be destroyed by authorities in [[Cameroon]] in 2017]]

column1: Though pangolins are protected by an international ban on their trade, populations have suffered from illegal trafficking due to beliefs in [[East Asia]] that their ground-up scales can stimulate [[lactation]] or cure [[cancer]] or [[asthma]].<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=No Species Is Safe From Burgeoning Wildlife Trade
column10: archivedate=22 February 2015}}</ref> In the past decade, numerous seizures of illegally trafficked pangolin and pangolin meat have taken place in Asia.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=The Most Trafficked Mammal You've Never Heard Of
column21: title=23 tonnes of pangolins seized in a week
column30: title='Noah's Ark' of 5,000 rare animals found floating off the coast of China
column43: archivedate=22 February 2015}}</ref> In one such incident in April 2013, {{convert
column47: abbr=on}} of pangolin meat were seized from a [[China
column48: Chinese]] vessel that ran aground in the [[Philippines]].<ref>{{cite news
column49: title=Chinese vessel on Philippine coral reef caught with illegal pangolin meat
column63: title=Boat Filled With 22,000 Pounds Of Pangolin Hits Endangered Coral Reef
column70: archivedate=2013-04-18}}</ref> In another case in August 2016, an [[Indonesia]]n man was arrested after police raided his home and found over 650 pangolins in freezers on his property.<ref>{{cite news
column72: title=Indonesian man arrested as 650 pangolins found dead in freezers
column75: access-date=2016-08-27}}</ref> The same threat is reported in  [[Nigeria]], where the animal is on the verge of extinction due to [[overexploitation]].<ref>The ''[[Media Trust
column76: Daily Trust]]'' (Nigeria), Saturday 18 February 2017</ref> The overexploitation comes from hunting pangolins for game meat and the reduction of their forest habitats due to deforestation caused by timber harvesting.<ref name=\":5\">{{cite journal
column80: title=Pangolins in south-west Nigeria – current status and prognosis
column85: url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/231829666}}</ref> The pangolin are hunted as game meat for both medicinal purposes and food consumption.<ref name=\":5\" />

column1: [[Nucleic acid sequence]]s of [[virus]]es taken from pangolins had initially been found to be a 99% match with SARS coronavirus 2 ([[SARS-CoV-2]]), the virus which causes [[COVID-19]], and responsible for the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]].<ref name=\"Cyranoski-2020\">{{Cite journal
column5: title=Did pangolins spread the China coronavirus to people?
column14: title=Viral Metagenomics Revealed Sendai Virus and Coronavirus Infection of Malayan Pangolins (Manis javanica)
column22: pmc=6893680 }} </ref> The working theory of researchers in [[Guangzhou]], China, was that SARS-CoV-2 had originated in bats and, prior to infecting humans, was circulating among pangolins. The illicit Chinese trade of pangolins for use in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] was suggested as a [[Vector (epidemiology)
column23: vector]] for human transmission.<ref name=\"Cyranoski-2020\" /><ref name=\"Live\">{{cite web
column25: title=1st known case of coronavirus traced back to November in China

column6: accessdate=March 15, 2020}}</ref> Researchers recently have implicated the pangolins as intermediate hosts in the ongoing coronavirus pandemic as the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin coronavirus and their similarity to SARS-CoV-2 suggests that pangolins are hosts for novel coronaviruses. <ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=Identifying SARS-CoV-2 related coronaviruses in Malayan pangolins

column1: However, further study was less conclusive on pangolins as the definitive source of (SARS-CoV-2), namely being the bridge that the virus used to jump from bats to humans, after it emerged that the 99% match did not actually refer to the entire genome, but to a specific site known as the receptor-binding domain (RBD).<ref name=\"Nature-coronavirus-mystery\">{{cite journal
column3: title=Mystery deepens over animal source of coronavirus
column12: bibcode=2020Natur.579...18C }}</ref> A whole-genome comparison found that the pangolin and human viruses share only 90.3% of their RNA.<ref name=\"Nature-coronavirus-mystery\" /> Ecologists worried that the early speculation about pangolins being the source may have led to mass slaughters, endangering the animals further, which was similar to what happened to [[civet
column13: civets]] during the [[SARS]] outbreak.<ref name=\"Nature-coronavirus-mystery\" /><ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Civet Cat Slaughter To Fight SARS

column1: The medical powers of pangolin meat and scales claimed by [[traditional Chinese medicine]] are based on behavioral observations: they eat ants; they have long tongues, and they have scales that protect them. The Chinese name ''chuan shan jia'' ({{lang
column3: 穿山甲}}) \"penetrating-the-mountain scales\") emphasizes the idea of penetration({{lang
column5: 穿}})  or passing all the way through even massive obstructions such as mountains({{lang
column9: 甲}})  which embody both penetration and protection and imply similar powers to penetrate blockages within the body and to give protection.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=我们仍未知道那天穿山甲说了什么
column17: quote=中医黑子常用来抨击中医的“穿山甲能穿山，所以能通经络”这句话的原文出处大概是《本草纲目》}}</ref>

column1: The first record of pangolin scales occurs in ''Ben Cao Jinji Zhu'' (\"Variorum of Shennong's Classic of Materia Medica\", 500 CE), which recommends pangolin scales for protection against ant bites; burning the scales is a cure for people crying hysterically during the night.<ref name=PanMed>{{cite book
column23: chapter=Meat and medicine: historic and contemporary use in Asia

column1: During the [[Tang dynasty]], a recipe for expelling evil spirits with a formulation of scales, herbs, and minerals appeared in 682, and in 752 CE the idea that pangolin scales could also stimulate milk secretion in lactating women, one of the important uses today, was recommended in the ''Wai Tai Mi Yao'' (\"Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library\").<ref name=PanMed/>

In the [[Song dynasty]], the notion of penetrating and clearing blockages was emphasized in the ''Taiping sheng hui fan''  (\"Formulas from Benevolent Sages Compiled During the Era of Peace and Tranquility\"), compiled by Wang Huaiyin in 992.<ref name=PanMed/>

Today the main uses of pangolin scales are to unblock blood clots, promote blood circulation, and to help lactating women secrete milk. There are many other applications for treating gynecological diseases, and pills that contain powdered pangolin scales are used for treating blockages of the fallopian tubes to cure infertility.<ref name=PanMed/>

The official [[pharmacopoeia]] of the [[People's Republic of China]] continues to include Chinese pangolin scales as an ingredient in TCM formulations, and there is a legal market for scales.<ref name=PanMed/>

column5: A coat of [[armor]] made of gilded pangolin scales from India, presented to [[George III of the United Kingdom

column1: As a result of increasing threats to pangolins, mainly in the form of illegal, international trade in pangolin skin, scales, and meat, these species have received increasing conservation attention in recent years. {{As of
column2: January 2020}}, the IUCN considered all eight species of pangolin on its [[IUCN Red List
column3: Red List of Threatened Species]] as threatened.<ref name=\"IUCN Manidae\"/> Also, the IUCN SSC Pangolin Specialist Group launched a global action plan to conserve pangolins, dubbed \"Scaling up Pangolin Conservation\" in July 2014. This action plan aims to improve all aspects of pangolin conservation with an added emphasis on combating poaching and trafficking of the animal, while educating communities in its importance.<ref name=\":1\">{{cite web
column7: access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref> Another suggested approach to fighting pangolin (and general wildlife) trafficking consists in \"following the money\" rather than \"the animal\", which aims to disrupt smugglers' profits by interrupting money flows. Financial intelligence gathering could thus become a key tool in protecting these animals, although this opportunity is often overlooked.<ref name=\":4\" /> In 2018, a Chinese NGO launched the Counting Pangolins movement, calling for joint efforts to save the mammals from [[trafficking]].<ref>Xinhua News (2018-11-21) [http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-11/21/c_137620372.htm Spotlight: Pangolin conservationists call for ban on illegal trade of mammal products]</ref><ref>China Plus (2017-02-18) [http://english.cri.cn/12394/2017/02/18/3124s952140.htm World Pangolin Day: Conservationists demand greater protection to stop extinction]</ref><ref>Xinhua News (2018-06-08) [http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-06/08/c_137240161.htm How China is combating wildlife trafficking in Africa]</ref> Wildlife conservation group [[Traffic (conservation programme)
column8: TRAFFIC]] has identified 159 smuggling routes used by pangolin traffickers and aims to shut these down.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Pangolins – Species we work with at TRAFFIC

column3: Pangolins in an illegal wildlife market in [[Myanmar]]]]

column1: Many attempts have been made to reproduce pangolins in captivity, but due to their reliance on wide-ranging habitats and very particular diets, these attempts are often unsuccessful.<ref name=\":0\" /><ref>{{cite journal
column21: title=Complications Associated with Pregnancy and Parturition in African White-bellied Pangolins (Phataginus Tricuspis)
column22: journal=Journal of Zoo and Wildlife Medicine
column26: pages=678–687 }}</ref> Pangolins have significantly decreased immune responses due to a genetic dysfunction, making them extremely fragile.<ref>{{cite journal
column89: title=Pangolin genomes and the evolution of mammalian scales and immunity
column96: pages=1312–1322}}</ref> They are susceptible to diseases such as [[pneumonia]] and the development of [[Stress ulcer
column97: ulcers]] in captivity, complications which can lead to an early death.<ref name=\":0\" /> In addition, pangolins rescued from illegal trade often have a higher chance of being infected with parasites such as [[intestinal worms]], further lessening their chance for rehabilitation and reintroduction to the wild.<ref name=\":0\" /> Recently, researchers have been able to improve artificial pangolin habitats to allow for reproduction of pangolins, providing some hope for future reintroduction of these species into their natural habitats.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: The idea of  farming pangolins to reduce the amount being illegally trafficked is being explored with little success.<ref>{{cite journal
column25: title=Evaluating the feasibility of pangolin farming and its potential conservation impact
column29: pages=e00714 }}</ref> The third Saturday in February is promoted as World Pangolin Day by the conservation NPO Annamiticus.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2017, [[Jackie Chan]] made a public service announcement called ''[[WildAid]]: Jackie Chan & Pangolins (Kung Fu Pangolin)''.<ref name=pangolins>{{cite news
Taiwan is one of the few conservation grounds for pangolins in the world after the country enacted the 1989 Wildlife Conservation Act.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Taiwan's Path to Pangolin Conservation : How a Mega Pangolin Leather Exporter Transformed into a Conservation Specialist
column6: accessdate= 2020-02-08}}</ref> The introduction of Wildlife Rehabilitation Centers in places like Luanshan ([[Yanping Township]]) in [[Taitung County
column9: Hualien]] became important communities for protecting pangolins and their habitats and has greatly improved the survival of pangolins. These centres work with local aboriginal tribes and forest police in the National Police Agency to prevent poaching, trafficking, and smuggling of pangolins, especially to black markets in China. These centres have also helped to reveal the causes of death and injury among Taiwan's pangolin population.<ref>{{cite journal
column25: title=Mortality and morbidity in wild Taiwanese pangolin (''Manis pentadactyla pentadactyla'')

column1: Today, Taiwan has the highest population density of pangolins in the world.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Taiwanese Researchers Collaborate With Locals In Pangolin Conservation

column1: * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090417080037/http://www.awf.org/content/wildlife/detail/pangolin Pangolin: Wildlife summary from the African Wildlife Foundation]
* [http://cmsdata.iucn.org/downloads/pangolin_proceedings_final_print__2_.pdf Proceedings of the Workshop on Trade and Conservation of Pangolins Native to South and Southeast Asia] (PDF)
* [http://web2.utc.edu/~gvv824/Gaudin%20et%20al%202009.pdf The Phylogeny of Living and Extinct Pangolins (Mammalia, Pholidota) and Associated Taxa: A Morphology Based Analysis] (PDF)

column2: people=Bromley, Victoria (Director/Producer), Young, Nora (Narrator/Host), Diekmann, Maria
column4: title=Nature: The World's Most Wanted Animal

column1: * [https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/05/opinion/coronavirus-china-pangolins.html  Coronavirus: Revenge of the Pangolins?] ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 6, 2020.
[[Category:Species endangered by human consumption for medicinal or magical purposes]]
[[Category:Taxa named by John Edward Gray]]","{{short description
[[File:A pangolin in defensive posture, Horniman Museum, London.jpg
column3: A pangolin in defensive posture, Horniman Museum, London]]

column9: short=x}}</ref> are [[mammals]] of the order '''Pholidota''' (from [[Ancient Greek]] [[wikt:φολίς
column11: extant]] family, '''Manidae''', has three genera: ''[[Manis]]'', ''[[Phataginus]]'' and ''[[Smutsia]]''. ''Manis'' comprises the four species found in Asia, while ''Phataginus'' and ''Smutsia'' each include two species living in Sub-Saharan Africa.<ref name=\"web2.utc.edu\">{{cite journal
column15: title=The Phylogeny of Living and Extinct Pangolins (Mammalia, Pholidota) and Associated Taxa: A Morphology Based Analysis
column24: accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> These species range in size from {{convert
column29: abbr=on}}. A number of [[extinct]] pangolin species are also known.

column1: Pangolins have large, protective [[keratin]] scales covering their skin; they are the only known mammals with this feature. They live in hollow trees or [[burrow]]s, depending on the species. Pangolins are [[nocturnal]], and their diet consists of mainly [[ants]] and [[termites]], which they capture using their long tongues. They tend to be solitary animals, meeting only to mate and produce a litter of one to three offspring, which they raise for about two years.

column2: threatened by poaching]] (for their meat and scales, which are used in [[Chinese traditional medicine]] for a variety of ailments including excessive anxiety and hysterical crying in children, women thought to be possessed by [[devil]]s and [[ogre]]s, [[malaria]]l fever, and deafness<ref>{{cite journal
column10: bibcode=1938Natur.141R..72. }}</ref>) and heavy [[deforestation]] of their natural habitats, and are the most [[wildlife smuggling
column11: trafficked]] mammals in the world.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=A Struggle to Save the Scaly Pangolin
column21: January 2020}}, of the eight species of pangolin, three (''[[Manis culionensis]]'', ''[[Manis pentadactyla
column23: M. javanica]]'') are listed as critically endangered, three (''[[Phataginus tricuspis]]'', ''[[Manis crassicaudata]]'' and ''[[Smutsia gigantea]]'') are listed as endangered and two (''[[Phataginus tetradactyla]]'' and ''[[Smutsia temminckii]]'') are listed as vulnerable on the [[Red List of Threatened Species]] of the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]].<ref name=\"IUCN Manidae\">{{cite web
column25: website=[[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]

column1: The name ''pangolin'' comes from the [[Malay language
column2: Malay]] word ''pengguling'', meaning \"one who rolls up\".<ref name=COED>{{cite book
column11: page=1030}}</ref> However, the modern name in [[Malay language
column12: Standard Malay]] is ''tenggiling''; whereas in [[Indonesian language
column13: Indonesian]] it is ''trenggiling''; and in the [[Philippine languages]] it is ''goling'', ''tanggiling'', or ''balintong'' (with the same meaning).<ref name=\"Vergara\">{{cite book

column1: The etymologies of the three generic names ''Manis'' (Linnaeus, 1758), ''Phataginus'' (Rafinesque, 1821), and ''Smutsia'' (Gray, 1865) are sometimes misunderstood.

column2: Neo-Latin]] generic name ''Manis'' apparently as a feminine singular form of the Latin masculine plural [[Manes]], the [[Ancient Rome
column3: Ancient Roman]] name for a type of [[spirit]], after the animal's strange appearance.<ref>{{cite web

column1: [[Constantine Rafinesque]] (1821) formed the Neo-Latin generic name ''Phataginus'' from the French term ''phatagin'', adopted by [[Count Buffon]] (1763) after the reported local name ''phatagin'' or ''phatagen'' used in the [[East Indies]].
The British [[naturalist]] [[John Edward Gray]] named ''Smutsia'' for the [[South Africa]]n naturalist [[Johannes Smuts]] (1808–1869),<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=S2A3 Biographical Database of Southern African Science [Johannes Smuts]
column8: title=Index Generum Mammalium: a List of the Genera and Families of Mammals
column14: access-date=May 28, 2018}}</ref> the first South African to write a [[treatise]] on mammals in 1832 (in which he described the species ''Manis temminckii'').

column1: All species of living pangolin had been assigned to the genus ''Manis'' until the late 2000s, when research prompted the splitting of extant pangolins into three genera: ''Manis'', ''Phataginus'', and ''Smutsia''.<ref name=\"web2.utc.edu\"/><ref name=\"KondrashovAgadjanian2012\"/>
** Genus †''[[Euromanis]]'' <small>(Storch & Martin, 1994) Gaudin, Emry & Wible, 2009</small> [''[[Eomanis krebsi]]'' <small>Storch & Martin, 1994</small>]
**** Family [[Patriomanidae]] <small>Szalay & Schrenk 1998 sensu Gaudin, Emry & Pogue, 2006</small>

The order Pholidota in the past was considered to be the [[sister taxon]] to [[Xenarthra]] (neotropical [[anteater]]s, [[sloth]]s, and [[armadillo]]s), but recent genetic evidence indicates their closest living relatives are the [[carnivora]]ns, with which they form a [[clade]] termed either [[Ferae]] or Ostentoria.<ref>{{cite journal
column27: title=Resolution of the Early Placental Mammal Radiation Using Bayesian Phylogenetics
column40: title = A new phylogenetic marker, apolipoprotein B, provides compelling evidence for eutherian relationships
column57: title=A higher-level MRP supertree of placental mammals
column80: title= The complete mitochondrial genome of Temminck's ground pangolin (''Smutsia temminckii''; Smuts, 1832) and phylogenetic position of the Pholidota (Weber, 1904)
column86: doi= 10.1016/j.gene.2014.08.040}}</ref> Fossil groups like the [[creodont]]s<ref>{{cite journal
column93: title=Resolving the relationships of Paleocene placental mammals
column104: palaeanodonts]] are even closer relatives to pangolins (the latter group being classified with pangolins in the clade [[Pholidotamorpha]]<ref name=\"KondrashovAgadjanian2012\">{{cite journal
column110: title=A nearly complete skeleton of ''Ernanodon'' (Mammalia, Palaeanodonta) from Mongolia: morphofunctional analysis
column117: pages=983–1001}}</ref>). The split between carnivorans and pangolins is estimated to have occurred 79-87 Ma ago.<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" /><ref name=\"Gaubert2018\">{{Cite journal
column141: title=The Complete Phylogeny of Pangolins: Scaling Up Resources for the Molecular Tracing of the Most Trafficked Mammals on Earth

column2: title=Phylogenetic position of the Pholidota in the context of the order-level cladogram of Boreoeutheria.
caption=The cladogram has been reconstructed from [[mitochondrial DNA

column1: The first dichotomy in the [[phylogeny]] of extant Manidae separates Asian pangolins (''Manis'') from African pangolins (''Smutsia'' and ''Phataginus'').

Within the former, ''Manis pentadactyla'' is the [[sister group]] to a clade comprising ''M. crassicaudata'' and ''M. javanica''. Within the latter, a split separates large taxa of genus ''Smutsia'' from small taxa of genus ''Phataginus''.<ref name=\"Gaubert2018\" />

column2: title=Phylogenetic relationships of genera and species of Manidae.
caption=The cladogram has been reconstructed from mitochondrial genomes and a handful of nuclear DNA sequences.<ref name=\"du Toit2017\"/><ref name=\"Gaubert2018\"/>

column1: Asian and African pangolins are thought to have diverged about 38-47 Ma ago.<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" /><ref name=\"Gaubert2018\" /> Moreover, the [[basal (phylogenetics)
column2: basal]] position of ''Manis'' within Pholidota<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" /><ref name=\"du Toit2017\">{{cite journal
column15: title= Mitochondrial genomes of African pangolins and insights into evolutionary patterns and phylogeny of the family Manidae
column20: doi= 10.1186/s12864-017-4140-5}}</ref> suggests the group originated in Eurasia, consistent with their [[laurasiatheria]]n phylogeny.<ref name=\"Du Toit2014\" />

column1: The physical appearance of a pangolin is marked by large hardened overlapping plate-like scales, which are soft on newborn pangolins, but harden as the animal matures.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite journal
column13: title=The First Birth and Survival of Cub in Captivity of Critically Endangered Malayan Pangolin (''Mariis javanica'')
column21: pmid=}}</ref> They are made of [[keratin]], the same material from which human [[fingernails]] and [[tetrapod]] [[Claw#Tetrapods
column22: claws]] are made, and are structurally and compositionally very different from the scales of [[reptile]]s.<ref name=Spearman2008>{{Cite journal
column25: title=On the nature of the horny scales of the pangolin
column26: journal=[[Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society]]
column33: doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1967.tb00508.x}}</ref> The pangolin's scaled body is comparable in appearance to a [[pine cone]]. It can curl up into a ball when threatened, with its overlapping scales acting as [[Armour (anatomy)
column34: armor]], while it protects its face by tucking it under its tail. The scales are sharp, providing extra defense from predators.<ref name=Wang2016>{{Cite journal
column37: title=Pangolin armor: Overlapping, structure, and mechanical properties of the keratinous scales

column1: Pangolins can emit a noxious-smelling chemical from [[gland]]s near the anus, similar to the spray of a [[skunk]].<ref>{{cite web
column8: url-status= live}}</ref> They have short legs, with sharp claws which they use for burrowing into [[ant]] and [[termite]] mounds and for climbing.<ref>{{cite web

column1: The tongues of pangolins are extremely long and – like those of the [[giant anteater]] and the [[tube-lipped nectar bat]] – the root of the tongue is not attached to the [[hyoid]] bone, but is in the [[thorax]] between the [[sternum]] and the [[vertebrate trachea
column5: title = Extrinsic Lingual Musculature of Two Pangolins (Pholidota: Manidae)
column14: jstor = 1382356}}</ref> Large pangolins can extend their tongues as much as {{Convert
column18: abbr=on}}, with a diameter of only {{Convert

column10: doi= 10.1111/j.1748-1090.1994.tb03578.x }}</ref> which use their well-developed sense of smell to find insects. The [[long-tailed pangolin]] is also active by day, while other species of pangolins spend most of the daytime sleeping, curled up into a ball.<ref name=Mondadori>{{cite book
column13: title = Great Book of the Animal Kingdom

column1: [[Arboreal]] pangolins live in hollow trees, whereas the ground-dwelling species dig tunnels to a depth of {{Convert
Some pangolins walk with their front claws bent under the foot pad, although they use the entire foot pad on their rear limbs. Furthermore, some exhibit a [[Bipedalism
column2: bipedal]] stance for some behaviour and may walk a few steps bipedally.<ref name=\"Mohapatra\">{{cite journal
column8: title=Behavioural descriptions of Indian pangolins (Manis crassicaudata) in captivity.
column14: doi=10.1155/2014/795062}}</ref> Pangolins are also good swimmers.<ref name=Mondadori/>

column1: [[File:Pangolin defending itself from lions (Gir Forest, Gujarat, India).jpg

column2: insectivorous]]. Most of their diet consists of various species of ants and termites and may be supplemented by other insects, especially larvae. They are somewhat particular and tend to consume only one or two species of insects, even when many species are available to them. A pangolin can consume {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} of insects per day.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title= Rollin' With the Pangolin – Diet
column17: url-status= live}}</ref> Pangolins are an important regulator of termite populations in their natural habitats.<ref>{{cite journal
column21: title=Transcriptomic analysis identifies genes and pathways related to myrmecophagy in the Malayan pangolin (Manis javanica)

column2: vision]], so they rely heavily on [[Olfaction
column3: smell]] and [[hearing]]. Pangolins also lack teeth; therefore they have evolved other physical characteristics to help them eat ants and termites. Their skeletal structure is sturdy and they have strong front legs that are useful for tearing into termite mounds.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite book
column12: doi=10.1002/9780470015902.a0001556.pub2}}</ref> They use their powerful front claws to dig into trees, ground, and vegetation to find prey,<ref>{{Cite journal
column16: title=Foraging behaviour and ecology of the Cape pangolin (Manis temminckii) in north-western Zimbabwe
column23: via=EBSCO}}</ref> then proceed to use their long tongues to probe inside the insect tunnels and to retrieve their prey.

column1: The structure of their tongue and stomach is key to aiding pangolins in obtaining and digesting insects. Their [[saliva]] is sticky,<ref name=\":3\" /> causing ants and termites to stick to their long tongues when they are hunting through insect tunnels. Without teeth, pangolins also lack the ability to chew;<ref name=\"Gutteridge2008\">{{cite book
column4: title=The South African Bushveld: A Field Guide from the Waterberg
column10: page=36}}</ref> however, while [[foraging]], they ingest small stones ([[gastroliths]]) which accumulate in their stomachs to help to grind up ants.<ref name=\"Publishing2015\">{{cite book
column17: page=215}}</ref> This part of their stomach is called the [[gizzard]], and it is also covered in keratinous spines.<ref>{{Cite journal
column25: title=Loss of teeth and enamel in tetrapods: fossil record, genetic data and morphological adaptations
column34: pmc=2736120}}</ref> These spines further aid in the grinding up and digestion of the pangolin's prey.

column1: Some species, such as the [[tree pangolin]], use their strong, [[prehensile]] tails to hang from tree branches and strip away bark from the trunk, exposing insect nests inside.<ref name=\"Prothero2016\">{{cite book
column4: title=The Princeton Field Guide to Prehistoric Mammals

column1: Pangolins are solitary and meet only to mate. Males are larger than females, weighing up to 40% more. While the mating season is not defined, they typically mate once each year, usually during the summer or autumn. Rather than the males seeking out the females, males mark their location with urine or feces and the females will find them. If there is competition over a female, the males will use their tails as clubs to fight for the opportunity to mate with her.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Rollin' With the Pangolin - Reproduction

column1: [[Gestation]] periods differ by species, ranging from roughly 70 to 140 days.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite journal
column17: title=Captive breeding of pangolins: current status, problems and future prospects
column24: pmid=26155072}}</ref> African pangolin females usually give birth to a single offspring at a time, but the Asiatic species may give birth to from one to three.<ref name=Mondadori/> Weight at birth is {{convert
column29: abbr=on}} and the average length is {{convert
column32: abbr=on}}. At the time of birth, the scales are soft and white. After several days, they harden and darken to resemble those of an adult pangolin. During the vulnerable stage, the mother stays with her offspring in the burrow, nursing it, and wraps her body around it if she senses danger. The young cling to the mother's tail as she moves about, although in burrowing species, they remain in the burrow for the first two to four weeks of life. At one month, they first leave the burrow riding on the mother's back. [[Weaning]] takes place around three months of age, at which stage the young begin to eat insects in addition to nursing. At two years of age, the offspring are sexually mature and are abandoned by the mother.<ref name=EoM>{{cite book

column3: A [[Philippine pangolin]] pup and its mother, a [[critically endangered]] species [[endemic]] to the [[Palawan]] island group. It is threatened by illegal poaching for the [[pangolin trade]] to [[China]] and [[Vietnam]] where it is regarded as a luxury medicinal delicacy.<ref name=\"Fabro\">{{cite news
column6: title=All hope is not lost for vanishing Palawan pangolin

column1: Pangolins are in high demand for [[Chinese traditional medicine]] in southern [[China]] and [[Vietnam]] because their scales are believed to have medicinal properties. Their meat is also considered a delicacy.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Over a million pangolins slaughtered in the last decade
column25: title=Crime Blotter: Pangolin Scales, Tiger Skins, and More
column32: title=Tiger Eyes, Crocodile Penis: It's What's For Dinner in Malaysia
column37: magazine=National Geographic}}</ref> 100,000 are estimated to be trafficked a year to China and Vietnam,<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite news
column39: title=What's the secret to saving this rare creature?
column46: first2=Tom}}</ref> amounting to over one million over the past decade.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref>{{Cite journal
column70: title=Assessing Africa-Wide Pangolin Exploitation by Scaling Local Data: Assessing African pangolin exploitation
column75: doi=10.1111/conl.12389}}</ref> This makes it the most [[Wildlife trade
column76: trafficked animal]] in the world.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref>{{cite news
column80: title=The world's most-trafficked mammal – and the scaliest
column83: access-date=2018-10-10}}</ref> This, coupled with [[deforestation]], has led to a large decrease in the numbers of pangolins. Some species, such as ''[[Chinese pangolin
column84: Manis pentadactyla]]'' have become commercially extinct in certain ranges as a result of overhunting.<ref>{{cite iucn
column102: accessdate=30 January 2020}}</ref> In November 2010, pangolins were added to the [[Zoological Society of London]]'s list of evolutionarily distinct and endangered mammals.<ref>{{cite news
column105: title='Asian unicorn' and scaly anteater make endangered list
column107: url=https://www.smh.com.au//breaking-news-world/asian-unicorn-and-scaly-anteater-make-endangered-list-20101119-180sa.html}}</ref> All eight species of pangolin are assessed as threatened by the [[IUCN]], while three are classified as [[critically endangered]].<ref name=\"IUCN Manidae\"/> All pangolin species are currently listed under Appendix I of [[CITES]] which prohibits international trade, except when the product is intended for non-commercial purposes and a permit has been granted.<ref name=CITES>{{cite web
column109: website=Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora

column1: Pangolins are also hunted and eaten in Ghana and are one of the more popular types of [[bushmeat]], while local healers use the pangolin as a source of traditional medicine.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Knowledge and uses of African pangolins as a source of traditional medicine in Ghana

column1: [[File:Pangolin scale burn in Cameroon. Credit- Kenneth Cameron - USFWS (2) (32575640450).jpg
column3: Confiscated black market pangolin scales, which are in high demand in [[Chinese traditional medicine]],<ref name=cnnchangethelist>{{cite web
column5: title=Change the List: The Most Trafficked Mammal You've Never Heard Of
column9: date=April 2014}}</ref> set to be destroyed by authorities in [[Cameroon]] in 2017]]

column1: Though pangolins are protected by an international ban on their trade, populations have suffered from illegal trafficking due to beliefs in [[East Asia]] that their ground-up scales can stimulate [[lactation]] or cure [[cancer]] or [[asthma]].<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=No Species Is Safe From Burgeoning Wildlife Trade
column10: archivedate=22 February 2015}}</ref> In the past decade, numerous seizures of illegally trafficked pangolin and pangolin meat have taken place in Asia.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=The Most Trafficked Mammal You've Never Heard Of
column21: title=23 tonnes of pangolins seized in a week
column30: title='Noah's Ark' of 5,000 rare animals found floating off the coast of China
column43: archivedate=22 February 2015}}</ref> In one such incident in April 2013, {{convert
column47: abbr=on}} of pangolin meat were seized from a [[China
column48: Chinese]] vessel that ran aground in the [[Philippines]].<ref>{{cite news
column49: title=Chinese vessel on Philippine coral reef caught with illegal pangolin meat
column63: title=Boat Filled With 22,000 Pounds Of Pangolin Hits Endangered Coral Reef
column70: archivedate=2013-04-18}}</ref> In another case in August 2016, an [[Indonesia]]n man was arrested after police raided his home and found over 650 pangolins in freezers on his property.<ref>{{cite news
column72: title=Indonesian man arrested as 650 pangolins found dead in freezers
column75: access-date=2016-08-27}}</ref> The same threat is reported in  [[Nigeria]], where the animal is on the verge of extinction due to [[overexploitation]].<ref>The ''[[Media Trust
column76: Daily Trust]]'' (Nigeria), Saturday 18 February 2017</ref> The overexploitation comes from hunting pangolins for game meat and the reduction of their forest habitats due to deforestation caused by timber harvesting.<ref name=\":5\">{{cite journal
column80: title=Pangolins in south-west Nigeria – current status and prognosis
column85: url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/231829666}}</ref> The pangolin are hunted as game meat for both medicinal purposes and food consumption.<ref name=\":5\" />

column1: [[Nucleic acid sequence]]s of [[virus]]es taken from pangolins had initially been found to be a 99% match with SARS coronavirus 2 ([[SARS-CoV-2]]), the virus which causes [[COVID-19]], and responsible for the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]].<ref name=\"Cyranoski-2020\">{{Cite journal
column5: title=Did pangolins spread the China coronavirus to people?
column14: title=Viral Metagenomics Revealed Sendai Virus and Coronavirus Infection of Malayan Pangolins (Manis javanica)
column22: pmc=6893680 }} </ref> The working theory of researchers in [[Guangzhou]], China, was that SARS-CoV-2 had originated in bats and, prior to infecting humans, was circulating among pangolins. The illicit Chinese trade of pangolins for use in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] was suggested as a [[Vector (epidemiology)
column23: vector]] for human transmission.<ref name=\"Cyranoski-2020\" /><ref name=\"Live\">{{cite web
column25: title=1st known case of coronavirus traced back to November in China

column6: accessdate=March 15, 2020}}</ref> Researchers recently have implicated the pangolins as intermediate hosts in the ongoing coronavirus pandemic as the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin coronavirus and their similarity to SARS-CoV-2 suggests that pangolins are hosts for novel coronaviruses. <ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=Identifying SARS-CoV-2 related coronaviruses in Malayan pangolins

column1: However, further study was less conclusive on pangolins as the definitive source of (SARS-CoV-2), namely being the bridge that the virus used to jump from bats to humans, after it emerged that the 99% match did not actually refer to the entire genome, but to a specific site known as the receptor-binding domain (RBD).<ref name=\"Nature-coronavirus-mystery\">{{cite journal
column3: title=Mystery deepens over animal source of coronavirus
column12: bibcode=2020Natur.579...18C }}</ref> A whole-genome comparison found that the pangolin and human viruses share only 90.3% of their RNA.<ref name=\"Nature-coronavirus-mystery\" /> Ecologists worried that the early speculation about pangolins being the source may have led to mass slaughters, endangering the animals further, which was similar to what happened to [[civet
column13: civets]] during the [[SARS]] outbreak.<ref name=\"Nature-coronavirus-mystery\" /><ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Civet Cat Slaughter To Fight SARS

column1: The medical powers of pangolin meat and scales claimed by [[traditional Chinese medicine]] are based on behavioral observations: they eat ants; they have long tongues, and they have scales that protect them. The Chinese name ''chuan shan jia'' ({{lang
column3: 穿山甲}}) \"penetrating-the-mountain scales\") emphasizes the idea of penetration({{lang
column5: 穿}})  or passing all the way through even massive obstructions such as mountains({{lang
column9: 甲}})  which embody both penetration and protection and imply similar powers to penetrate blockages within the body and to give protection.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=我们仍未知道那天穿山甲说了什么
column17: quote=中医黑子常用来抨击中医的“穿山甲能穿山，所以能通经络”这句话的原文出处大概是《本草纲目》}}</ref>

column1: The first record of pangolin scales occurs in ''Ben Cao Jinji Zhu'' (\"Variorum of Shennong's Classic of Materia Medica\", 500 CE), which recommends pangolin scales for protection against ant bites; burning the scales is a cure for people crying hysterically during the night.<ref name=PanMed>{{cite book
column23: chapter=Meat and medicine: historic and contemporary use in Asia

column1: During the [[Tang dynasty]], a recipe for expelling evil spirits with a formulation of scales, herbs, and minerals appeared in 682, and in 752 CE the idea that pangolin scales could also stimulate milk secretion in lactating women, one of the important uses today, was recommended in the ''Wai Tai Mi Yao'' (\"Arcane Essentials from the Imperial Library\").<ref name=PanMed/>

In the [[Song dynasty]], the notion of penetrating and clearing blockages was emphasized in the ''Taiping sheng hui fan''  (\"Formulas from Benevolent Sages Compiled During the Era of Peace and Tranquility\"), compiled by Wang Huaiyin in 992.<ref name=PanMed/>

Today the main uses of pangolin scales are to unblock blood clots, promote blood circulation, and to help lactating women secrete milk. There are many other applications for treating gynecological diseases, and pills that contain powdered pangolin scales are used for treating blockages of the fallopian tubes to cure infertility.<ref name=PanMed/>

The official [[pharmacopoeia]] of the [[People's Republic of China]] continues to include Chinese pangolin scales as an ingredient in TCM formulations, and there is a legal market for scales.<ref name=PanMed/>

column5: A coat of [[armor]] made of gilded pangolin scales from India, presented to [[George III of the United Kingdom

column1: As a result of increasing threats to pangolins, mainly in the form of illegal, international trade in pangolin skin, scales, and meat, these species have received increasing conservation attention in recent years. {{As of
column2: January 2020}}, the IUCN considered all eight species of pangolin on its [[IUCN Red List
column3: Red List of Threatened Species]] as threatened.<ref name=\"IUCN Manidae\"/> Also, the IUCN SSC Pangolin Specialist Group launched a global action plan to conserve pangolins, dubbed \"Scaling up Pangolin Conservation\" in July 2014. This action plan aims to improve all aspects of pangolin conservation with an added emphasis on combating poaching and trafficking of the animal, while educating communities in its importance.<ref name=\":1\">{{cite web
column7: access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref> Another suggested approach to fighting pangolin (and general wildlife) trafficking consists in \"following the money\" rather than \"the animal\", which aims to disrupt smugglers' profits by interrupting money flows. Financial intelligence gathering could thus become a key tool in protecting these animals, although this opportunity is often overlooked.<ref name=\":4\" /> In 2018, a Chinese NGO launched the Counting Pangolins movement, calling for joint efforts to save the mammals from [[trafficking]].<ref>Xinhua News (2018-11-21) [http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-11/21/c_137620372.htm Spotlight: Pangolin conservationists call for ban on illegal trade of mammal products]</ref><ref>China Plus (2017-02-18) [http://english.cri.cn/12394/2017/02/18/3124s952140.htm World Pangolin Day: Conservationists demand greater protection to stop extinction]</ref><ref>Xinhua News (2018-06-08) [http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-06/08/c_137240161.htm How China is combating wildlife trafficking in Africa]</ref> Wildlife conservation group [[Traffic (conservation programme)
column8: TRAFFIC]] has identified 159 smuggling routes used by pangolin traffickers and aims to shut these down.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Pangolins – Species we work with at TRAFFIC

column3: Pangolins in an illegal wildlife market in [[Myanmar]]]]

column1: Many attempts have been made to reproduce pangolins in captivity, but due to their reliance on wide-ranging habitats and very particular diets, these attempts are often unsuccessful.<ref name=\":0\" /><ref>{{cite journal
column21: title=Complications Associated with Pregnancy and Parturition in African White-bellied Pangolins (Phataginus Tricuspis)
column22: journal=Journal of Zoo and Wildlife Medicine
column26: pages=678–687 }}</ref> Pangolins have significantly decreased immune responses due to a genetic dysfunction, making them extremely fragile.<ref>{{cite journal
column89: title=Pangolin genomes and the evolution of mammalian scales and immunity
column96: pages=1312–1322}}</ref> They are susceptible to diseases such as [[pneumonia]] and the development of [[Stress ulcer
column97: ulcers]] in captivity, complications which can lead to an early death.<ref name=\":0\" /> In addition, pangolins rescued from illegal trade often have a higher chance of being infected with parasites such as [[intestinal worms]], further lessening their chance for rehabilitation and reintroduction to the wild.<ref name=\":0\" /> Recently, researchers have been able to improve artificial pangolin habitats to allow for reproduction of pangolins, providing some hope for future reintroduction of these species into their natural habitats.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: The idea of  farming pangolins to reduce the amount being illegally trafficked is being explored with little success.<ref>{{cite journal
column25: title=Evaluating the feasibility of pangolin farming and its potential conservation impact
column29: pages=e00714 }}</ref> The third Saturday in February is promoted as World Pangolin Day by the conservation NPO Annamiticus.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2017, [[Jackie Chan]] made a public service announcement called ''[[WildAid]]: Jackie Chan & Pangolins (Kung Fu Pangolin)''.<ref name=pangolins>{{cite news
Taiwan is one of the few conservation grounds for pangolins in the world after the country enacted the 1989 Wildlife Conservation Act.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Taiwan's Path to Pangolin Conservation : How a Mega Pangolin Leather Exporter Transformed into a Conservation Specialist
column6: accessdate= 2020-02-08}}</ref> The introduction of Wildlife Rehabilitation Centers in places like Luanshan ([[Yanping Township]]) in [[Taitung County
column9: Hualien]] became important communities for protecting pangolins and their habitats and has greatly improved the survival of pangolins. These centres work with local aboriginal tribes and forest police in the National Police Agency to prevent poaching, trafficking, and smuggling of pangolins, especially to black markets in China. These centres have also helped to reveal the causes of death and injury among Taiwan's pangolin population.<ref>{{cite journal
column25: title=Mortality and morbidity in wild Taiwanese pangolin (''Manis pentadactyla pentadactyla'')

column1: Today, Taiwan has the highest population density of pangolins in the world.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Taiwanese Researchers Collaborate With Locals In Pangolin Conservation

column5: title=Profile: Abdullah Ocalan ( Greyer and tempered by long isolation, PKK leader is braving the scepticism of many Turks, and some of his own fighters)
