column10: title=The Kurdish Spring: A New Map of the Middle East
column18: title=Who Becomes a Terrorist and Why?: The Psychology and Sociology of Terrorism
column26: title=Kurdish rebel chief Ocalan dons mantle of peacemaker

column2: occupation         = Founder and leader of militant organization [[Kurdistan Workers' Party
column3: PKK]],<ref name=\"Paul\">Paul J. White, ''Primitive rebels or revolutionary modernizers?: The Kurdish national movement in Turkey'', Zed Books, 2000, [https://books.google.com/books?id=a80KQ4jdOeUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Primitive+rebels+or+revolutionary+modernizers%3F&hl=tr&ei=fojfTNauOYSkvgOt75HbDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22nationalist%20leader%22&f=false \"Professor Robert Olson, University of Kentucky\"]</ref> political activist, writer, [[List of political theorists

column2: education          = [[Faculty of Political Science, Ankara University
column3: Ankara University, Faculty of Political Science]]<ref>{{cite book
column6: title=Capitalism: The Age of Unmasked Gods and Naked Kings

column2:
relatives = Mehmet Öcalan (brother)
[[Osman Öcalan]] (brother)
Fatma Öcalan (sister)
Ömer Öcalan (nephew)
[[Dilek Öcalan]] (niece)

column16: lang}}; born {{circa}} 1947), also known as '''Apo'''<ref name=\"US State Dept\" /><ref>{{cite encyclopedia
column20: accessdate=25 July 2013}}</ref> (short for both Abdullah and \"uncle\" in Kurdish),<ref>{{cite book
column23: title=Turkey and the War on Terror: 'For Forty Years We Fought Alone'
column29: quote=The most ruthless among them was Abdullah Öcalan, known as Apo (a diminutive for Abdullah; the word also means 'uncle' in Kurdish).}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
column32: title=The Settlement Issue in Turkey and the Kurds: An Analysis of Spatical Policies, Modernity and War
column38: quote=In 1975 the group settled on a name, the Kurdistan Revolutionaries (Kurdistan Devrimcileri), but others knew them as Apocu, followers of Apo, the nickname of Abdullah Öcalan (apo is also Kurdish for uncle).}}</ref> is a [[Kurdish nationalist
column39: Kurdish]] leader, leftist political theoretician, political prisoner and one of the founding members of the militant [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]] (PKK).<ref name=\"USTerrorList2\">{{cite web
column48: title=2001 Report on Foreign Terrorist Organizations
column51: publisher=Bureau of Public Affairs, U.S. State Department

column1: Öcalan was arrested in 1999 by the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)
column2: Turkish National Intelligence Agency (MIT)]] with the support of the [[CIA]] in [[Nairobi]] and taken to Turkey, where he was sentenced to death under Article 125 of the Turkish Penal Code, which concerns the formation of armed organisations.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Abdullah Ocalan: Is the Famed Kurdish Leader a Double Agent Working for Turkish Intelligence against His Own Party, the PKK?
column16: title=Greek Intelligence and the Capture of PKK Leader Abdullah Ocalan in 1999

column1: The sentence was commuted to aggravated life imprisonment when Turkey [[Capital punishment in Turkey
column2: abolished the death penalty]] in support of its bid to be admitted to membership in the [[European Union]]. From 1999 until 2009, he was the sole prisoner<ref>{{cite news
column6: date=24 March 1999}}</ref> on [[İmralı]] island, in the [[Sea of Marmara]].<ref>Marlies Casier, Joost Jongerden, ''Nationalisms and Politics in Turkey: Political Islam, Kemalism and the Kurdish Issue'', Taylor & Francis, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_sG-NVapmrkC&pg=PA146&dq=%C3%96calan+%C4%B0mral%C4%B1&hl=tr&ei=XF3gTLC4AYWSuwO7xsW8Dg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBjgU#v=onepage&q=%C3%96calan%20%C4%B0mral%C4%B1&f=false p. 146.]</ref><ref>Council of Europe, ''Parliamentary Assembly Documents 1999 Ordinary Session (fourth part, September 1999), Volume VII'', Council of Europe, 1999, [https://books.google.com/books?id=EkgXi4vNFjAC&pg=PA18&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 18]</ref> Öcalan now argues that the period of armed warfare is past and a political solution to the Kurdish question should be developed.<ref name=\"MKK\">Mag. Katharina Kirchmayer, ''The Case of the Isolation Regime of Abdullah Öcalan: A Violation of European Human Rights Law and Standards?'', GRIN Verlag, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=E8ACMAY1rRgC&pg=PA37&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 37]</ref> The conflict between Turkey and the PKK has resulted in over 40,000 deaths, including PKK members, the [[Turkish Armed Forces
column7: Turkish military]], and civilians, both [[Kurdish people

column1: From prison, Öcalan has published several books. [[Jineology]], also known as the science of women, is a form of [[feminism]] advocated by Öcalan<ref name=\"reuters-argentieri\">{{cite news
column8: title = One group battling Islamic State has a secret weapon – female fighters}}</ref> and subsequently a fundamental tenet of the [[Kurdistan Communities Union]].<ref name=\"opendemocracy\">{{cite web
column19: title = A Kurdish response to climate change}}</ref>

column1: Öcalan was born in Ömerli,<ref name=\"BIRTH\">{{dead link
column3: bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> a village in [[Halfeti]], [[Şanlıurfa Province]] in eastern [[Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: website=Partiya Karkerên Kurdistan / Kurdistan Workers Party
column11: df=dmy-all}}</ref> While some sources report his birthday as being 4 April 1948, no official birth records for him exist, and he himself claims not to know exactly when he was born, estimating the year to be 1946 or 1947.<ref>{{cite web
column21: df=dmy-all}}</ref> He is the oldest of seven children.<ref>Aliza Marcus, ''Blood and Belief,'' New York University Press, 2007. (p.16)</ref> According to some sources, Öcalan's grandmother was an ethnic [[Turkish people
column22: Turk]] and (he once claimed that) his mother was also an ethnic Turk.<ref>Blood and Belief: The Pkk and the Kurdish Fight for Independence, by Aliza Marcus, p.15, 2007</ref><ref>Perceptions: journal of international affairs – Volume 4, no.1, SAM (Center), 1999, p.142</ref> According to Amikam Nachmani, lecturer at the [[Bar-Ilan University]] in Israel, Öcalan did not know [[Kurdish language
column23: Kurdish]] when he met him in 1991. Nachmani: \"''He [Öcalan] told me that he speaks Turkish, gives orders in Turkish, and thinks in Turkish.\"<ref>Turkey: Facing a New Millennium: Coping With Intertwined Conflicts, Amikam Nachmani, p.210, 2003</ref>

column2: Osman]] became a PKK commander until he defected from the PKK with several others to establish the Patriotic and Democratic Party of Kurdistan.<ref name=\"CK\">{{cite journal
column13: df=dmy-all }}</ref> His other brother, Mehmet Öcalan, is a member of the pro-Kurdish [[Peace and Democracy Party]] (BDP).<ref>[https://archive.today/20120701122531/http://archive.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=bdp-wants-autonomy-for-kurds-in-new-constitution-2011-09-04 \"BDP wants autonomy for Kurds in new Constitution\"], ''[[Hürriyet Daily News]]'', 4 September 2011</ref> Fatma Öcalan is the sister of Abdullah Öcalan<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=Travel ban for the sister and brother of Öcalan
column18: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> and [[Dilek Öcalan]], a former parliamentarian of the [[Peoples' Democratic Party (Turkey)
column21: title=HDP MP Dilek Öcalan Sentenced to 2 Years, 6 Months in Prison
column26: access-date=}}</ref> Ömer Öcalan, a current member of parliament for the HDP is his nephew.<ref>{{Cite web
column28: title=HDP Urfa candidate, Öcalan: We are a house for all peoples
column33: title=Different identities enter Parliament with the HDP

column1: == Education and early political and revolutionary activity ==
After graduating from a vocational high school in Ankara ({{lang-tr
column2: Ankara Tapu-Kadastro Meslek Lisesi}}), Öcalan started working at the Diyarbakir Title Deeds Office. He was relocated one month later to [[Bakırköy]], Istanbul. In Istanbul he participated in the reunions of the [[Revolutionary Cultural Eastern Hearths]] (DDKO) <ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=Disengaging from Terrorism - Lessons from the Turkish Penitents
column11: Istanbul Law Faculty]] but transferred after the first year to [[Ankara University]] to study political science.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=Too many questions, but not enough answers
column23: archive-date=13 February 2009 }}</ref> His return to Ankara (normally impossible given his situation<ref group=notes>Normally, students can only transfer between like departments, otherwise the student must retake the university entrance exam. Moreover, Öcalan was awarded a scholarship by the Ministry of Finance, despite being ineligible due to his age, and the fact that he had participated in political demonstrations. He had also been tried and acquitted by a [[martial law]] court. The public prosecutor had asked for the harshest possible sentence.</ref>) was facilitated by the state in order to divide a militant group, ''[[Dev-Genç]]'' (Revolutionary Youth Federation of Turkey), of which Öcalan at the time was a member. President [[Süleyman Demirel]] later regretted this decision, since the PKK was to become a much greater threat to the state than Dev-Genç.<ref>{{cite news
column31: quote=Abdullah Öcalan'ın İstanbul'dan Ankara'ya gelmesine keşke izin verilmeseydi. O zamanlar Dev-Genç'i bölmek için böyle bir yol izlendi... Kürt gençlerini Marksistler'in elinden kurtarmak ve Dev-Genç'in bölünmesi hedeflendi. Bunda başarılı olundu olunmasına ama Abdullah Öcalan yağdan kıl çeker gibi kaydı gitti. Keşke Tuzluçayır'da öldürülseydi!
column35: df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 1972 he was detained due to a participation in a protest held against the killing of [[Mahir Çayan]]. For 7 months he was held at Mamak Prison.<ref name=\":02\">{{Cite web
column37: title=Who is who in Turkish politics
column46: access-date=15 November 2019}}</ref> In November 1973 the Ankara Democratic Association of Higher Education, (''Ankara Demokratik Yüksek Öğrenim Demeği,'' ''ADYÖD'') was founded and shortly after he was elected to join its board.<ref>{{Cite journal
column52: title=The Kurdistan Workers Party and a New Left in Turkey: Analysis of the revolutionary movement in Turkey through the PKK's memorial text on Haki Karer
column54: journal=European Journal of Turkish Studies. Social Sciences on Contemporary Turkey
column58: issn=1773-0546}}</ref> In December 1974 ''ADYÖD'' was closed down.<ref>{{Cite journal
column64: title=The Kurdistan Workers Party and a New Left in Turkey: Analysis of the revolutionary movement in Turkey through the PKK's memorial text on Haki Karer
column66: journal=European Journal of Turkish Studies. Social Sciences on Contemporary Turkey

column1: In 1978, in the midst of the right- and left-wing conflicts which culminated in the [[1980 Turkish coup d'état]], Öcalan founded the [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]] (PKK), which launched a war against the Turkish government in order to set up an independent Kurdish state.<ref name=\"BIRTH\" /><ref name=\"cnn-apology\">{{cite news
column5: title=Kurdish leader Ocalan apologizes during trial
column9: url-status=dead }}</ref> In July 1979 he fled to Syria, where he remained until October 1998, when the Syrian government expelled him.<ref>{{cite book
column11: title=Turkey and the War on Terror: For Forty Years We Fought Alone (Contemporary Security Studies)

column1: In 1984, the PKK initiated a campaign of armed conflict by attacking government forces<ref name=MFA>[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Turkey)
column2: Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], [http://www.fas.org/irp/world/para/docs/mfa-t-pkk-s.htm The Workers' Party of Kurdistan (PKK)], [[Federation of American Scientists]]</ref><ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/news/1998/11/20/letter-italian-prime-minister-massimo-dalema Letter to Italian Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema], [[Human Rights Watch]], 21 November 1998</ref><ref name=SECURITY>[https://www.amnesty.org/ailib/intcam/turkey/turktoc.htm Turkey: No security without human rights] {{webarchive
column4: date=5 August 2010 }} Amnesty International, October 1996</ref><ref name=REPORT>[http://pdm.medicine.wisc.edu/18-2pdfs/new152RodopluTurkey.pdf Special Report: Terrorism in Turkey] {{webarchive
column6: date=28 May 2008 }} Ulkumen Rodophu, Jeffrey Arnold and Gurkan Ersoy, 6 February 2004</ref> in [[Turkey]] as well as civilians<ref>[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=turkey-kurds--0920-08-2011-09-21] {{Webarchive
column8: date=16 July 2016 }}, Four civilians die in PKK attack in SE Turkey</ref><ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Pro-PKK protesters attack civilians, Turkey captures senior PKK member
column17: title=Batman baby dies after PKK attack, civilian death toll rises to three
column22: df=dmy }}</ref> in order to create an independent Kurdish state. As a result, the United States, [[European Union]], [[Syria]], Australia, [[Turkey]], and [[List of states listing the Kurdistan Workers Party as a terrorist group
column23: many other countries]] have included the PKK on their lists of terrorist organizations.<ref name=FTO>[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/ct/rls/other/des/123085.htm Foreign Terrorist Organizations] [[U.S. Department of State]], 28 September 2012</ref><ref name=\"TERROR\">{{cite web
column25: title=MFA – A Report on the PKK and Terrorism

column4: PKK]] leader Öcalan allegedly used this Cypriot passport to enter Kenya where he was taken in and protected by the Greek embassy.]]

column1: Until 1998, Öcalan was based in Syria. On at least one occasion, in 1993, he was detained and held by Syria's [[General Intelligence Directorate (Syria)
column2: General Intelligence Directorate]] but later released.<ref>{{cite news
column4: trans-title={{!(}}https://hdl.handle.net/2027/uiug.30112106671198?urlappend=%3Bseq=214 PKK Leader Abdullah Ocalan Arrested in Syria{{)!}}
column11: publisher=translated by [[Foreign Broadcast Information Service]]}}</ref> As the situation deteriorated in Turkey, the Turkish government openly threatened Syria over its support for the PKK.<ref>{{cite journal
column14: title=The PKK problem: Explaining Turkey's failure to develop a political solution
column25: fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> As a result, the Syrian government forced Öcalan to leave the country but did not turn him over to the Turkish authorities. Öcalan went to Russia first and from there moved to various countries, including Italy and [[Greece]]. In 1998 the Turkish government requested the extradition of Öcalan from Italy.<ref>Italian diplomacy tries to free herself from the tangle in which it is located, between Turks and Kurds, \" internationalizing \" the crisis:{{cite journal
column28: title=Ocalan: la suggestiva strategia turca per legittimare la pena capitale
column36: via=[[Questia]]}}</ref> He was at that time defended by [[Britta Böhler]], a high-profile German attorney who argued that the crimes he was accused of would have to be proven in court.<ref>{{Cite news
column39: title=Von der RAF-Sympathisantin zur Anwältin Öcalans

column1: He was captured in [[Kenya]] on 15 February 1999, while being transferred from the Greek embassy to [[Jomo Kenyatta International Airport]] in [[Nairobi]], in an operation by the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)
column2: Millî İstihbarat Teşkilâtı (Turkish National Intelligence Organization)]] reportedly with the help of the [[CIA]].<ref name=\"nytimes-capture\">{{cite news
column4: title=U.S. Helped Turkey Find and Capture Kurd Rebel
column8: accessdate=15 December 2007}}</ref> George Costoulas, the Greek consul who protected him, said that his own life was in danger after the operation.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Türkiye Öcalan için Kenya'ya para verdi

column1: Speaking to [[Can Dündar]] on [[NTV Turkey]], the Deputy Undersecretary of the Turkish [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)
column2: National Intelligence Organization]], Cevat Öneş, said that Öcalan impeded American aspirations of establishing a separate Kurdish state. The Americans transferred him to the Turkish authorities, who flew him back to Turkey for trial.<ref>{{cite news
column8: quote=Öcalan yakalandığında ABD, bağımsız bir devlet kurma isteğindeydi. Öcalan, konumu itibariyle, araç olma işlevi bakımından buna engel bir isimdi. ABD bölgede yeni bir Kürt devleti kurabilmek için Öcalan'ı Türkiye'ye teslim etti.
column13: df=dmy-all}}</ref> His capture led thousands of Kurds to hold [[February 1999 Kurdish protests
column14: world wide protests]] condemning the capture of Öcalan at Greek and Israeli embassies. Kurds living in Germany were threatened with deportation if they continued to hold demonstrations in support of Öcalan. The warning came after three Kurds were killed and 16 injured during the [[1999 attack on Israeli Consulate in Berlin
column15: 1999 attack]] on the Israeli [[List of diplomatic missions of Israel
column16: consulate]] in Berlin.<ref name=PROTESTS>[http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9902/17/ocalan.protest.01/ \"Kurds seize embassies, wage violent protests across Europe\"], CNN.com, 17 February 1999</ref><ref name=PROTESTS-ATHENS>[[Yannis Kontos]], [http://www.akakurdistan.com/kurds/stories/kontos/ \"Kurd Akar Sehard Azir, 33, sets himself on fire during a demonstration outside the Greek Parliament in Central Athens, Greece, on Monday, 15 February 1999\"], ''Photostory'', July 1999</ref>

column1: A state security court consisting of three military judges was convened on the island to try him. Öcalan was charged with treason and separatism and sentenced to death on 29 June 1999.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=The Argus-Press – Google News Archive Search
column4: accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref> He was also banned from holding public office for life.<ref name=\"bbcnews-verdict\">{{cite news
column9: accessdate=11 January 2008}}</ref> In 1999 the Turkish Parliament discussed a Repentance Bill which would commute Öcalans death sentence to a 20 year imprisonment and allow PKK militants to surrender with a limited amnesty, but it didn't pass due to resistance from the far-right around the [[Nationalist Movement Party]] (MHP).<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Bill to spare life of Ocalan withdrawn by Ecevit
column14: access-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> In January 2000 the Turkish government declared the death sentence was delayed until European Court of Human Rights EU reviewed the verdict.<ref name=\"cnn-excecutiondelay\">{{cite news
column18: title=Turkey delays execution of Kurdish rebel leader Ocalan
column21: accessdate=11 January 2008}}</ref> Upon the abolition of the death penalty in Turkey in August 2002,<ref>{{Cite web
column28: access-date=}}</ref> in October of that year, the security court commuted his sentence to [[life imprisonment]].<ref>{{Cite book
column36: language=en}}</ref> The [[Kurdish Human Rights Project]] (KHRP) may have aided this case's decision.<ref name=\"KHRP\">{{cite web
column37: title=Future of justice, equality and the rule of law

column1: In 2005, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] ruled that Turkey had violated articles 3, 5, and 6 of the European Convention of Human Rights by refusing to allow Öcalan to appeal his arrest and by sentencing him to death without a fair trial.<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=23 January 2015}}</ref> Öcalan's request for a retrial was refused by Turkish courts.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=There will absolutely be no retrial for Abdullah Öcalan

column1: After his capture, Öcalan was held in solitary confinement as the only prisoner on [[İmralı]] island in the [[Sea of Marmara]]. Following the commutation of the death sentence to a life sentence in 2002,<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Kurd's Death Sentence Commuted to Life Term
column7: access-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> Öcalan remained imprisoned on İmralı, and was the sole inmate there. Although former prisoners at [[İmralı]] were transferred to other prisons, more than 1,000 Turkish military personnel were stationed on the island to guard him. In Novemberİ 2009, Turkish authorities announced that other prisoners would be transferred to the İmralı island and that they were ending his solitary confinement by transferring several other prisoners to İmralı.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=PKK leader Ocalan gets company in prison
column12: access-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> They said that Öcalan would be allowed to see them for ten hours a week. The new prison was built after the Council of Europe's [[Committee for the Prevention of Torture]] visited the island and objected to the conditions in which he was being held.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=Company at last for Kurdish inmate alone for ten years
column25: title=Turkey building new prison for PKK members
column32: url-status=live}}</ref>From 27 July 2011 until the 2 May 2019 his lawyers have not been allowed to see Abdullah Öcalan.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column37: access-date=2019-05-17}}</ref> From July 2011 until December 2017 his lawyers filed more than 700 appeals for visits, but all were rejected.<ref>{{Cite news
column39: title=Lawyers' appeal to visit Öcalan rejected for the 710th time
column42: language=en}}</ref> There are regular demonstrations held by the Kurdish community to raise awareness of the isolation of Öcalan.<ref>{{cite web
column48: accessdate=27 December 2018}}</ref> In October 2012 several hundred Kurdish political prisoners went on hunger strike for better detention conditions for Öcalan and the right to use the Kurdish language in education and jurisprudence. The hunger strike lasted 68 days until Öcalan demanded its end.<ref>{{cite book
column56: page=88}}</ref> Öcalan was banned from receiving visits almost two years from 6 October 2014 until 11 September 2016, when his brother Mehmet Öcalan visited him for [[Eid al-Adha]].<ref>{{Cite news
column58: title=Inhaftierter PKK-Chef: Erstmals seit zwei Jahren Familienbesuch für Öcalan
column61: access-date=2019-01-14}}</ref> On 6 September 2018 visits from lawyers were banned for six months due to former punishments he received in the years 2005-2009, the fact that the lawyers made their conversations with Ocalan public, and the impression that Öcalan was leading the PKK through communications with his lawyers.<ref name=\":3\" /> He was again banned from receiving visits until 12 January 2019 when his brother was permitted to visit him a second time. His brother said his health was good.<ref>{{Cite web
column63: title=PKK's Ocalan visited by family in Turkish prison, first time in years
column67: access-date=2019-01-14}}</ref> The ban on the visitation of his lawyers was lifted in April 2019, and Öcalan saw his lawyers on 2 May 2019.<ref name=\":3\" />

column1: === Legal prosecution of sympathizers of Abdullah Öcalan ===

In 2008, the Justice Minister of Turkey, Mehmet Ali Sahin, said that between 2006 and 2007, 949 people were convicted and more than 7,000 people prosecuted for calling Öcalan \"esteemed\" (''Sayın'').<ref>{{Cite book
column3: title=The Kurdish Question in Turkey: New Perspectives on Violence, Representation, and Reconciliation

column1: In 1993, upon request of Turkish president Turgut Özal, Öcalan Jalal Talabani for negotiations following which Öcalan declared a unilateral cease fire which had a duration from 20 March to the 15 April.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite book
column3: title=Nahost Jahrbuch 1993: Politik, Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft in Nordafrika und dem Nahen und Mittleren Osten
column14: title=Primitive Rebels Or Revolutionary Modernizers?: The Kurdish National Movement in Turkey
column23: oclc=1048960654}}</ref> Later he prolonged it in order to enable negotiations. Soon after Özal died on 17 April 1993,<ref>{{Cite web
column29: access-date=2019-07-22}}</ref> the initiative was halted by Turkey on the grounds that Turkey did not negotiate with terrorists.<ref name=\":4\" /> After his capture, Öcalan called for a halt in PKK attacks, and he has advocated a peaceful solution to the Kurdish conflict inside the borders of Turkey.<ref name=PEACEFUL>[http://www.freedom-for-ocalan.com/english/download/REPORT%20AND%20RECOMMENDATIONS%20ON%20THE%20KURDISH%20QUESTION%20IN%20TURKEY,%20%20BY%20THE%20INTERNATIONAL%20%20DELEGATION%20OF%20HUMAN%20RIGHTS%20LAWYERS_%20JANUARY%202005.pdf REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS ON THE KURDISH QUESTION IN TURKEY] by the international delegation of human rights lawyers, January 1997</ref><ref name=DIPLOMACY>[http://www.etext.org/Politics/Arm.The.Spirit/Kurdistan/PKK.ERNK.ARGK/ocalan-interview-january-1999.txt Interview with Abdullah Ocalan \"Our First Priority Is Diplomacy\"] {{webarchive
column31: date=8 December 2008 }} ''Middle East Insight'' magazine, January 1999</ref><ref name=MYTH>[http://chris-kutschera.com/A/Ocalan%20myth.htm Kurdistan Turkey: Abdullah Ocalan, The End of a Myth?] ''The Middle East'' magazine, February 2000</ref><ref name=PLAN>[http://www.xs4all.nl/~kicadam/pers/oud/propose.html Abdullah Öcalan proposes 7-point peace plan] {{webarchive
column33: date=6 December 2008 }} Kurdistan Informatie Centrum Nederland</ref><ref name=TEK>van Bruinessen, Martin. [https://web.archive.org/web/20090225152612/http://www.let.uu.nl/~martin.vanbruinessen/personal/publications/Kurds_after_capture_Ocalan.pdf Turkey, Europe and the Kurds after the capture of Abdullah Öcalan] 1999</ref> Öcalan called for the foundation of a \"Truth and Justice Commission\" by Kurdish institutions in order to investigate [[war crime]]s committed by both the PKK and Turkish security forces. A similar structure began functioning in May 2006.<ref name=CONFEDERALISM>[http://www.kurdistan-post.org/News-file-article-sid-10965.html Öldürülen imam ve 10 korucunun itibarı iade edildi] {{Webarchive
column35: date=8 February 2009 }}, ''ANF News Agency'', 30 May 2006.</ref> In March 2005, Öcalan issued the ''Declaration of Democratic confederalism in Kurdistan''<ref name=KONFEDERALIZM>{{cite news

column4: url-status= live}}</ref> calling for a border-free confederation between the Kurdish regions of Southeastern Turkey (called \"[[Turkish Kurdistan
column5: Northern Kurdistan]]\" by Kurds<ref name=KL>[http://www.kurdishlibrary.org/Kurdish_Library/SvenskaKB/Organisations_SWE/PKK95_Program_Tur.html PKK Program (1995)] Kurdish Library, 24 January 1995</ref>), Northeast Syria (\"[[Rojava
column7: South Kurdistan]]\"), and Northwestern Iran (\"[[Iranian Kurdistan
column8: East Kurdistan]]\"). In this zone, three bodies of law would be implemented: EU law, Turkish/Syrian/Iraqi/Iranian law and Kurdish law. This proposal was adopted by the PKK programme following the \"Refoundation Congress\" in April 2005.<ref name=REFOUNDATION>[http://www.pkk-info.com/tr/eskisite/pkktarihi/PKK.ilk.bildirgesi.html PKK Yeniden İnşa Bildirgesi] {{webarchive
column10: date=6 February 2009 }} PKK web site, 20 April 2005</ref>

column1: Öcalan had his lawyer, Ibrahim Bilmez,<ref name=LAWYER>[http://www.syracuse.com/newsflash/international/index.ssf?/base/international-34/1159461581252960.xml&storylist=International Kurdish leader calls for cease-fire] {{webarchive
column3: date=24 March 2007 }} NewsFlash</ref> release a statement on 28 September 2006 calling on the PKK to declare a ceasefire and seek peace with Turkey. Öcalan's statement said, \"The PKK should not use weapons unless it is attacked with the aim of annihilation,\" and \"it is very important to build a democratic union between Turks and Kurds. With this process, the way to democratic dialogue will be also opened\".<ref name=CEASE>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5389746.stm Kurdish rebel boss in truce plea], ''[[BBC News]]''</ref>

column1: On 31 May 2010, however, Öcalan said he was abandoning the ongoing dialogue with Turkey, as \"this process is no longer meaningful or useful\". Öcalan stated that Turkey had ignored his three protocols for negotiation: (a) his terms of health and security, (b) his release, and (c) a peaceful resolution to the Kurdish issue in Turkey. Though the Turkish government had received Öcalan's protocols, they were never released to the public. Öcalan said he would leave the top PKK commanders in charge of the conflict, but that this should not be misinterpreted as a call for the PKK to intensify its armed conflict with Turkey.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=TURKEY – PKK steps up attacks in Turkey
column6: title=Hürriyet - Haberler, Son Dakika Haberleri ve Güncel Haber

column1: In 2013, Öcalan initiated new peace negotiations. On 21 March of  that year, Öcalan declared a ceasefire between the PKK and the Turkish state. Öcalan's statement was read to hundreds of thousands of Kurds in Diyarbakir who had gathered to celebrate the Kurdish New Year, [[Newroz as celebrated by Kurds
column2: Newroz]]. The statement said in part, \"Let guns be silenced and politics dominate... a new door is being opened from the process of armed conflict to democratization and democratic politics. It's not the end. It's the start of a new era.\"<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Inhaftierter Kurden-Chef stößt Tür zum Frieden auf
column8: language=de}}</ref> Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
column9: Recep Tayyip Erdogan]] welcomed the statement, and hope for a peaceful settlement was raised on both sides.

column1: Soon after Öcalan's declaration, the functional head of the PKK, [[Murat Karayılan]] responded by promising to implement a ceasefire, stating, \"Everyone should know the PKK is as ready for peace as it is for war\".

Since his incarceration, Öcalan has significantly changed his ideology through exposure to Western [[social theorist]]s such as [[Murray Bookchin]], [[Immanuel Wallerstein]], [[Fernand Braudel]], and [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] (who Öcalan calls \"a prophet\").<ref name=\"BOOKS\">{{cite web
column8: date=16 March 2012 }} PWD-Kurdistan, 16 March 2005</ref> Drawing heavily on Bookchin's [[libertarian socialist]] idea of [[Communalism (political philosophy)
column11: title=Bookchin, Öcalan, and the Dialectics of Democracy
column16: accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref> Öcalan fashioned his ideal society called \"democratic confederalism\".

column1: '''Democratic confederalism''' is a \"system of popularly elected administrative councils, allowing local communities to exercise autonomous control over their assets, while linking to other communities via a network of confederal councils.\"<ref name=\":0\">Paul White, \"Democratic Confederalism and the PKK's Feminist Transformation,\" in ''The PKK: Coming Down from the Mountains'' (London: Zed Books, 2015), pp. 126–149.</ref> Decisions are made by communes in each neighborhood, village, or city. All are welcome to partake in the communal councils, but political participation is not mandated. There is no private property, but rather “ownership by use, which grants individuals usage rights to the buildings, land, and infrastructure, but not the right to sell and buy on the market or convert them to private enterprises.”<ref name=\":0\" /> The economy is in the hands of the communal councils, and is thus (in the words of Bookchin) ‘neither collectivised nor privatised - it is common.’<ref name=\":0\" /> [[Feminism]], [[ecology]], and [[direct democracy]] are essential in democratic confederalism.<ref>{{Cite book

With his 2005 \"Declaration of Democratic Confederalism in Kurdistan\", Öcalan advocated for a Kurdish implementation of Bookchin's ''[[The Ecology of Freedom]]'' via municipal assemblies as a democratic confederation of Kurdish communities beyond the state borders of Syria, Iran, Iraq, and Turkey. Öcalan promoted a platform of shared values: environmentalism, self-defense, gender equality, and a pluralistic tolerance for religion, politics, and culture. While some of his followers questioned Öcalan's conversion from [[Marxism-Leninism]], the PKK adopted Öcalan's proposal and began to form assemblies.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=A Dream of Secular Utopia in ISIS' Backyard

column1: In early 2004, Öcalan attempted to arrange a meeting with [[Murray Bookchin]] through Öcalan's lawyers, describing himself as Bookchin's \"student\" eager to adapt Bookchin's thought to Middle Eastern society. Bookchin was too ill to meet with Öcalan. In May 2004 Bookchin conveyed this message \"My hope is that the Kurdish people will one day be able to establish a free, rational society that will allow their brilliance once again to flourish. They are fortunate indeed to have a leader of Mr. Öcalan's talents to guide them\". When Bookchin died in 2006, the PKK hailed the American thinker as \"one of the greatest social scientists of the 20th century\" and vowed to put his theories into practice.<ref name=\"biehl dialectics\" />
Followers of Öcalan and members of the PKK are known by his [[diminutive]] name as ''Apocu'' (Apo-ites), and his movement is known as ''Apoculuk'' (Apoism).<ref name=\"Mango2005\">{{cite book
column3: title=Turkey and the War on Terror: For Forty Years We Fought Alone

column1: Öcalan was arrested in 1999 by the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)
column2: Turkish National Intelligence Agency (MIT)]] with the support of the [[CIA]] in [[Nairobi]] and taken to Turkey, where he was sentenced to death under Article 125 of the Turkish Penal Code, which concerns the formation of armed organisations.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Abdullah Ocalan: Is the Famed Kurdish Leader a Double Agent Working for Turkish Intelligence against His Own Party, the PKK?
column16: title=Greek Intelligence and the Capture of PKK Leader Abdullah Ocalan in 1999

column1: The sentence was commuted to aggravated life imprisonment when Turkey [[Capital punishment in Turkey
column2: abolished the death penalty]] in support of its bid to be admitted to membership in the [[European Union]]. From 1999 until 2009, he was the sole prisoner<ref>{{cite news
column6: date=24 March 1999}}</ref> on [[İmralı]] island, in the [[Sea of Marmara]].<ref>Marlies Casier, Joost Jongerden, ''Nationalisms and Politics in Turkey: Political Islam, Kemalism and the Kurdish Issue'', Taylor & Francis, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_sG-NVapmrkC&pg=PA146&dq=%C3%96calan+%C4%B0mral%C4%B1&hl=tr&ei=XF3gTLC4AYWSuwO7xsW8Dg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBjgU#v=onepage&q=%C3%96calan%20%C4%B0mral%C4%B1&f=false p. 146.]</ref><ref>Council of Europe, ''Parliamentary Assembly Documents 1999 Ordinary Session (fourth part, September 1999), Volume VII'', Council of Europe, 1999, [https://books.google.com/books?id=EkgXi4vNFjAC&pg=PA18&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 18]</ref> Öcalan now argues that the period of armed warfare is past and a political solution to the Kurdish question should be developed.<ref name=\"MKK\">Mag. Katharina Kirchmayer, ''The Case of the Isolation Regime of Abdullah Öcalan: A Violation of European Human Rights Law and Standards?'', GRIN Verlag, 2010, [https://books.google.com/books?id=E8ACMAY1rRgC&pg=PA37&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 37]</ref> The conflict between Turkey and the PKK has resulted in over 40,000 deaths, including PKK members, the [[Turkish Armed Forces
column7: Turkish military]], and civilians, both [[Kurdish people

column1: From prison, Öcalan has published several books. [[Jineology]], also known as the science of women, is a form of [[feminism]] advocated by Öcalan<ref name=\"reuters-argentieri\">{{cite news
column8: title = One group battling Islamic State has a secret weapon – female fighters}}</ref> and subsequently a fundamental tenet of the [[Kurdistan Communities Union]].<ref name=\"opendemocracy\">{{cite web
column19: title = A Kurdish response to climate change}}</ref>

column1: Öcalan was born in Ömerli,<ref name=\"BIRTH\">{{dead link
column3: bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> a village in [[Halfeti]], [[Şanlıurfa Province]] in eastern [[Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: website=Partiya Karkerên Kurdistan / Kurdistan Workers Party
column11: df=dmy-all}}</ref> While some sources report his birthday as being 4 April 1948, no official birth records for him exist, and he himself claims not to know exactly when he was born, estimating the year to be 1946 or 1947.<ref>{{cite web
column21: df=dmy-all}}</ref> He is the oldest of seven children.<ref>Aliza Marcus, ''Blood and Belief,'' New York University Press, 2007. (p.16)</ref> According to some sources, Öcalan's grandmother was an ethnic [[Turkish people
column22: Turk]] and (he once claimed that) his mother was also an ethnic Turk.<ref>Blood and Belief: The Pkk and the Kurdish Fight for Independence, by Aliza Marcus, p.15, 2007</ref><ref>Perceptions: journal of international affairs – Volume 4, no.1, SAM (Center), 1999, p.142</ref> According to Amikam Nachmani, lecturer at the [[Bar-Ilan University]] in Israel, Öcalan did not know [[Kurdish language
column23: Kurdish]] when he met him in 1991. Nachmani: \"''He [Öcalan] told me that he speaks Turkish, gives orders in Turkish, and thinks in Turkish.\"<ref>Turkey: Facing a New Millennium: Coping With Intertwined Conflicts, Amikam Nachmani, p.210, 2003</ref>

column2: Osman]] became a PKK commander until he defected from the PKK with several others to establish the Patriotic and Democratic Party of Kurdistan.<ref name=\"CK\">{{cite journal
column13: df=dmy-all }}</ref> His other brother, Mehmet Öcalan, is a member of the pro-Kurdish [[Peace and Democracy Party]] (BDP).<ref>[https://archive.today/20120701122531/http://archive.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=bdp-wants-autonomy-for-kurds-in-new-constitution-2011-09-04 \"BDP wants autonomy for Kurds in new Constitution\"], ''[[Hürriyet Daily News]]'', 4 September 2011</ref> Fatma Öcalan is the sister of Abdullah Öcalan<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=Travel ban for the sister and brother of Öcalan
column18: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> and [[Dilek Öcalan]], a former parliamentarian of the [[Peoples' Democratic Party (Turkey)
column21: title=HDP MP Dilek Öcalan Sentenced to 2 Years, 6 Months in Prison
column26: access-date=}}</ref> Ömer Öcalan, a current member of parliament for the HDP is his nephew.<ref>{{Cite web
column28: title=HDP Urfa candidate, Öcalan: We are a house for all peoples
column33: title=Different identities enter Parliament with the HDP

column1: == Education and early political and revolutionary activity ==
After graduating from a vocational high school in Ankara ({{lang-tr
column2: Ankara Tapu-Kadastro Meslek Lisesi}}), Öcalan started working at the Diyarbakir Title Deeds Office. He was relocated one month later to [[Bakırköy]], Istanbul. In Istanbul he participated in the reunions of the [[Revolutionary Cultural Eastern Hearths]] (DDKO) <ref>{{Cite book
column5: title=Disengaging from Terrorism - Lessons from the Turkish Penitents
column11: Istanbul Law Faculty]] but transferred after the first year to [[Ankara University]] to study political science.<ref>{{cite news
column14: title=Too many questions, but not enough answers
column23: archive-date=13 February 2009 }}</ref> His return to Ankara (normally impossible given his situation<ref group=notes>Normally, students can only transfer between like departments, otherwise the student must retake the university entrance exam. Moreover, Öcalan was awarded a scholarship by the Ministry of Finance, despite being ineligible due to his age, and the fact that he had participated in political demonstrations. He had also been tried and acquitted by a [[martial law]] court. The public prosecutor had asked for the harshest possible sentence.</ref>) was facilitated by the state in order to divide a militant group, ''[[Dev-Genç]]'' (Revolutionary Youth Federation of Turkey), of which Öcalan at the time was a member. President [[Süleyman Demirel]] later regretted this decision, since the PKK was to become a much greater threat to the state than Dev-Genç.<ref>{{cite news
column31: quote=Abdullah Öcalan'ın İstanbul'dan Ankara'ya gelmesine keşke izin verilmeseydi. O zamanlar Dev-Genç'i bölmek için böyle bir yol izlendi... Kürt gençlerini Marksistler'in elinden kurtarmak ve Dev-Genç'in bölünmesi hedeflendi. Bunda başarılı olundu olunmasına ama Abdullah Öcalan yağdan kıl çeker gibi kaydı gitti. Keşke Tuzluçayır'da öldürülseydi!
column35: df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 1972 he was detained due to a participation in a protest held against the killing of [[Mahir Çayan]]. For 7 months he was held at Mamak Prison.<ref name=\":02\">{{Cite web
column37: title=Who is who in Turkish politics
column46: access-date=15 November 2019}}</ref> In November 1973 the Ankara Democratic Association of Higher Education, (''Ankara Demokratik Yüksek Öğrenim Demeği,'' ''ADYÖD'') was founded and shortly after he was elected to join its board.<ref>{{Cite journal
column52: title=The Kurdistan Workers Party and a New Left in Turkey: Analysis of the revolutionary movement in Turkey through the PKK's memorial text on Haki Karer
column54: journal=European Journal of Turkish Studies. Social Sciences on Contemporary Turkey
column58: issn=1773-0546}}</ref> In December 1974 ''ADYÖD'' was closed down.<ref>{{Cite journal
column64: title=The Kurdistan Workers Party and a New Left in Turkey: Analysis of the revolutionary movement in Turkey through the PKK's memorial text on Haki Karer
column66: journal=European Journal of Turkish Studies. Social Sciences on Contemporary Turkey

column1: In 1978, in the midst of the right- and left-wing conflicts which culminated in the [[1980 Turkish coup d'état]], Öcalan founded the [[Kurdistan Workers' Party]] (PKK), which launched a war against the Turkish government in order to set up an independent Kurdish state.<ref name=\"BIRTH\" /><ref name=\"cnn-apology\">{{cite news
column5: title=Kurdish leader Ocalan apologizes during trial
column9: url-status=dead }}</ref> In July 1979 he fled to Syria, where he remained until October 1998, when the Syrian government expelled him.<ref>{{cite book
column11: title=Turkey and the War on Terror: For Forty Years We Fought Alone (Contemporary Security Studies)

column1: In 1984, the PKK initiated a campaign of armed conflict by attacking government forces<ref name=MFA>[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Turkey)
column2: Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], [http://www.fas.org/irp/world/para/docs/mfa-t-pkk-s.htm The Workers' Party of Kurdistan (PKK)], [[Federation of American Scientists]]</ref><ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/news/1998/11/20/letter-italian-prime-minister-massimo-dalema Letter to Italian Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema], [[Human Rights Watch]], 21 November 1998</ref><ref name=SECURITY>[https://www.amnesty.org/ailib/intcam/turkey/turktoc.htm Turkey: No security without human rights] {{webarchive
column4: date=5 August 2010 }} Amnesty International, October 1996</ref><ref name=REPORT>[http://pdm.medicine.wisc.edu/18-2pdfs/new152RodopluTurkey.pdf Special Report: Terrorism in Turkey] {{webarchive
column6: date=28 May 2008 }} Ulkumen Rodophu, Jeffrey Arnold and Gurkan Ersoy, 6 February 2004</ref> in [[Turkey]] as well as civilians<ref>[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=turkey-kurds--0920-08-2011-09-21] {{Webarchive
column8: date=16 July 2016 }}, Four civilians die in PKK attack in SE Turkey</ref><ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Pro-PKK protesters attack civilians, Turkey captures senior PKK member
column17: title=Batman baby dies after PKK attack, civilian death toll rises to three
column22: df=dmy }}</ref> in order to create an independent Kurdish state. As a result, the United States, [[European Union]], [[Syria]], Australia, [[Turkey]], and [[List of states listing the Kurdistan Workers Party as a terrorist group
column23: many other countries]] have included the PKK on their lists of terrorist organizations.<ref name=FTO>[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/ct/rls/other/des/123085.htm Foreign Terrorist Organizations] [[U.S. Department of State]], 28 September 2012</ref><ref name=\"TERROR\">{{cite web
column25: title=MFA – A Report on the PKK and Terrorism

column4: PKK]] leader Öcalan allegedly used this Cypriot passport to enter Kenya where he was taken in and protected by the Greek embassy.]]

column1: Until 1998, Öcalan was based in Syria. On at least one occasion, in 1993, he was detained and held by Syria's [[General Intelligence Directorate (Syria)
column2: General Intelligence Directorate]] but later released.<ref>{{cite news
column4: trans-title={{!(}}https://hdl.handle.net/2027/uiug.30112106671198?urlappend=%3Bseq=214 PKK Leader Abdullah Ocalan Arrested in Syria{{)!}}
column11: publisher=translated by [[Foreign Broadcast Information Service]]}}</ref> As the situation deteriorated in Turkey, the Turkish government openly threatened Syria over its support for the PKK.<ref>{{cite journal
column14: title=The PKK problem: Explaining Turkey's failure to develop a political solution
column25: fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> As a result, the Syrian government forced Öcalan to leave the country but did not turn him over to the Turkish authorities. Öcalan went to Russia first and from there moved to various countries, including Italy and [[Greece]]. In 1998 the Turkish government requested the extradition of Öcalan from Italy.<ref>Italian diplomacy tries to free herself from the tangle in which it is located, between Turks and Kurds, \" internationalizing \" the crisis:{{cite journal
column28: title=Ocalan: la suggestiva strategia turca per legittimare la pena capitale
column36: via=[[Questia]]}}</ref> He was at that time defended by [[Britta Böhler]], a high-profile German attorney who argued that the crimes he was accused of would have the be proven in court.<ref>{{Cite news
column39: title=Von der RAF-Sympathisantin zur Anwältin Öcalans

column1: He was captured in [[Kenya]] on 15 February 1999, while being transferred from the Greek embassy to [[Jomo Kenyatta International Airport]] in [[Nairobi]], in an operation by the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)
column2: Millî İstihbarat Teşkilâtı (Turkish National Intelligence Organization)]] reportedly with the help of the [[CIA]].<ref name=\"nytimes-capture\">{{cite news
column4: title=U.S. Helped Turkey Find and Capture Kurd Rebel
column8: accessdate=15 December 2007}}</ref> George Costoulas, the Greek consul who protected him, said that his own life was in danger after the operation.<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Türkiye Öcalan için Kenya'ya para verdi

column1: Speaking to [[Can Dündar]] on [[NTV Turkey]], the Deputy Undersecretary of the Turkish [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)
column2: National Intelligence Organization]], Cevat Öneş, said that Öcalan impeded American aspirations of establishing a separate Kurdish state. The Americans transferred him to the Turkish authorities, who flew him back to Turkey for trial.<ref>{{cite news
column8: quote=Öcalan yakalandığında ABD, bağımsız bir devlet kurma isteğindeydi. Öcalan, konumu itibariyle, araç olma işlevi bakımından buna engel bir isimdi. ABD bölgede yeni bir Kürt devleti kurabilmek için Öcalan'ı Türkiye'ye teslim etti.
column13: df=dmy-all}}</ref> His capture led thousands of Kurds to hold [[February 1999 Kurdish protests
column14: world wide protests]] condemning the capture of Öcalan at Greek and Israeli embassies. Kurds living in Germany were threatened with deportation if they continued to hold demonstrations in support of Öcalan. The warning came after three Kurds were killed and 16 injured during the [[1999 attack on Israeli Consulate in Berlin
column15: 1999 attack]] on the Israeli [[List of diplomatic missions of Israel
column16: consulate]] in Berlin.<ref name=PROTESTS>[http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9902/17/ocalan.protest.01/ \"Kurds seize embassies, wage violent protests across Europe\"], CNN.com, 17 February 1999</ref><ref name=PROTESTS-ATHENS>[[Yannis Kontos]], [http://www.akakurdistan.com/kurds/stories/kontos/ \"Kurd Akar Sehard Azir, 33, sets himself on fire during a demonstration outside the Greek Parliament in Central Athens, Greece, on Monday, 15 February 1999\"], ''Photostory'', July 1999</ref>

column1: A state security court consisting of three military judges was convened on the island to try him. Öcalan was charged with treason and separatism and sentenced to death on 29 June 1999.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=The Argus-Press – Google News Archive Search
column4: accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref> He was also banned from holding public office for life.<ref name=\"bbcnews-verdict\">{{cite news
column9: accessdate=11 January 2008}}</ref> In 1999 the Turkish Parliament discussed a Repentance Bill which would commute Öcalans death sentence to a 20 year imprisonment and allow PKK militants to surrender with a limited amnesty, but it didn't pass due to resistance from the far-right around the [[Nationalist Movement Party]] (MHP).<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Bill to spare life of Ocalan withdrawn by Ecevit
column14: access-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> In January 2000 the Turkish government declared the death sentence was delayed until European Court of Human Rights EU reviewed the verdict.<ref name=\"cnn-excecutiondelay\">{{cite news
column18: title=Turkey delays execution of Kurdish rebel leader Ocalan
column21: accessdate=11 January 2008}}</ref> Upon the abolition of the death penalty in Turkey in August 2002,<ref>{{Cite web
column28: access-date=}}</ref> in October of that year, the security court commuted his sentence to [[life imprisonment]].<ref>{{Cite book
column36: language=en}}</ref> The [[Kurdish Human Rights Project]] (KHRP) may have aided this case's decision.<ref name=\"KHRP\">{{cite web
column37: title=Future of justice, equality and the rule of law

column1: In 2005, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] ruled that Turkey had violated articles 3, 5, and 6 of the European Convention of Human Rights by refusing to allow Öcalan to appeal his arrest and by sentencing him to death without a fair trial.<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=23 January 2015}}</ref> Öcalan's request for a retrial was refused by Turkish courts.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=There will absolutely be no retrial for Abdullah Öcalan

column1: After his capture, Öcalan was held in solitary confinement as the only prisoner on [[İmralı]] island in the [[Sea of Marmara]]. Following the commutation of the death sentence to a life sentence in 2002,<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Kurd's Death Sentence Commuted to Life Term
column7: access-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> Öcalan remained imprisoned on İmralı, and was the sole inmate there. Although former prisoners at [[İmralı]] were transferred to other prisons, more than 1,000 Turkish military personnel were stationed on the island to guard him. In Novemberİ 2009, Turkish authorities announced that other prisoners would be transferred to the İmralı island and that they were ending his solitary confinement by transferring several other prisoners to İmralı.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=PKK leader Ocalan gets company in prison
column12: access-date=2020-03-10}}</ref> They said that Öcalan would be allowed to see them for ten hours a week. The new prison was built after the Council of Europe's [[Committee for the Prevention of Torture]] visited the island and objected to the conditions in which he was being held.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=Company at last for Kurdish inmate alone for ten years
column25: title=Turkey building new prison for PKK members
column32: url-status=live}}</ref>From 27 July 2011 until the 2 May 2019 his lawyers have not been allowed to see Abdullah Öcalan.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web
column37: access-date=2019-05-17}}</ref> From July 2011 until December 2017 his lawyers filed more than 700 appeals for visits, but all were rejected.<ref>{{Cite news
column39: title=Lawyers' appeal to visit Öcalan rejected for the 710th time
column42: language=en}}</ref> There are regular demonstrations held by the Kurdish community to raise awareness of the isolation of Öcalan.<ref>{{cite web
column48: accessdate=27 December 2018}}</ref> In October 2012 several hundred Kurdish political prisoners went on hunger strike for better detention conditions for Öcalan and the right to use the Kurdish language in education and jurisprudence. The hunger strike lasted 68 days until Öcalan demanded its end.<ref>{{cite book
column56: page=88}}</ref> Öcalan was banned from receiving visits almost two years from 6 October 2014 until 11 September 2016, when his brother Mehmet Öcalan visited him for [[Eid al-Adha]].<ref>{{Cite news
column58: title=Inhaftierter PKK-Chef: Erstmals seit zwei Jahren Familienbesuch für Öcalan
column61: access-date=2019-01-14}}</ref> On 6 September 2018 visits from lawyers were banned for six months due to former punishments he received in the years 2005-2009, the fact that the lawyers made their conversations with Ocalan public, and the impression that Öcalan was leading the PKK through communications with his lawyers.<ref name=\":3\" /> He was again banned from receiving visits until 12 January 2019 when his brother was permitted to visit him a second time. His brother said his health was good.<ref>{{Cite web
column63: title=PKK's Ocalan visited by family in Turkish prison, first time in years
column67: access-date=2019-01-14}}</ref> The ban on the visitation of his lawyers was lifted in April 2019, and Öcalan saw his lawyers on 2 May 2019.<ref name=\":3\" />

column1: === Legal prosecution of sympathizers of Abdullah Öcalan ===

In 2008, the Justice Minister of Turkey, Mehmet Ali Sahin, said that between 2006 and 2007, 949 people were convicted and more than 7,000 people prosecuted for calling Öcalan \"esteemed\" (''Sayın'').<ref>{{Cite book
column3: title=The Kurdish Question in Turkey: New Perspectives on Violence, Representation, and Reconciliation

column1: In 1993, upon request of Turkish president Turgut Özal, Öcalan Jalal Talabani for negotiations following which Öcalan declared a unilateral cease fire which had a duration from 20 March to the 15 April.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite book
column3: title=Nahost Jahrbuch 1993: Politik, Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft in Nordafrika und dem Nahen und Mittleren Osten
column14: title=Primitive Rebels Or Revolutionary Modernizers?: The Kurdish National Movement in Turkey
column23: oclc=1048960654}}</ref> Later he prolonged it in order to enable negotiations. Soon after Özal died on 17 April 1993,<ref>{{Cite web
column29: access-date=2019-07-22}}</ref> the initiative was halted by Turkey on the grounds that Turkey did not negotiate with terrorists.<ref name=\":4\" /> After his capture, Öcalan called for a halt in PKK attacks, and he has advocated a peaceful solution to the Kurdish conflict inside the borders of Turkey.<ref name=PEACEFUL>[http://www.freedom-for-ocalan.com/english/download/REPORT%20AND%20RECOMMENDATIONS%20ON%20THE%20KURDISH%20QUESTION%20IN%20TURKEY,%20%20BY%20THE%20INTERNATIONAL%20%20DELEGATION%20OF%20HUMAN%20RIGHTS%20LAWYERS_%20JANUARY%202005.pdf REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS ON THE KURDISH QUESTION IN TURKEY] by the international delegation of human rights lawyers, January 1997</ref><ref name=DIPLOMACY>[http://www.etext.org/Politics/Arm.The.Spirit/Kurdistan/PKK.ERNK.ARGK/ocalan-interview-january-1999.txt Interview with Abdullah Ocalan \"Our First Priority Is Diplomacy\"] {{webarchive
column31: date=8 December 2008 }} ''Middle East Insight'' magazine, January 1999</ref><ref name=MYTH>[http://chris-kutschera.com/A/Ocalan%20myth.htm Kurdistan Turkey: Abdullah Ocalan, The End of a Myth?] ''The Middle East'' magazine, February 2000</ref><ref name=PLAN>[http://www.xs4all.nl/~kicadam/pers/oud/propose.html Abdullah Öcalan proposes 7-point peace plan] {{webarchive
column33: date=6 December 2008 }} Kurdistan Informatie Centrum Nederland</ref><ref name=TEK>van Bruinessen, Martin. [https://web.archive.org/web/20090225152612/http://www.let.uu.nl/~martin.vanbruinessen/personal/publications/Kurds_after_capture_Ocalan.pdf Turkey, Europe and the Kurds after the capture of Abdullah Öcalan] 1999</ref> Öcalan called for the foundation of a \"Truth and Justice Commission\" by Kurdish institutions in order to investigate [[war crime]]s committed by both the PKK and Turkish security forces. A similar structure began functioning in May 2006.<ref name=CONFEDERALISM>[http://www.kurdistan-post.org/News-file-article-sid-10965.html Öldürülen imam ve 10 korucunun itibarı iade edildi] {{Webarchive
column35: date=8 February 2009 }}, ''ANF News Agency'', 30 May 2006.</ref> In March 2005, Öcalan issued the ''Declaration of Democratic confederalism in Kurdistan''<ref name=KONFEDERALIZM>{{cite news

column4: url-status= live}}</ref> calling for a border-free confederation between the Kurdish regions of Southeastern Turkey (called \"[[Turkish Kurdistan
column5: Northern Kurdistan]]\" by Kurds<ref name=KL>[http://www.kurdishlibrary.org/Kurdish_Library/SvenskaKB/Organisations_SWE/PKK95_Program_Tur.html PKK Program (1995)] Kurdish Library, 24 January 1995</ref>), Northeast Syria (\"[[Rojava
column7: South Kurdistan]]\"), and Northwestern Iran (\"[[Iranian Kurdistan
column8: East Kurdistan]]\"). In this zone, three bodies of law would be implemented: EU law, Turkish/Syrian/Iraqi/Iranian law and Kurdish law. This proposal was adopted by the PKK programme following the \"Refoundation Congress\" in April 2005.<ref name=REFOUNDATION>[http://www.pkk-info.com/tr/eskisite/pkktarihi/PKK.ilk.bildirgesi.html PKK Yeniden İnşa Bildirgesi] {{webarchive
column10: date=6 February 2009 }} PKK web site, 20 April 2005</ref>

column1: Öcalan had his lawyer, Ibrahim Bilmez,<ref name=LAWYER>[http://www.syracuse.com/newsflash/international/index.ssf?/base/international-34/1159461581252960.xml&storylist=International Kurdish leader calls for cease-fire] {{webarchive
column3: date=24 March 2007 }} NewsFlash</ref> release a statement on 28 September 2006 calling on the PKK to declare a ceasefire and seek peace with Turkey. Öcalan's statement said, \"The PKK should not use weapons unless it is attacked with the aim of annihilation,\" and \"it is very important to build a democratic union between Turks and Kurds. With this process, the way to democratic dialogue will be also opened\".<ref name=CEASE>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5389746.stm Kurdish rebel boss in truce plea], ''[[BBC News]]''</ref>

column1: On 31 May 2010, however, Öcalan said he was abandoning the ongoing dialogue with Turkey, as \"this process is no longer meaningful or useful\". Öcalan stated that Turkey had ignored his three protocols for negotiation: (a) his terms of health and security, (b) his release, and (c) a peaceful resolution to the Kurdish issue in Turkey. Though the Turkish government had received Öcalan's protocols, they were never released to the public. Öcalan said he would leave the top PKK commanders in charge of the conflict, but that this should not be misinterpreted as a call for the PKK to intensify its armed conflict with Turkey.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=TURKEY – PKK steps up attacks in Turkey
column6: title=Hürriyet - Haberler, Son Dakika Haberleri ve Güncel Haber

column1: In 2013, Öcalan initiated new peace negotiations. On 21 March of  that year, Öcalan declared a ceasefire between the PKK and the Turkish state. Öcalan's statement was read to hundreds of thousands of Kurds in Diyarbakir who had gathered to celebrate the Kurdish New Year, [[Newroz as celebrated by Kurds
column2: Newroz]]. The statement said in part, \"Let guns be silenced and politics dominate... a new door is being opened from the process of armed conflict to democratization and democratic politics. It's not the end. It's the start of a new era.\"<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Inhaftierter Kurden-Chef stößt Tür zum Frieden auf
column8: language=de}}</ref> Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
column9: Recep Tayyip Erdogan]] welcomed the statement, and hope for a peaceful settlement was raised on both sides.

column1: Soon after Öcalan's declaration, the functional head of the PKK, [[Murat Karayılan]] responded by promising to implement a ceasefire, stating, \"Everyone should know the PKK is as ready for peace as it is for war\".

Since his incarceration, Öcalan has significantly changed his ideology through exposure to Western [[social theorist]]s such as [[Murray Bookchin]], [[Immanuel Wallerstein]], [[Fernand Braudel]], and [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] (who Öcalan calls \"a prophet\").<ref name=\"BOOKS\">{{cite web
column8: date=16 March 2012 }} PWD-Kurdistan, 16 March 2005</ref> Drawing heavily on Bookchin's [[libertarian socialist]] idea of [[Communalism (political philosophy)
column11: title=Bookchin, Öcalan, and the Dialectics of Democracy
column16: accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref> Öcalan fashioned his ideal society called \"democratic confederalism\".

column1: '''Democratic confederalism''' is a \"system of popularly elected administrative councils, allowing local communities to exercise autonomous control over their assets, while linking to other communities via a network of confederal councils.\"<ref name=\":0\">Paul White, \"Democratic Confederalism and the PKK's Feminist Transformation,\" in ''The PKK: Coming Down from the Mountains'' (London: Zed Books, 2015), pp. 126–149.</ref> Decisions are made by communes in each neighborhood, village, or city. All are welcome to partake in the communal councils, but political participation is not mandated. There is no private property, but rather “ownership by use, which grants individuals usage rights to the buildings, land, and infrastructure, but not the right to sell and buy on the market or convert them to private enterprises.”<ref name=\":0\" /> The economy is in the hands of the communal councils, and is thus (in the words of Bookchin) ‘neither collectivised nor privatised - it is common.’<ref name=\":0\" /> [[Feminism]], [[ecology]], and [[direct democracy]] are essential in democratic confederalism.<ref>{{Cite book

With his 2005 \"Declaration of Democratic Confederalism in Kurdistan\", Öcalan advocated for a Kurdish implementation of Bookchin's ''[[The Ecology of Freedom]]'' via municipal assemblies as a democratic confederation of Kurdish communities beyond the state borders of Syria, Iran, Iraq, and Turkey. Öcalan promoted a platform of shared values: environmentalism, self-defense, gender equality, and a pluralistic tolerance for religion, politics, and culture. While some of his followers questioned Öcalan's conversion from [[Marxism-Leninism]], the PKK adopted Öcalan's proposal and began to form assemblies.<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=A Dream of Secular Utopia in ISIS' Backyard

column1: In early 2004, Öcalan attempted to arrange a meeting with [[Murray Bookchin]] through Öcalan's lawyers, describing himself as Bookchin's \"student\" eager to adapt Bookchin's thought to Middle Eastern society. Bookchin was too ill to meet with Öcalan. In May 2004 Bookchin conveyed this message \"My hope is that the Kurdish people will one day be able to establish a free, rational society that will allow their brilliance once again to flourish. They are fortunate indeed to have a leader of Mr. Öcalan's talents to guide them\". When Bookchin died in 2006, the PKK hailed the American thinker as \"one of the greatest social scientists of the 20th century\" and vowed to put his theories into practice.<ref name=\"biehl dialectics\" />
Followers of Öcalan and members of the PKK are known by his [[diminutive]] name as ''Apocu'' (Apo-ites), and his movement is known as ''Apoculuk'' (Apoism).<ref name=\"Mango2005\">{{cite book
column3: title=Turkey and the War on Terror: For Forty Years We Fought Alone

column1: Several localities have awarded him with an honorary citizenship:{{Div col

column1: Öcalan is the author of more than 40 books, four of which were written in prison. Many of the notes taken from his weekly meetings with his lawyers have been edited and published.

column2: U.S. military]] [[acronym]] for [[Judge Advocate General's Corps
column3: Judge Advocate General]]<ref>Sometimes stylized as '''''J*A*G''''' in promotional materials, including the DVD releases</ref>) is an American [[legal drama]] television series with a U.S. Navy theme, created by [[Donald P. Bellisario]], and produced by Belisarius Productions in association with [[Paramount Pictures
column5: Network Television]] (now [[CBS Television Studios]]).<ref name=\"2000 production notes\">{{cite web
column11: archivedate=December 10, 2000 }}. From the Paramount website, through [[archive.org]]. Retrieved on 2015-03-22.</ref><ref>It was one of the last Paramount-produced TV series to end under that name, prior to the firm becoming [[CBS Paramount Network Television]].</ref> The series was originally aired on [[NBC]] for one season from September 23, 1995, to May 22, 1996, and then on [[CBS]] for an additional nine seasons from January 3, 1997, to April 29, 2005. The first season was co-produced with [[Universal Television
column12: NBC Productions]] (now [[Universal Television]]) and was originally perceived as a ''[[Top Gun]]'' meets ''[[A Few Good Men]]'' hybrid series.<ref name=\"Neal Karlen 1995\">[[Neal Karlen
column13: Karlen, Neal]]. \"[https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/05/tv/cover-story-from-the-man-behind-magnum-pi-top-gun-meets-a-few-good-men.html COVER STORY;From the Man Behind 'Magnum, P.I.,' 'Top Gun' Meets 'A Few Good Men'] {{webarchive

column1: In the spring of 1996, NBC announced that the series had been canceled after finishing 79th in the ratings, leaving one episode unaired. In December 1996, the rival network CBS announced it had picked up the series as a [[mid-season replacement]] and aired 15 new episodes as its second season. For several seasons, ''JAG'' climbed in the ratings and ultimately ran for nine additional seasons. ''JAG'' furthermore spawned the hit series ''[[NCIS (TV series)
column2: NCIS]]'', which in turn led to spin-offs ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'' and ''[[NCIS: New Orleans]]''.

column1: In total, 227 episodes were produced over 10 seasons. At the time of the original airing of its fifth season in the United States, ''JAG'' was seen in over 90 countries worldwide.<ref>{{cite web
column7: archivedate=November 10, 2000 }}. Official Paramount site from January 2000, retrieved through [[archive.org]]. Retrieved on 2013-10-09.</ref> ''JAG'' entered [[Broadcast syndication

column6: source=Donald P. Bellisario on creating ''JAG''<ref name=\"2000pn3\">{{cite web
column12: archivedate=December 10, 2000 }}. From the Paramount website, through [[archive.org]]. Retrieved on 2013-10-09.</ref>
column13: \"Dramatic, action adventure programming has all but disappeared from the airwaves. I don't do [[sitcom]]s; I don't do urban neurotic dramas. I created ''JAG'' because it's the kind of television I like to watch. Besides that, I served four years in the Marine Corps and remain fascinated by the military's code of ethics—God, duty, honor, country—and how, in these rapidly changing times, it still survives. That's what Harm and Mac, and ''JAG'' as a whole, represent.\"}}

column1: The series follows the exploits of the [[Washington metropolitan area]]–based<ref>In the first season, the JAG headquarters was set in [[Washington, DC]], while in later seasons it is located in [[Falls Church, Virginia]]. The real-life OJAG is based at [[the Pentagon]] and the [[Washington Navy Yard]].</ref> \"[[Judge Advocate General's Corps, U.S. Navy
column2: judge]] [[U.S. Marine Corps Judge Advocate Division#Marine Corps judge advocates
column11: 5587a}}</ref>) in the [[United States Department of the Navy
column12: Department of the Navy's]] [[Judge Advocate General of the Navy
column13: Office of the Judge Advocate General]], who in the line of duty can prosecute and defend [[Trial
column14: criminal cases]] under the [[jurisdiction]] of the [[Uniform Code of Military Justice]]<ref>{{UnitedStatesCode
column18: 827}}</ref> (arising from the global presence of the [[U.S. Navy]] and the [[U.S. Marine Corps]]<ref>{{UnitedStatesCode
column20: 805}}</ref>), conduct informal and formal investigations, and advise on [[Laws of war
column23: date=2013-12-27 }}, [[Judge Advocate general of the Navy
column24: Office of the Judge Advocate General]], U.S. Department of the Navy. Retrieved on 2013-09-17.</ref>

column2: Law & Order]]'', the plots from many episodes were often \"[[ripped from the headlines]]\" with portions of the plot either resembling or referencing recognizable aspects of actual cases or incidents, such as the [[USS Cole bombing
column4: Act of Terror]]\" and \"[[List of JAG episodes#ep127
column6: rescue of downed pilot Scott O'Grady]] (\"[[List of JAG episodes#ep13

column12: The Court-Martial of Sandra Gilbert]]\").<ref name=\"2000pn3\"/>

column1: While not part of the mission of its real-world counterpart, some of the main characters are at times also involved, directly and indirectly, in various [[Central Intelligence Agency
column2: CIA]] intelligence operations, often revolving around the recurring character CIA officer [[Clayton Webb]] (played by [[Steven Culp]]).
Harmon Rabb, Jr., USN]], Lieutenant/Lieutenant Commander/Commander, JAG Corps; Acting Judge Advocate General; Carrier Commander; Captain/XO of U.S.S. Allegiance (''NCIS: Los Angeles'').
