column1: * [[Rif Hutton]] as Lt. Commander Alan Mattoni, USN (Seasons 3–6)
* [[Sibel Galindez]] as Lieutenant Elizabeth Hawkes, \"Skates\", USN  (Seasons 2, 4–7)

The creator of ''JAG'', Donald P. Bellisario, served for four years in the [[U.S. Marine Corps]], and after having worked his way up through advertising jobs, he landed his first network television job as a story editor for the World War II-era series ''[[Baa Baa Black Sheep (TV series)
column2: Baa Baa Black Sheep]]'', where he got a habit of promoting a consistent promilitary stance in a business where he got the perception that \"antiwar\" and \"antisoldier\" mentality were the commonplace.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\">[[#Erickson
column3: Erickson]]: p. 127.</ref> The stereotype in the post-[[Vietnam war]] era of \"[[Vietnam Veteran#Negative stereotypes of Vietnam veterans and efforts to overcome
column4: crazed Vietnam veterans]]\" was notably subverted, by not just one, but three of the main characters, in ''[[Magnum P.I.]]'', of which Bellisario was the co-creator.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

column1: Following the cancellation of his series ''[[Quantum Leap]]'', Bellisario began working on a one-shot screenplay of a murder mystery aboard a U.S. Navy aircraft carrier, where the victim was a female aviator.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

The issue of whether or not to expand the options for women serving in the U.S. armed forces as fighter pilots and in other frontline assignments was a contentious social issue of the day. In 1991, a famous incident had occurred at the [[Tailhook Association]] [[Tailhook scandal
column2: convention in Las Vegas]], where male naval aviators had behaved in manners inappropriate, if not criminal.  The follow-up criminal and other investigations by the [[Naval Investigative Service
column3: then-named NIS]], the [[Naval Inspector General]], and the Judge Advocate General of the Navy, were later heavily criticized by the [[Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Defense]].  The  [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column4: Acting Secretary of the Navy]] [[Sean O'Keefe]], to whom the report was delivered, agreed with the findings and began to take corrective action with respect to both the perceived attitude problems towards women and the functions of the investigative arms of the Department of the Navy.<ref>{{cite AV media

column1: The fallout from the incident resulted in a hard blow to the [[Naval aviation
column2: naval aviation community]], where the promotions of many [[naval aviator]]s were put on hold. The common counterclaim from the other side of the aisle, as articulated by former Secretary of the Navy in the [[Reagan administration]] and [[naval flight officer]] [[John F. Lehman]], was that the naval aviation community had been unfairly subjected to a witch-hunt motivated by [[political correctness]], in effect killing its ''esprit de corps'', and by extension damaging its combat effectiveness.<ref name=\"Lehman:372\">[[#Lehman
column3: Lehman]]: p. 372.</ref> During the [[Clinton administration]] in April 1993, [[United States Secretary of Defense
column4: Secretary of Defense]] [[Les Aspin]] announced a new policy, which in effect made it possible to have female fighter pilots serving on aircraft carriers at sea and in other new positions (but still prohibited from serving in [[infantry]], etc.)

column3: title = Women in Combat (Department of Defense briefing)

column1: Thus, the stage was set for the reality-based fictional drama, when Bellisario read in a newspaper about the forthcoming introduction of female fighter pilots on aircraft carriers.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

While doing research on which organizational entities would partake in investigative efforts of crimes committed aboard Naval vessels, Bellisario found  the special agents of the [[Naval Criminal Investigative Service]] filled the police role, and the uniformed lawyers, in the Navy's Judge Advocate General's Corps, could alternate between the role of defense attorney, prosecutor, and field investigator. Bellisario chose to go ahead with the lawyers and remarked season six about the unique advantages it brought from a story-telling point of view: \"Unlike most [[legal drama
column2: law shows]], I've got a detective, a prosecutor, and a defender.\"<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

column1: [[File:RADM Donald Guter, JAGC, USN visited the JAG television series set, 2001-02-20.jpg
column3: The then-[[Judge Advocate General of the Navy]], Rear Admiral Donald J. Guter (second from left), visiting the set, meeting with the cast during the shooting of \"[[JAG (season 6)#ep128

column1: Initially, the producers of ''JAG'' did not receive any co-operation from the Department of the Navy, due to sensitivity in light of all the accumulative negative publicity that had been generated from the [[Tailhook scandal]] and its aftermath.<ref name=\"Erickson:129\">[[#Erickson
column2: Erickson]]: p. 129.</ref> However, the lack of co-operation from the military was not a show-stopper, as the ''JAG'' production team, by virtue of being a [[Paramount Pictures]] production, had access to the [[stock footage]] of the motion pictures owned by the studio, which included many films with military content, such as ''[[Top Gun (film)
column4: The Final Countdown]]'', and ''[[The Hunt for Red October (film)
column5: The Hunt for Red October]].<ref name=\"Erickson:128\">[[#Erickson

column1: In 1997, though, the naval services had begun to change their minds, and began to render support to the production team on a script-by-script basis. A primetime network series about Navy lawyers bringing out controversial subjects in a very public arena was apparently no longer an issue in itself, but as noted by Commander Bob Anderson of the Navy's [[Public affairs (military)
column2: entertainment media liaison office]] in Los Angeles in a ''[[TV Guide]]'' interview: \"We're fine with that as long as the bad guys are caught and punished, and the institution of the Navy is not the bad guy\".<ref name=\"Erickson:129\"/>

column1: Almost all episodes of the series feature scenes filmed aboard real United States Navy ships. The ship most widely used was {{USS
column4: 6}}, in commission as a training carrier at the time. Most of the ''Nimitz''-class carriers also appear in one or several episodes. {{USS
column13: 6}} were also used in the series.

column1: USS ''Enterprise'' was used as the fictional USS ''Seahawk'' in many episodes. USS ''Forrestal'' and {{USS
column4: 6}} were also used as the fictional ''Seahawk'', both in season four and for one episode each. For scenes filmed aboard ''Enterprise'', the whole crew wore caps reading ''USS Seahawk – CVN 65'' so they matched the ship's real hull number.

column1: USS ''Forrestal'' was featured in many episodes, most prominently two in which she portrayed the fictional USS ''Reprisal''.  In these episodes, all crew members wore caps with the ''CV-35'' pennant number.  This number was intentionally out of sequence with the pennant numbers of active USN carriers at the time the series was filmed. CV-35 would have been the real pennant number of an ''Essex''-class carrier actually called ''Reprisal'', which was canceled during construction in 1945 when World War II ended, and broken up in 1949 after consideration had been given to completing her to a revised design roughly similar to that of {{USS
Only six USN ships featured in the series were called by their real names: {{USS
column19: 6}}. ''Kitty Hawk'' is mentioned in one of the season-three episodes, but never seen on screen. ''America'' is the murder scene in a season-three episode, but shots supposedly depicting her are in fact shots of ''Forrestal''. Real shots of ''Theodore Roosevelt'' in harbor are used in one episode of season one.

column1: [[File:US Navy 050125-N-0685S-001 Crewmembers for the hit television show JAG set up for the next shot outside the Transient Aircraft Line on board Naval Air Station North Island, Calif.jpg
column4: Crewmembers set up for a shot at [[Naval Air Station North Island

column1: Season-three opener \"Ghost Ship\" was filmed entirely aboard ''Hornet'' while she was laid up at Alameda Naval Air Station before being preserved as a museum ship. Part of the storyline in \"Ghost Ship\" deals with the final fate of ''Hornet''. It implies (though not explicitly stating it) she was eventually scrapped due to severe fire damage sustained during the course of the episode, contrary to her real-life fate as a national landmark. The subplot in \"Ghost Ship\" indicating that the ship's double hull had to be cut open from the inside to repair supposed damage to her bow during Vietnam was not at all correct with her service record.

''Coral Sea'' is also featured in the season-three episode \"Vanished\" and season-four episodes \"Angels 30\" and \"Shakedown\". As she had already been scrapped at the time the episodes supposedly took place, archival footage of ''Coral Sea'' was used, with other footage shot aboard ''Forrestal''. The majority of the exterior scenes from \"Angels 30\" were filmed aboard ''Forrestal'' and a few aboard ''Enterprise''.
''Belknap'' is mentioned in the season-four episode \"Going after Francesca\" as the [[United States Sixth Fleet
column2: Sixth Fleet]] flagship, a role she actually fulfilled in real life from 1986 until her decommissioning in 1994. ''Belknap'' had already been decommissioned and was laid up awaiting scrapping when the episode was filmed, allowing for actual exterior shots of the ship to be featured in the episode.

column1: The series also includes appearances by {{sclass-
column13: 6}} itself during the opening credit montage), and {{sclass-
column16: 1}}s. In one of the episodes, the [[Spanish Navy
column21: 2}} is used to depict a fictional USN ''Oliver Hazard Perry''-class ship (denoted by her NATO pennant number \"F 81\" painted under the bridge, instead of the U.S. practice of having a \"number only\" ID painted on the bow).

column1: While most sea episodes are focused on aviation missions, several are based around submarine warfare: namely episodes 1:3, 2:6, 4:16, 5:22, 6:15, 7:14, 7:24, 8:7, 8:17, and 9:7.

column4: Harm (David James Elliott) and Mac (Catherine Bell) use a challenge coin to determine who will resign his or her commission.]]

column1: In February 2005, David James Elliott announced he would leave the show at the end of the 10th season; the show was subsequently not renewed for an 11th season by the network.<ref name=\"Why JAG\">{{cite web
column4: title=Why 'JAG' came to an abrupt end
column12: df=mdy-all}}</ref> The show also introduced new younger characters, including former ''[[As the World Turns]]'' star [[Chris Beetem]], and [[Jordana Spiro]] from ''[[The Huntress (TV series)

column1: The producers also considered relocating the fictional setting of the show, from Falls Church to [[Naval Base San Diego]]. An episode of the final season, \"[[List of JAG episodes#ep222
column2: JAG: San Diego]]\" had the main cast, excluding Harm, going to the San Diego naval base and working with the local JAG office there. Though it was reportedly considered as a pilot episode, as a reformat of the show aiming for a younger audience, CBS ultimately decided not to pursue a new series.

column1: Nevertheless, CBS announced the cancellation of the show on April 4, 2005, after 10 seasons. The final episode, \"[[List of JAG episodes#ep227
column2: Fair Winds and Following Seas]]\", aired on April 29, 2005, and in which Harm and Mac are assigned different [[Military base
column3: stations]]: Harm in [[London]], Mac in [[San Diego]]. They finally confront their feelings and decide to get married. The episode ends with Bud tossing a [[challenge coin]] to decide which one would give up his or her military career to be with the other. However, in keeping with ''JAG'' tradition, the outcome of the toss is never seen, as the screen fades to black, showing only the coin, which bears the inscription \"1995 – 2005\", the years the series spanned.

column1: What happened is later revealed in the 2019 finale of the [[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 10)
column2: tenth season]] of ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'', ''\"False Flag\"'', in which David James Elliott and Catherine Bell both appeared. Mac won the coin toss and Harm resigned his commission and moved with her to San Diego, but later they mutually ended their relationship and Harm rejoined the Navy and is currently serving as the [[Executive officer
column3: XO]] of the (fictional) aircraft carrier, ''USS Allegiance''. Mac left the Marines to serve as Marine Liaison to the Secretary of State, a civilian position. Harm and Mac had not seen each other in 9 years until video conferencing with each other in their new roles. In the [[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 11)
column4: eleventh season]] premiere, Harm and Mac reunite in person, share an embrace, and later renew a discussion of their relationship, once again without reaching a conclusion.

column1: In January 2003, CBS announced that Donald P. Bellisario was developing a ''JAG'' [[Spin-off (media)
column2: spin-off]],  around the work of the [[Naval Criminal Investigative Service]].<ref name=\"Variety20030113\">{{cite web
column3: title=CBS ‘Angel’ to fly home – Net also eyes 'JAG' spinoff
column11: df=mdy-all}}</ref> It was aired in April 2003 in a two-part [[backdoor pilot]] in which Commander Rabb is arrested, but later vindicated as innocent, for the murder of Lieutenant Singer. The two episodes, titled \"[[Ice Queen (JAG)
column13: Meltdown]]\", focused on the NCIS team, with most of the JAG regulars as supporting characters. Whereas the episodes of ''JAG'' are primarily oriented on a mixture of courtroom drama and military activities in the field, ''[[NCIS (TV series)
column14: NCIS]]'' episodes are more focused, as the meaning of  the acronym suggests, on criminal investigations. ''NCIS'' also follows a different storytelling format from ''JAG'', emphasizing character humor to a larger extent than its parent program. ''NCIS'' later produced its own spin-offs, ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'' and ''[[NCIS: New Orleans]]'', which shows a further departure from the styles and themes of ''JAG''.

column1: The two episodes \"Ice Queen\" and \"Meltdown\" were edited down to a one-hour pilot film, which was then used to sell the idea of ''NCIS'' as a new series to CBS; the pilot used the title, \"NCIS – The Beginning\". It was later also used to introduce the show to CBS affiliates and advertisers.  It was only broadcast once and is not available on home video.

Excluding the backdoor pilot, few major characters from ''JAG'' have appeared in the ''NCIS'' series. Patrick Labyorteaux appeared briefly as Lieutenant Bud Roberts in the ''NCIS'' first-season episode \"[[NCIS (season 1)#ep2
column2: Hung Out to Dry]]\", and again – now with the rank of captain – in the season fourteen episode \"Rogue,\" advising the NCIS team on a legal issue. [[John M. Jackson]] returned in May 2013 as retired Rear Admiral A.J. Chegwidden, now a civilian attorney in the private sector hired by [[List of NCIS characters#Leon Vance
column3: Director Vance]] to provide legal representation for [[Leroy Jethro Gibbs
column4: Special Agent Gibbs]], in the season ten ''NCIS'' finale, \"[[Damned If You Do (NCIS)
column5: Damned If You Do]]\".<ref name=tl>{{cite web
column8: title=NCIS Exclusive: A JAG Favorite to Return in This Season's 'Nail-Biter' of a Finale
column16: df=mdy-all}}</ref> Jackson has recurred as A.J. Chegwidden since the eighth season of ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]''. Chegwidden is a Vietnam-era compatriot of series regulars Hetty Lange ([[Linda Hunt]]) and Owen Granger ([[Miguel Ferrer]]). David James Elliot and Catherine Bell returned to their roles as Harmon Rabb and Sarah MacKenzie for the first time since ''JAG'' ended in the last two episodes of [[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 10)
column17: the tenth season of ''NCIS: Los Angeles'']].<ref>\"[[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 10)#ep23

column1: While several other actors who played major roles on ''JAG'' have also appeared on ''NCIS'', such as Scott Lawrence (Sturgis Turner on ''JAG''),<ref>Scott Lawrence played Captain Thomas Lind in the ''NCIS'' episode \"[[A Man Walks Into a Bar...]]\".</ref> Steven Culp (Clayton Webb on ''JAG''),<ref>Steven Culp played Commander William Skinner in the ''NCIS'' fifth-season episode \"[[NCIS (season 5)#ep100
column2: Chimera]]\".</ref> Randy Vazquez (Victor Galindez on ''JAG''),<ref>Randy Vazquez played ATF Special Agent Phillip Caffey in the ''NCIS'' twelfth-season episode \"[[NCIS (season 12)#ep278
column3: No Good Deed]]\".</ref> and [[Michael Bellisario]] ([[Mikey Roberts]] on ''JAG'');<ref>Recurring part as [[List of NCIS characters#Charles .22Chip.22 Sterling
column8: Frame Up]]\") of the third season of ''NCIS''.</ref> they played completely different characters when appearing on ''NCIS''. Similarly, after [[Sean Murray (actor)
column9: Sean Murray]] (Donald Bellisario's stepson) played a one-off Ensign character in ''JAG'' season 4, and the recurring character of Danny Walden in season 6, he joined the core cast of ''NCIS'' during the first season as Tim McGee, and is still on the show as of 2019.

column1: First introduced in the NCIS back-door pilot, [[Alicia Coppola]] appeared as Navy judge advocate Lieutenant Commander Faith Coleman in several episodes of ''NCIS''.<ref>''NCIS'' episodes: \"[[NCIS (season 1)#ep18
column4: Hometown Hero]]\".</ref> [[Adam Baldwin]] played the same guest role, Navy SEAL Commander Michael Rainer, in one episode of each show.<ref>''JAG'': \"[[List of JAG episodes#ep195

column1: ''[[First Monday]]'' was a short-lived series co-created by Bellisario and [[Paul Levine]] about fictional [[U.S. Supreme Court]] justices and their clerks, which aired in 2002 and starred [[James Garner]] and [[Joe Mantegna]]. The character of [[U.S. Senator]] Edward Sheffield ([[Dean Stockwell]]), who appeared in three episodes of that show, later became a recurring character on ''JAG'' as the new [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column2: Secretary of the Navy]], starting in season eight.

column1: The sitcom ''[[Yes, Dear]]'' did an episode called \"Let's Get Jaggy With It\" where Greg's father Tom ([[Tim Conway]]) wins a walk-on role on ''JAG''. Catherine Bell guest-starred as herself while David James Elliott, Patrick Labyorteaux, and Scott Lawrence guest-starred as their respective ''JAG'' characters.

On September 1, 1998, the pilot episode of ''JAG'' was released on [[VHS]] cassette in the U.S. by [[Paramount Home Entertainment]]. However, no further episodes of the series proper were released on any home entertainment media while the show was still in production, allegedly due to syndication deals made with several broadcasters.<ref>{{cite web
Beginning in 2006, [[CBS Home Entertainment]] (distributed by [[Paramount Home Entertainment
column2: Paramount]]) has released all 10 seasons on DVD in regions 1, 2 and 4.<ref>[http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/shows/JAG/2445#News JAG] {{webarchive
column4: date=February 17, 2013 }}, [[TVShowsOnDVD.com]]. retrieved on 2013-09-17.</ref> Seasons 1 to 4 are released with a 4:3 [[aspect ratio (image)
column5: aspect ratio]], while seasons 5 to 10 have a 16:9 aspect ratio. The region-2 and −4 editions do not have the bonus features (audio commentaries and retrospective interviews) included on the region-1 editions of seasons one and two.

column1: On December 11, 2012, CBS released ''JAG: The Complete Series – Collector's Edition'' on DVD in region 1. This collection contains, other than all 227 episodes of the series and the bonus features of the previously released individual season packs, one disc with new bonus features and a booklet with production notes.<ref>[http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/JAG-The-Complete-Series/17502 JAG: The Complete Series] {{webarchive

On April 14, 2015, [[CBS Home Entertainment]] released a repackaged version of the complete series set, at a lower price, in Region 1. It does not include the bonus disc that was part of the original complete series set.<ref name=\"re-release\">{{cite web

column3: Judge Advocate General]]<ref>Sometimes stylized as '''''J*A*G''''' in promotional materials, including the DVD releases</ref>) is an American [[legal drama]] television series with a U.S. Navy theme, created by [[Donald P. Bellisario]], and produced by Belisarius Productions in association with [[Paramount Pictures
column5: Network Television]] (now [[CBS Television Studios]]).<ref name=\"2000 production notes\">{{cite web
column11: archivedate=December 10, 2000 }}. From the Paramount website, through [[archive.org]]. Retrieved on 2015-03-22.</ref><ref>It was one of the last Paramount-produced TV series to end under that name, prior to the firm becoming [[CBS Paramount Network Television]].</ref> The series was originally aired on [[NBC]] for one season from September 23, 1995, to May 22, 1996, and then on [[CBS]] for an additional nine seasons from January 3, 1997, to April 29, 2005. The first season was co-produced with [[Universal Television
column12: NBC Productions]] (now [[Universal Television]]) and was originally perceived as a ''[[Top Gun]]'' meets ''[[A Few Good Men]]'' hybrid series.<ref name=\"Neal Karlen 1995\">[[Neal Karlen
column13: Karlen, Neal]]. \"[https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/05/tv/cover-story-from-the-man-behind-magnum-pi-top-gun-meets-a-few-good-men.html COVER STORY;From the Man Behind 'Magnum, P.I.,' 'Top Gun' Meets 'A Few Good Men'] {{webarchive

column1: In the spring of 1996, NBC announced that the series had been canceled after finishing 79th in the ratings, leaving one episode unaired. In December 1996, the rival network CBS announced it had picked up the series as a [[mid-season replacement]] and aired 15 new episodes as its second season. For several seasons, ''JAG'' climbed in the ratings and ultimately ran for nine additional seasons. ''JAG'' furthermore spawned the hit series ''[[NCIS (TV series)
column2: NCIS]]'', which in turn led to spin-offs ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'' and ''[[NCIS: New Orleans]]''.

column1: In total, 227 episodes were produced over 10 seasons. At the time of the original airing of its fifth season in the United States, ''JAG'' was seen in over 90 countries worldwide.<ref>{{cite web
column7: archivedate=November 10, 2000 }}. Official Paramount site from January 2000, retrieved through [[archive.org]]. Retrieved on 2013-10-09.</ref> ''JAG'' entered [[Broadcast syndication

column6: source=Donald P. Bellisario on creating ''JAG''<ref name=\"2000pn3\">{{cite web
column12: archivedate=December 10, 2000 }}. From the Paramount website, through [[archive.org]]. Retrieved on 2013-10-09.</ref>
column13: \"Dramatic, action adventure programming has all but disappeared from the airwaves. I don't do [[sitcom]]s; I don't do urban neurotic dramas. I created ''JAG'' because it's the kind of television I like to watch. Besides that, I served four years in the Marine Corps and remain fascinated by the military's code of ethics—God, duty, honor, country—and how, in these rapidly changing times, it still survives. That's what Harm and Mac, and ''JAG'' as a whole, represent.\"}}

column1: The series follows the exploits of the [[Washington metropolitan area]]–based<ref>In the first season, the JAG headquarters was set in [[Washington, DC]], while in later seasons it is located in [[Falls Church, Virginia]]. The real-life OJAG is based at [[the Pentagon]] and the [[Washington Navy Yard]].</ref> \"[[Judge Advocate General's Corps, U.S. Navy

column18: 827}}</ref> (arising from the global presence of the [[U.S. Navy]] and the [[U.S. Marine Corps]]<ref>{{UnitedStatesCode
column20: 805}}</ref>), conduct informal and formal investigations, and advise on [[Laws of war

column2: CIA]] intelligence operations, often revolving around the recurring character CIA officer [[Clayton Webb]] (played by [[Steven Culp]]).

The creator of ''JAG'', Donald P. Bellisario, served for four years in the [[U.S. Marine Corps]], and after having worked his way up through advertising jobs, he landed his first network television job as a story editor for the World War II-era series ''[[Baa Baa Black Sheep (TV series)
column2: Baa Baa Black Sheep]]'', where he got a habit of promoting a consistent promilitary stance in a business where he got the perception that \"antiwar\" and \"antisoldier\" mentality were the commonplace.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\">[[#Erickson
column3: Erickson]]: p. 127.</ref> The stereotype in the post-[[Vietnam war]] era of \"[[Vietnam Veteran#Negative stereotypes of Vietnam veterans and efforts to overcome
column4: crazed Vietnam veterans]]\" was notably subverted, by not just one, but three of the main characters, in ''[[Magnum P.I.]]'', of which Bellisario was the co-creator.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

column1: Following the cancellation of his series ''[[Quantum Leap]]'', Bellisario began working on a one-shot screenplay of a murder mystery aboard a U.S. Navy aircraft carrier, where the victim was a female aviator.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

The issue of whether or not to expand the options for women serving in the U.S. armed forces as fighter pilots and in other frontline assignments was a contentious social issue of the day. In 1991, a famous incident had occurred at the [[Tailhook Association]] [[Tailhook scandal
column2: convention in Las Vegas]], where male naval aviators had behaved in manners inappropriate, if not criminal.  The follow-up criminal and other investigations by the [[Naval Investigative Service
column3: then-named NIS]], the [[Naval Inspector General]], and the Judge Advocate General of the Navy, were later heavily criticized by the [[Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Defense]].  The  [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column4: Acting Secretary of the Navy]] [[Sean O'Keefe]], to whom the report was delivered, agreed with the findings and began to take corrective action with respect to both the perceived attitude problems towards women and the functions of the investigative arms of the Department of the Navy.<ref>{{cite AV media

column1: The fallout from the incident resulted in a hard blow to the [[Naval aviation
column2: naval aviation community]], where the promotions of many [[naval aviator]]s were put on hold. The common counterclaim from the other side of the aisle, as articulated by former Secretary of the Navy in the [[Reagan administration]] and [[naval flight officer]] [[John F. Lehman]], was that the naval aviation community had been unfairly subjected to a witch-hunt motivated by [[political correctness]], in effect killing its ''esprit de corps'', and by extension damaging its combat effectiveness.<ref name=\"Lehman:372\">[[#Lehman
column3: Lehman]]: p. 372.</ref> During the [[Clinton administration]] in April 1993, [[United States Secretary of Defense
column4: Secretary of Defense]] [[Les Aspin]] announced a new policy, which in effect made it possible to have female fighter pilots serving on aircraft carriers at sea and in other new positions (but still prohibited from serving in [[infantry]], etc.)

column3: title = Women in Combat (Department of Defense briefing)

column1: Thus, the stage was set for the reality-based fictional drama, when Bellisario read in a newspaper about the forthcoming introduction of female fighter pilots on aircraft carriers.<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

While doing research on which organizational entities would partake in investigative efforts of crimes committed aboard Naval vessels, Bellisario found  the special agents of the [[Naval Criminal Investigative Service]] filled the police role, and the uniformed lawyers, in the Navy's Judge Advocate General's Corps, could alternate between the role of defense attorney, prosecutor, and field investigator. Bellisario chose to go ahead with the lawyers and remarked season six about the unique advantages it brought from a story-telling point of view: \"Unlike most [[legal drama
column2: law shows]], I've got a detective, a prosecutor, and a defender.\"<ref name=\"Erickson:127\"/>

column1: [[File:RADM Donald Guter, JAGC, USN visited the JAG television series set, 2001-02-20.jpg
column3: The then-[[Judge Advocate General of the Navy]], Rear Admiral Donald J. Guter (second from left), visiting the set, meeting with the cast during the shooting of \"[[JAG (season 6)#ep128

column1: Initially, the producers of ''JAG'' did not receive any co-operation from the Department of the Navy, due to sensitivity in light of all the accumulative negative publicity that had been generated from the [[Tailhook scandal]] and its aftermath.<ref name=\"Erickson:129\">[[#Erickson
column2: Erickson]]: p. 129.</ref> However, the lack of co-operation from the military was not a show-stopper, as the ''JAG'' production team, by virtue of being a [[Paramount Pictures]] production, had access to the [[stock footage]] of the motion pictures owned by the studio, which included many films with military content, such as ''[[Top Gun (film)
column4: The Final Countdown]]'', and ''[[The Hunt for Red October (film)
column5: The Hunt for Red October]].<ref name=\"Erickson:128\">[[#Erickson

column1: In 1997, though, the naval services had begun to change their minds, and began to render support to the production team on a script-by-script basis. A primetime network series about Navy lawyers bringing out controversial subjects in a very public arena was apparently no longer an issue in itself, but as noted by Commander Bob Anderson of the Navy's [[Public affairs (military)
column2: entertainment media liaison office]] in Los Angeles in a ''[[TV Guide]]'' interview: \"We're fine with that as long as the bad guys are caught and punished, and the institution of the Navy is not the bad guy\".<ref name=\"Erickson:129\"/>

column1: Almost all episodes of the series feature scenes filmed aboard real United States Navy ships. The ship most widely used was {{USS
column4: 6}}, in commission as a training carrier at the time. Most of the ''Nimitz''-class carriers also appear in one or several episodes. {{USS
column13: 6}} were also used in the series.

column1: USS ''Enterprise'' was used as the fictional USS ''Seahawk'' in many episodes. USS ''Forrestal'' and {{USS
column4: 6}} were also used as the fictional ''Seahawk'', both in season four and for one episode each. For scenes filmed aboard ''Enterprise'', the whole crew wore caps reading ''USS Seahawk – CVN 65'' so they matched the ship's real hull number.

column1: USS ''Forrestal'' was featured in many episodes, most prominently two in which she portrayed the fictional USS ''Reprisal''.  In these episodes, all crew members wore caps with the ''CV-35'' pennant number.  This number was intentionally out of sequence with the pennant numbers of active USN carriers at the time the series was filmed. CV-35 would have been the real pennant number of an ''Essex''-class carrier actually called ''Reprisal'', which was canceled during construction in 1945 when World War II ended, and broken up in 1949 after consideration had been given to completing her to a revised design roughly similar to that of {{USS
Only six USN ships featured in the series were called by their real names: {{USS
column19: 6}}. ''Kitty Hawk'' is mentioned in one of the season-three episodes, but never seen on screen. ''America'' is the murder scene in a season-three episode, but shots supposedly depicting her are in fact shots of ''Forrestal''. Real shots of ''Theodore Roosevelt'' in harbor are used in one episode of season one.

column1: [[File:US Navy 050125-N-0685S-001 Crewmembers for the hit television show JAG set up for the next shot outside the Transient Aircraft Line on board Naval Air Station North Island, Calif.jpg
column4: Crewmembers set up for a shot at [[Naval Air Station North Island

column1: Season-three opener \"Ghost Ship\" was filmed entirely aboard ''Hornet'' while she was laid up at Alameda Naval Air Station before being preserved as a museum ship. Part of the storyline in \"Ghost Ship\" deals with the final fate of ''Hornet''. It implies (though not explicitly stating it) she was eventually scrapped due to severe fire damage sustained during the course of the episode, contrary to her real-life fate as a national landmark. The subplot in \"Ghost Ship\" indicating that the ship's double hull had to be cut open from the inside to repair supposed damage to her bow during Vietnam was not at all correct with her service record.

''Coral Sea'' is also featured in the season-three episode \"Vanished\" and season-four episodes \"Angels 30\" and \"Shakedown\". As she had already been scrapped at the time the episodes supposedly took place, archival footage of ''Coral Sea'' was used, with other footage shot aboard ''Forrestal''. The majority of the exterior scenes from \"Angels 30\" were filmed aboard ''Forrestal'' and a few aboard ''Enterprise''.
''Belknap'' is mentioned in the season-four episode \"Going after Francesca\" as the [[United States Sixth Fleet
column2: Sixth Fleet]] flagship, a role she actually fulfilled in real life from 1986 until her decommissioning in 1994. ''Belknap'' had already been decommissioned and was laid up awaiting scrapping when the episode was filmed, allowing for actual exterior shots of the ship to be featured in the episode.

column1: The series also includes appearances by {{sclass-
column13: 6}} itself during the opening credit montage), and {{sclass-
column16: 1}}s. In one of the episodes, the [[Spanish Navy
column21: 2}} is used to depict a fictional USN ''Oliver Hazard Perry''-class ship (denoted by her NATO pennant number \"F 81\" painted under the bridge, instead of the U.S. practice of having a \"number only\" ID painted on the bow).

column1: While most sea episodes are focused on aviation missions, several are based around submarine warfare: namely episodes 1:3, 2:6, 4:16, 5:22, 6:15, 7:14, 7:24, 8:7, 8:17, and 9:7.

column4: Harm (David James Elliott) and Mac (Catherine Bell) use a challenge coin to determine who will resign his or her commission.]]

column1: In February 2005, David James Elliott announced he would leave the show at the end of the 10th season; the show was subsequently not renewed for an 11th season by the network.<ref name=\"Why JAG\">{{cite web
column4: title=Why 'JAG' came to an abrupt end
column12: df=mdy-all}}</ref> The show also introduced new younger characters, including former ''[[As the World Turns]]'' star [[Chris Beetem]], and [[Jordana Spiro]] from ''[[The Huntress (TV series)

column1: The producers also considered relocating the fictional setting of the show, from Falls Church to [[Naval Base San Diego]]. An episode of the final season, \"[[List of JAG episodes#ep222
column2: JAG: San Diego]]\" had the main cast, excluding Harm, going to the San Diego naval base and working with the local JAG office there. Though it was reportedly considered as a pilot episode, as a reformat of the show aiming for a younger audience, CBS ultimately decided not to pursue a new series.

column1: Nevertheless, CBS announced the cancellation of the show on April 4, 2005, after 10 seasons. The final episode, \"[[List of JAG episodes#ep227
column2: Fair Winds and Following Seas]]\", aired on April 29, 2005, and in which Harm and Mac are assigned different [[Military base
column3: stations]]: Harm in [[London]], Mac in [[San Diego]]. They finally confront their feelings and decide to get married. The episode ends with Bud tossing a [[challenge coin]] to decide which one would give up his or her military career to be with the other. However, in keeping with ''JAG'' tradition, the outcome of the toss is never seen, as the screen fades to black, showing only the coin, which bears the inscription \"1995 – 2005\", the years the series spanned.

column1: What happened is later revealed in the 2019 finale of the [[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 10)
column2: tenth season]] of ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'', ''\"False Flag\"'', in which David James Elliott and Catherine Bell both appeared. Mac won the coin toss and Harm resigned his commission and moved with her to San Diego, but later they mutually ended their relationship and Harm rejoined the Navy and is currently serving as the [[Executive officer
column3: XO]] of the (fictional) aircraft carrier, ''USS Allegiance''. Mac left the Marines to serve as Marine Liaison to the Secretary of State, a civilian position. Harm and Mac had not seen each other in 9 years until video conferencing with each other in their new roles. In the [[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 11)
column4: eleventh season]] premiere, Harm and Mac reunite in person, share an embrace, and later renew a discussion of their relationship, once again without reaching a conclusion.

column1: In January 2003, CBS announced that Donald P. Bellisario was developing a ''JAG'' [[Spin-off (media)
column2: spin-off]],  around the work of the [[Naval Criminal Investigative Service]].<ref name=\"Variety20030113\">{{cite web
column3: title=CBS ‘Angel’ to fly home – Net also eyes 'JAG' spinoff
column11: df=mdy-all}}</ref> It was aired in April 2003 in a two-part [[backdoor pilot]] in which Commander Rabb is arrested, but later vindicated as innocent, for the murder of Lieutenant Singer. The two episodes, titled \"[[Ice Queen (JAG)
column13: Meltdown]]\", focused on the NCIS team, with most of the JAG regulars as supporting characters. Whereas the episodes of ''JAG'' are primarily oriented on a mixture of courtroom drama and military activities in the field, ''[[NCIS (TV series)
column14: NCIS]]'' episodes are more focused, as the meaning of  the acronym suggests, on criminal investigations. ''NCIS'' also follows a different storytelling format from ''JAG'', emphasizing character humor to a larger extent than its parent program. ''NCIS'' later produced its own spin-offs, ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'' and ''[[NCIS: New Orleans]]'', which shows a further departure from the styles and themes of ''JAG''.

column1: The two episodes \"Ice Queen\" and \"Meltdown\" were edited down to a one-hour pilot film, which was then used to sell the idea of ''NCIS'' as a new series to CBS; the pilot used the title, \"NCIS – The Beginning\". It was later also used to introduce the show to CBS affiliates and advertisers.  It was only broadcast once and is not available on home video.

Excluding the backdoor pilot, few major characters from ''JAG'' have appeared in the ''NCIS'' series. Patrick Labyorteaux appeared briefly as Lieutenant Bud Roberts in the ''NCIS'' first-season episode \"[[NCIS (season 1)#ep2
column2: Hung Out to Dry]]\", and again – now with the rank of captain – in the season fourteen episode \"Rogue,\" advising the NCIS team on a legal issue. [[John M. Jackson]] returned in May 2013 as retired Rear Admiral A.J. Chegwidden, now a civilian attorney in the private sector hired by [[List of NCIS characters#Leon Vance
column3: Director Vance]] to provide legal representation for [[Leroy Jethro Gibbs
column4: Special Agent Gibbs]], in the season ten ''NCIS'' finale, \"[[Damned If You Do (NCIS)
column5: Damned If You Do]]\".<ref name=tl>{{cite web
column8: title=NCIS Exclusive: A JAG Favorite to Return in This Season's 'Nail-Biter' of a Finale
column16: df=mdy-all}}</ref> Jackson has recurred as A.J. Chegwidden since the eighth season of ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]''. Chegwidden is a Vietnam-era compatriot of series regulars Hetty Lange ([[Linda Hunt]]) and Owen Granger ([[Miguel Ferrer]]). David James Elliot and Catherine Bell returned to their roles as Harmon Rabb and Sarah MacKenzie for the first time since ''JAG'' ended in the last two episodes of [[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 10)
column17: the tenth season of ''NCIS: Los Angeles'']].<ref>\"[[NCIS: Los Angeles (season 10)#ep23

column1: While several other actors who played major roles on ''JAG'' have also appeared on ''NCIS'', such as Scott Lawrence (Sturgis Turner on ''JAG''),<ref>Scott Lawrence played Captain Thomas Lind in the ''NCIS'' episode \"[[A Man Walks Into a Bar...]]\".</ref> Steven Culp (Clayton Webb on ''JAG''),<ref>Steven Culp played Commander William Skinner in the ''NCIS'' fifth-season episode \"[[NCIS (season 5)#ep100
column2: Chimera]]\".</ref> Randy Vazquez (Victor Galindez on ''JAG''),<ref>Randy Vazquez played ATF Special Agent Phillip Caffey in the ''NCIS'' twelfth-season episode \"[[NCIS (season 12)#ep278
column3: No Good Deed]]\".</ref> and [[Michael Bellisario]] ([[Mikey Roberts]] on ''JAG'');<ref>Recurring part as [[List of NCIS characters#Charles .22Chip.22 Sterling
column8: Frame Up]]\") of the third season of ''NCIS''.</ref> they played completely different characters when appearing on ''NCIS''. Similarly, after [[Sean Murray (actor)
column9: Sean Murray]] (Donald Bellisario's stepson) played a one-off Ensign character in ''JAG'' season 4, and the recurring character of Danny Walden in season 6, he joined the core cast of ''NCIS'' during the first season as Tim McGee, and is still on the show as of 2019.

column1: First introduced in the NCIS back-door pilot, [[Alicia Coppola]] appeared as Navy judge advocate Lieutenant Commander Faith Coleman in several episodes of ''NCIS''.<ref>''NCIS'' episodes: \"[[NCIS (season 1)#ep18
column4: Hometown Hero]]\".</ref> [[Adam Baldwin]] played the same guest role, Navy SEAL Commander Michael Rainer, in one episode of each show.<ref>''JAG'': \"[[List of JAG episodes#ep195

column1: ''[[First Monday]]'' was a short-lived series co-created by Bellisario and [[Paul Levine]] about fictional [[U.S. Supreme Court]] justices and their clerks, which aired in 2002 and starred [[James Garner]] and [[Joe Mantegna]]. The character of [[U.S. Senator]] Edward Sheffield ([[Dean Stockwell]]), who appeared in three episodes of that show, later became a recurring character on ''JAG'' as the new [[United States Secretary of the Navy
column2: Secretary of the Navy]], starting in season eight.

column1: The sitcom ''[[Yes, Dear]]'' did an episode called \"Let's Get Jaggy With It\" where Greg's father Tom ([[Tim Conway]]) wins a walk-on role on ''JAG''. Catherine Bell guest-starred as herself while David James Elliott, Patrick Labyorteaux, and Scott Lawrence guest-starred as their respective ''JAG'' characters.

On September 1, 1998, the pilot episode of ''JAG'' was released on [[VHS]] cassette in the U.S. by [[Paramount Home Entertainment]]. However, no further episodes of the series proper were released on any home entertainment media while the show was still in production, allegedly due to syndication deals made with several broadcasters.<ref>{{cite web
Beginning in 2006, [[CBS Home Entertainment]] (distributed by [[Paramount Home Entertainment
column2: Paramount]]) has released all 10 seasons on DVD in regions 1, 2 and 4.<ref>[http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/shows/JAG/2445#News JAG] {{webarchive
column4: date=February 17, 2013 }}, [[TVShowsOnDVD.com]]. retrieved on 2013-09-17.</ref> Seasons 1 to 4 are released with a 4:3 [[aspect ratio (image)
column5: aspect ratio]], while seasons 5 to 10 have a 16:9 aspect ratio. The region-2 and −4 editions do not have the bonus features (audio commentaries and retrospective interviews) included on the region-1 editions of seasons one and two.

column1: On December 11, 2012, CBS released ''JAG: The Complete Series – Collector's Edition'' on DVD in region 1. This collection contains, other than all 227 episodes of the series and the bonus features of the previously released individual season packs, one disc with new bonus features and a booklet with production notes.<ref>[http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/JAG-The-Complete-Series/17502 JAG: The Complete Series] {{webarchive

On April 14, 2015, [[CBS Home Entertainment]] released a repackaged version of the complete series set, at a lower price, in Region 1. It does not include the bonus disc that was part of the original complete series set.<ref name=\"re-release\">{{cite web

column1: [[File:04.02_總統視察「中央流行疫情指揮中心」_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg
The wearing of '''face masks during the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]]''' has received varying recommendations from different [[List of national public health agencies
column2: public health agencies]] and [[governments]]. The topic has been a subject of debate, with public health agencies and governments disagreeing on a universal protocol for wearing face masks. Some groups are recommending that all members of the public wear masks, while others recommend that only [[COVID-19]] patients and their caretakers should wear masks. Additionally, public health agencies of different countries and territories have changed their recommendations regarding face masks over time.<ref name=\"mask_not_mask\"/> Face masks have been a subject of [[shortage]]s and also been made compulsory in some countries.

column1: Types of face masks, from least to most protective, include [[Cloth facemask
column2: cloth facemasks]], medical (non-surgical) masks,<ref name=\"nhc_masks\" /><ref name=20200402businessinsider/> [[surgical masks]], and filtering facepiece [[respirator]]s such as [[N95 mask]]s and [[FFP mask]]s.

column1: A [[cloth facemask]] is a mask made of common [[Textile
column2: textiles]], usually [[cotton]], worn over the mouth and nose.  Unlike surgical masks and respirators, they are not subject to regulation, and there is currently little research or guidance on their effectiveness as a protective measure against [[Transmission (medicine)
column5: date=April 2020}}  They were routinely used by healthcare workers starting from the late 19th century until the mid 20th century.  In the 1960s they fell out of use in the [[Developed country
column6: developed world]] in favor of modern surgical masks, but their use has persisted in [[Developing country
column11: title=Reusability of Facemasks During an Influenza Pandemic: Facing the Flu
column23: title=Facemasks for the prevention of infection in healthcare and community settings
column41: title=Use of cloth masks in the practice of infection control – evidence and policy gaps

column1: A [[surgical mask]] is a loose-fitting, [[Disposable product
column2: disposable]] device that creates a physical barrier between the mouth and nose of the wearer and potential [[Contamination
column3: contaminants]] in the immediate environment. If worn properly, a surgical mask is meant to help block large-particle [[Respiratory droplets
column5: sprays]], or splatter that may contain [[Virus
column6: viruses]] and [[bacteria]], keeping it from reaching the wearer's mouth and nose.  Surgical masks may also help reduce exposure of the wearer's [[saliva]] and respiratory secretions to others.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column8: title=N95 Respirators and Surgical Masks (Face Masks)
column14: accessdate=2020-03-28}} {{PD-inline}}</ref> A surgical mask, by design, does not filter or block very small particles in the air that may be transmitted by coughs, sneezes, or certain medical procedures. Surgical masks also do not provide complete protection from [[Pathogen
column15: germs]] and other contaminants because of the loose fit between the surface of the face mask and the face. Surgical masks may be labeled as surgical, isolation, dental, or medical procedure masks.<ref name=\":2\" /> Surgical masks are made of a [[nonwoven fabric]] created using a [[melt blowing]] process.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Not Enough Face Masks Are Made In America To Deal With Coronavirus
column22: title=Chinese mask makers use loopholes to speed up regulatory approval

column1: An [[N95 mask]] is a particulate-filtering facepiece [[respirator]] that meets the N95 [[NIOSH air filtration rating
column2: air filtration rating]] of the US [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]], meaning that it filters at least 95 percent of [[airborne particles]], while not resistant to [[oil]] like the P95. It is the most common particulate-filtering facepiece respirator.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=NIOSH-Approved N95 Particulate Filtering Facepiece Respirators - A Suppliers List
column8: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
column13: access-date=2020-03-27}}</ref>  It is an example of a [[mechanical filter respirator]], which provides protection against [[particulates]], but not [[gas]]es or [[vapor]]s.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: website=U.S. National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
column24: access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref> Like surgical masks, the N95 mask is made of melt-blown nonwoven polypropylene fabric.<ref name=\"VOADeliver\">{{Cite news
column28: title=World Depends on China for Face Masks But Can Country Deliver?
column36: title=COVID-19 Has Caused A Shortage Of Face Masks. But They're Surprisingly Hard To Make
column40: authorlink=}}</ref>  The corresponding facemask used in the [[European Union]] is the [[FFP mask
column43: title=Comparison of FFP2, KN95, and N95 and Other Filtering Facepiece Respirator Classes
column53: title=Strategies for Optimizing the Supply of N95 Respirators: Crisis/Alternate Strategies
column57: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

column1: Health organizations have recommended that people cover their mouth and nose with a bent elbow or a tissue when coughing or sneezing, and dispose of any tissue immediately.<ref name=\"WHO-advice\" /><ref name=\"AutoDW-55\" /> Surgical masks are recommended for those who may be infected,<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":8\" /><ref name=\"who-mask-advices\" /> as wearing a mask can limit the volume and travel distance of [[Respiratory droplet
column2: expiratory droplets]] dispersed when talking, sneezing, and coughing.<ref name=\"nCoV: What the Public Should Do\" /> The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) has issued instructions on when and how to use masks.<ref name=\"WHO masks\" />

column1: Masks have also been recommended for use by those who are taking care of someone who may have the disease.<ref name=\"who-mask-advices\" /> The WHO has recommended the wearing of masks by healthy people only if they are at high risk, such as those who are caring for a person with COVID-19, although they also acknowledge that wearing masks may help people avoid touching their face.<ref name=\"who-mask-advices\" /> Several countries have started to encourage the use of face masks by members of the public.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Puede que Asia haya tenido razón sobre el coronavirus y las mascarillas, y el resto del mundo se está convenciendo de ello

column1: World Health Organization advice to the public in the context of COVID-19 endorsed the use of masks only under the following conditions:<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) advice for the public: When and how to use masks

column1: * If you are healthy, you only need to wear a mask if you are taking care of a person with suspected 2019-nCoV infection.
* Wear a mask if you are coughing or sneezing.
* Masks are effective only when used in combination with frequent hand-cleaning with alcohol-based [[hand sanitizer]] or soap and water.
* If you wear a mask, then you must know how to use it and dispose of it properly.
[[File:Use of Cloth Face Coverings to Help Slow the Spread of COVID-19.pdf
column3: Guidance from the US [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] on using and making cloth masks during the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]]<ref name=\"cdc_cloth\"/>]]

column1: The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column2: United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) recommended in March 2020 that if neither respirators nor surgical masks are available, as a last resort, it may be necessary for healthcare workers to use masks that have never been evaluated or approved by NIOSH or homemade masks, though caution should be exercised when considering this option.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Strategies for Optimizing the Supply of N95 Respirators: Crisis/Alternate Strategies
column8: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column13: access-date=2020-03-28}} {{PD-inline}}</ref>  In April 2020, the CDC recommended that the general public wear cloth face coverings in public settings where other [[social distancing]] measures are difficult to maintain such as, grocery stores and pharmacies, especially in areas of significant community-based transmission, due to the significance of [[Asymptomatic carrier
column14: asymptomatic]] and pre-symptomatic disease transmission.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web
column16: title=Use of Cloth Face Coverings to Help Slow the Spread of COVID-19
column20: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column27: title=Recommendation Regarding the Use of Cloth Face Coverings, Especially in Areas of Significant Community-Based Transmission
column31: website=U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

column1: In March and April 2020, the CDC faced backlash over their earlier statements advising that most healthy people did not need to wear a mask. The earlier recommendations had been made to try to conserve supplies for medical professionals, but damaged the agency's credibility.<ref name=\"BackfiredNYT\">{{cite news
column4: title=Why Telling People They Don't Need Masks Backfired
column15: title=Should We All Be Wearing Masks In Public? Health Experts Revisit The Question

column1: China has specifically recommended the use of disposable [[surgical mask
column2: non-surgical medical masks]] by healthy members of the public,<ref name=\"nhc_masks\" /><ref name=\"autogenerated1\" /> particularly when coming into close contact ({{convert
column6: 0}} or less) with other people.<ref name=\"sci_masks\">{{cite web
column8: title=关于印发公众科学戴口罩指引的通知引
column12: publisher=[[Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention]]
column14: archivedate=20 March 2020 }}</ref> Hong Kong recommends wearing a surgical mask when taking public transport or staying in crowded places.<ref name=\"chp_hk\" /><ref name=\"time5799964\" /> Thailand's health officials are encouraging people to make [[cloth facemask]]s at home and wash them daily.<ref name=\"0azBR\" />

column3: Queue to buy face masks in Hong Kong, January 30, 2020. Everyone in the line is already wearing a disposable medical mask.]]

column1: Among the reasons cited by Chinese health officials for wearing masks even by healthy individuals are the following:<ref name=\"nhc_why\"/>
# Asymptomatic transmission. Many people can be infected without symptoms or only with mild symptoms.
# Impossibility of appropriate social distancing in many public places at all times.

# Cost-benefit mismatch. If only the infected individuals wear a mask, they would possibly have a negative incentive to do so. An infected individual might get nothing positive, but only bear the costs such as inconvenience, purchasing expenses and even prejudice.
# There is no shortage of masks supply in China, which has been producing 100 million masks per day since early March.

Leading microbiologist [[Yuen Kwok-yung]] from the [[University of Hong Kong]] cites a large [[viral load]] in [[sputum]] and [[saliva]] of an infected person and asymptomatic cases as the reasons why even healthy individuals should wear a mask.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Q&A with HK microbiologist Yuen Kwok-yung who helped confirm coronavirus' human spread

column1: According to Stephen Griffin, a virologist at the [[University of Leeds]], \"Wearing a mask can reduce the propensity [of] people to touch their faces, which is a major source of infection without proper hand hygiene.\"<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=How to avoid touching your face so much

column2: Shortages related to the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic}}

column1: [[File:Citizens of Wuhan lining up outside of a drug store to buy masks during the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak.jpg
column3: People in Wuhan lining up in front of a drug store to buy [[surgical masks]]]]

column1: [[File:Surgical mask and 84 disinfectant liquid purchase limit notice at a CSF Market (20200202155633).jpg
column3: A notice at a supermarket in Beijing, which says each person can only buy one pack of surgical masks and one bottle of 84 disinfectant liquid a day]]

column1: As the epidemic accelerated, the mainland market saw a shortage of [[Surgical mask
column2: face masks]] due to increased public demand.<ref name=sohu161795>{{cite news
column5: title=一罩难求：南都民调实测走访发现，线上线下口罩基本卖脱销
column8: agency=南方都市报}}</ref> In Shanghai, customers had to queue for nearly an hour to buy a pack of face masks; stocks were sold out in another in half an hour.<ref name=udn4304194>{{cite news
column11: title=全球各地瘋搶口罩 專家：不必買N95
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> [[Hoarding]] and price gouging drove up prices, so the market regulator said it would crack down on such acts.<ref name=southcn190111854>{{cite news
column20: title=广东市场监管部门：将坚决打击囤积居奇、哄抬价格等行为
column30: url-status=live}}</ref> In January 2020, price controls were imposed on all face masks on [[Taobao]] and [[Tmall]].<ref name=ycwb30486944>{{cite news
column33: title=口罩买不到怎么办？这些药店平台春节期间持续供应
column39: url-status=live}}</ref> Other Chinese e-commerce platforms – [[JD.com]],<ref name=bjnews677805>{{cite web
column41: title=京东：禁止第三方商家口罩涨价
column50: title=苏宁易购：口罩等健康类商品禁涨价，并开展百亿补贴
column59: title=拼多多：对口罩等产品进行监测，恶意涨价者将下架
column66: url-status=live}}</ref> – did likewise; third-party vendors would be subject to price caps, with violators subject to sanctions.

column1: By March, China quadrupled its production capacity and has been producing 100 million masks per day.<ref name=\"nhc_why\"/>

In 2006, 156 million masks were added to the US [[Strategic National Stockpile]] in anticipation of a flu pandemic.<ref name=\"Manjoo\" /> After they were used against the [[2009 flu pandemic]], neither the [[Presidency of Barack Obama
column2: Obama administration]] nor the [[Presidency of Donald Trump
column3: Trump administration]] renewed the stocks.<ref name=\"Manjoo\" /> By 1 April, the US's [[Strategic National Stockpile]] was nearly emptied.<ref name=\"washingtonpost7148009252\">{{cite web
column5: title=Protective gear in national stockpile is nearly depleted, DHS officials say
column7: first=Nick Miroff closeNick MiroffReporter covering immigration

column2: 2009 H1N1]]-related spending rose to €382 million, mainly on supplies and vaccines, which was later criticised.<ref name=\":19\" /><ref name=\":20\" /> It was decided in 2011 to not replete its stocks and rely more on supply from China and [[Just-in-time manufacturing
column3: just-in-time logistics]].<ref name=\":19\" /> In 2010, its stock included 1 billion surgical masks and 600 million FFP2 masks; in early 2020 it was 150 millions and zero, respectively.<ref name=\":19\" /> While stocks were progressively reduced, a 2013 rationale stated the aim to reduce costs of acquisition and storage, now distributing this effort to all private enterprises as an optional best practice to ensure their workers' protection.<ref name=\":19\" /> This was especially relevant to FFP2 masks, more costly to acquire and store.<ref name=\":19\" /><ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Quand l'État stratège a renoncé à renouveler ses stocks de masques
column13: access-date=6 April 2020}}</ref> As the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in France]] took an increasing toll on medical supplies, masks and PPE supplies ran low and caused national outrage. France needs 40 millions masks per week, according to French president Emmanuel Macron.<ref name=\":25\">{{cite web
column15: title=France to produce 40 million face masks by end of April for domestic battle against Covid-19
column18: access-date=6 April 2020}}</ref> France instructed its few remaining mask-producing factories to work 24/7 shifts, and to ramp up national production to 40 millions masks per month.<ref name=\":25\" /> French lawmakers have opened an inquiry on the past management of these strategic stocks.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Covid-19: French lawmakers to investigate where one and a half billion masks sent
column23: access-date=6 April 2020}}</ref> The mask shortage has been called a ''\"scandal d'État\"'' (State scandal).<ref>{{cite web
column25: title=Pénurie de masques : les raisons d'un \"scandale d'État\"

column1: In late-March/early-April 2020, as Western countries were in turn dependent on China for supplies of masks and other equipment, China was seen as making soft-power play to influence world opinion.<ref name=bbc52092395/><ref name=20200402businessinsider/> However, a batch of masks purchased by Netherlands was reportedly rejected as being sub-standard. The Dutch health ministry issued a recall of 600,000 face masks from a Chinese supplier on 21 March which did not fit properly and whose filters did not work as intended despite them having a quality certificate.<ref name=\"bbc52092395\"/><ref name=\"20200402businessinsider\"/> The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs responded that the customer should \"double-check the instructions to make sure that you ordered, paid for and distributed the right ones. Do not use non-surgical masks for surgical purposes\".<ref name=20200402businessinsider/>
N95 masks were in short supply and high demand during the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]].<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Feds have 1.5 million expired N95 masks in storage despite CDC clearing them for use on COVID-19: report
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> Production of N95 masks was limited due to constraints on the supply of [[nonwoven polypropylene]] fabric (which is used as the primary filter) as well as the cessation of exports from China.<ref name=\"VOADeliver\" /><ref>{{Cite news
column13: title=Critical Component of Protective Masks in Short Supply - The epidemic has driven up demand for material in N95 filters; 'everyone thinks there is this magic factory somewhere'
column19: authorlink= }}</ref> China controls 50{{nbsp}}percent of global production of masks, and facing its own coronavirus epidemic, dedicated all its production for domestic use, only allowing exports through government-allocated humanitarian assistance.<ref name=\"VOADeliver\" />

column1: In March 2020, President [[Donald Trump]] applied the [[Defense Production Act]] against the American company [[3M]] which allows the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] to obtain N95 respirators from [[3M]].<ref name=\"Fabian\">{{cite web
column3: title=Trump Attacks 3M Over Mask Production, Drawing Company Pushback
column19: first3=Tom}}</ref> White House trade adviser [[Peter Navarro]] stated that there were concerns that 3M products were not making their way to the US.<ref name=\"Fabian\" /> 3M replied that it has not changed the prices it charges and is unable to control the prices its dealers or retailers charge.<ref name=\"Fabian\" />

column1: In early April 2020, Berlin politician [[Andreas Geisel]] alleged that a shipment of 200,000 N95 masks that it had ordered from American producer [[3M]]'s China facility were intercepted in [[Bangkok]] and diverted to the United States.<ref name=Betschka>{{cite news
column11: Michael Müller]] blamed president Trump for the confiscation and [[Berlin Police
column13: Barbara Slowik]] stated that she believes \"this is related to the US government's export ban.\"<ref name=Betschka/> 3M said they had no knowledge of the shipment, stating \"We know nothing of an order from the Berlin police for 3M masks that come from China\" and the US government denied that any confiscation had happened and that they use appropriate channels for all its purchases.<ref name=Betschka/><ref>{{Cite news
column17: title=Schutzmasken konfisziert? Schwere Vorwürfe aus Berlin: Jetzt reagiert das Weiße Haus
column21: accessdate=}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' also reported that \"There is no solid proof Trump [nor any other American official] approved the [German] heist\".<ref>{{cite news
column23: title=US's global reputation hits rock-bottom over Trump's coronavirus response

column1: [[Jared Moskowitz]], head of the [[Florida Division of Emergency Management]], accused 3M of selling N95 masks directly to foreign countries for cash instead of the US. Moskowitz stated that 3M agreed to authorized distributors and brokers to represent they were selling the masks to [[Florida]], but instead his team for the last several weeks \"get to warehouses that are completely empty.\" He then said the 3M authorized US distributors later told him the masks Florida contracted for never showed up because the company instead prioritized orders that came in later, for higher prices, from foreign countries (including Germany, Russia, and France). As a result, Moskowitz highlighted the issue on Twitter, saying he decided to “troll” 3M.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Florida emergency management official says 3M selling masks to foreign countries: 'We're chasing ghosts'
column10: title=Interview With Jared Moskowitz, Director of Florida's Division of Emergency Management
column17: title=Florida emergency management chief says state will have enough ICU beds and ventilators
column20: accessdate=5 April 2020}}</ref> ''[[Forbes]]'' reported that \"roughly 280 million masks from warehouses around the US had been purchased by foreign buyers [on March 30, 2020] and were earmarked to leave the country, according to the broker — and that was in ''one'' day\", causing massive critical shortages of masks in the US.<ref>{{Cite news
column24: title=I Spent A Day In The Coronavirus-Driven Feeding Frenzy Of N95 Mask Sellers And Buyers And This Is What I Learned
column28: authors=Natasha Bertrand, Gabby Orr, Daneil Lippman and Nahal Toosi
column30: title=Pence task force freezes coronavirus aid amid backlash

column1: As more and more countries restricted the export of N95 masks, Novo Textiles in [[British Columbia]] had plans to become the number-one manufacturer in [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=COVID-19: Coquitlam company retools, will be first in Canada to produce N95 respirators
column7: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> AMD Medicom in [[Quebec]] also plans to become the second Canadian manufacturer of N95 masks, with a contract to supply the [[Government of Canada]].<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Medicom to begin manufacturing N95 masks in Canada as foreign countries curb exports

column1: == Mask use and policies by country and territory ==

column2: 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic by country and territory
column3: National responses to the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic}}

Austria]]: Everyone entering a [[supermarket]], a grocery store or a drug store must wear a face mask.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-52126735 Coronavirus: Expert panel to assess face mask use by public], BBC News, David Shukman, 1{{nbsp}}April 2020.</ref><ref>{{Cite news
column7: title=Coronavirus: Why you now have to wear a mask in Austrian shops

column2: Bosnia and Herzegovina}} [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Bosnia and Herzegovina
column3: Bosnia and Herzegovina]]: Wearing a face mask is compulsory.<ref name=\"newshub\">{{Cite news
column7: title=Coronavirus: Countries where face masks are mandatory in COVID-19 fight

column2: China}} [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic in mainland China
column3: China]]: Healthy individuals are advised to wear disposable medical masks in public places.<ref name=\"nhc_masks\"/><ref name=\"sci_masks\"/> Some local governments require wearing masks when going outside.

column2: Czech Republic}} [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Czech Republic
column3: Czech Republic]]: Forbidden to go out in public without wearing a mask or covering one's nose and mouth.<ref name=\"czsk\"/>
France]]: On March 3, the government issued a degree announcing [[requisition]] of stocks of FFP2 and anti-splash masks until until May 31, 2020.<ref name=\"frdecree3\">{{cite web
column5: title=Décret n° 2020-190 du 3 mars 2020 relatif aux réquisitions nécessaires dans le cadre de la lutte contre le virus covid-19

column3: Germany]]: On 31 March, [[Jena]] was the first bigger German city to introduce an obligation to wear masks, or makeshift masks including scarves, in supermarkets, public transport, and buildings with public traffic.<ref name=\"de_jena\">{{Cite news
column7: title=German city introduces face masks for shoppers as coronavirus spreads
column10: agency=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> On 2 April, the [[Robert Koch Institute]], the federal epidemic authority, changed its previous recommendation that only people with symptoms should wear masks to also include people without symptoms.<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=Plötzlich ändert das Robert-Koch-Institut seine Einschätzung zum Mundschutz

column2: Hong Kong}} [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Hong Kong
column3: Hong Kong]]: Members of the public are recommended to wear a surgical mask when taking public transport or staying in crowded places.<ref name=\"chp_hk\" />
Indonesia]]: Citizens were ordered to wear face masks when they leave the house.<ref name=\"mal_apr4\"/>
Israel]]: All residents are asked to wear face masks when in public.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Netanyahu tells Israelis to wear masks outside; gives stipends for kids, elderly

column3: Japan]]: Masks have been widely used by healthy individuals despite absence of official advice to do so.<ref name=\"AutoDW-58\" /> On March 1, prime minister [[Shinzo Abe]] enacted a policy in [[Hokkaido]] instructing manufactures to sell facial masks directly to the government, which would then deliver it to residents.<ref>[https://japan.kantei.go.jp/98_abe/actions/202003/_00001.html \"16th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters\"]. Prime Minister of Japan and His Cabinet, 1 March 2020.</ref>

Malaysia]]: Masks have been widely used by healthy individuals despite absence of official advice to do so.<ref name=\"nst561250\" /> On March 17, Malaysia banned exports of medical and surgical masks to meet local demand.<ref name=\"malaysiaban\">{{cite web
column5: title=Minister bans Malaysia from exporting face masks
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> In April, the government was set to distribute 24.62 million masks, four for each household, while advising people to only use them if they have symptoms.<ref name=\"mal_apr4\">{{cite web
column15: title=Malaysia to Give Out Masks to Households as Guidance Shifts

column3: Morocco]]: Wearing a face mask is compulsory.<ref>{{Cite news
column7: title=Morocco makes face masks compulsory due to coronavirus

column3: Panama]]: Panama has made it obligatory to wear a face mask whenever going outside, while also recommending the manufacture of a homemade face mask for those who cannot purchase face masks.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Es 'obligatorio' usar mascarilla si va a salir de casa, según ministra consejera de Salud

column3: Singapore]]: Masks have been widely used by healthy individuals despite absence of official advice to do so.<ref name=\"20200131straitstimes\" />
Slovakia]]: Forbidden to go out in public without wearing a mask or covering one's nose and mouth.<ref name=\"czsk\"/><ref name=\"newshub\" />

column2: South Korea}} [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in South Korea
column3: South Korea]]: Masks have been widely used by healthy individuals despite absence of official advice to do so.<ref name=\"hzpH7\" /> The government implemented a policy of centralized procurement and rationing of face masks, purchasing 80% of national production since early March.<ref name=\"nyt_kor\">{{cite news
column5: title=How South Korea Solved Its Face Mask Shortage

column3: Taiwan]]: On January 21, the government announced a temporary ban on the export of face masks.<ref name=\"BBCTW06Feb2020\">{{cite news
column5: title=Coronavirus: Does China have enough face masks to meet its needs?
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> On 6 February, the government instituted a mask rationing system.<ref name=\"tw_ration\">{{cite news
column16: title=WUHAN VIRUS/Taiwan approves new rationing system for surgical masks
column23: url-status=live }}</ref> Taiwan has been producing ten million masks per day since mid-March.<ref name=\"focus_tw\"/> On April 1, passengers on trains and intercity buses were required to wear face masks,<ref name=\"tw_tran_apr1\"/> unmasked riders facing a fine.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=Virus Outbreak: Fines authorized for unmasked riders

column3: Vietnam]]: On March 16, [[Vietnam]] requested everyone to wear a face mask when going to public areas in order to protect themselves and others.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=All in Vietnam must wear face mask in public places for coronavirus prevention

column3: Ukraine]]: Since April 6, wearing a face mask is required by the government in public places. In [[Kyiv]], public places were clarified to include parks and streets.<ref name=\"bbc_ua_apr6\">{{cite news
column4: title=У масках - скрізь на вулиці, на в'їзді мірятимуть температуру. Нові обмеження в Києві

column2: US}} [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in the United States
column3: United States]]: On April 6, the CDC recommended the wearing of non-medical cloth face coverings when in public places.<ref>{{cite web
column6: website=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column12: title=The CDC released a guide on how to make a face mask without sewing skills. Materials include a bandana, a coffee filter, and hair ties.
