column2: American stand-up comedian, actor, writer, and producer}}

column1: {{Infobox comedian <!-- for individuals - see Template:Infobox comedian for usage -->

column2: image                = Jim Gaffigan making a goofy excited face, Jan 2014, NYC (cropped).jpg

column1: '''James Christopher Gaffigan''' (born July 7, 1966) is an American stand-up comedian, actor, writer and producer. He was raised in [[Chesterton, Indiana]]. His material is often about fatherhood, observations, laziness, and food. He is also regarded as a \"clean\" comic, using little profanity in his routines. He has had several successful comedy specials, including ''[[Jim Gaffigan: Mr. Universe
column2: Mr. Universe]],'' ''Obsessed'', ''Cinco,'' and ''Quality Time'', all of which have received Grammy nominations.

column1: His memoir, ''Dad Is Fat'' (2013) and his most recent book, ''Food: A Love Story'' (2014), are both published by [[Crown Publishers]]. He co-created and starred in a [[TV Land]] television series based on his life called ''[[The Jim Gaffigan Show]]''.
He collaborates extensively with his wife, actress [[Jeannie Gaffigan]],<ref name= NYTwedding>{{cite news
column3: title= WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Jeannie Noth, Jim Gaffigan
column6: work= The New York Times}}</ref> and together they have five children. They are [[Catholic Church in the United States
column7: Catholic]], a topic that comes up in his comedy, and live in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]].

column1: Gaffigan was born on July 7, 1966<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Celeb birthdays for the week of July 7–13
column4: agency= Associated Press}}</ref> in [[Elgin, Illinois]],<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Jim Gaffigan brings 'sexy dad mind' to Northerly Island on Thursday
column9: publisher=}}</ref> the son of Marcia Mitchell and Michael A. Gaffigan.<ref name= NYTwedding /> He grew up in [[Chesterton, Indiana]], the youngest of six children, and often jokes about growing up in a large family.<ref name=spin/> His mother Marcia was a charity worker and fundraiser; she was also accomplished at [[needlework]], for which she received a national award for original design and craftsmanship from the American Needlepoint Guild in 1985.<ref name=NWI>{{Cite news
column11: title=Marcia Mitchell Gaffigan, 53, loses battle with cancer
column15: location=[[Chesterton, Indiana]]}}</ref> She died of cancer in 1990, aged 53.<ref name=NWI/>

column1: His father Michael, a banker, was the president and CEO of the Mercantile National Bank of Indiana for fifteen years until his retirement in 1991.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Mercantile National CEO retires this year
column7: location=[[Hammond, Indiana]]}}</ref> A former [[seminarian]], he was also actively involved in local charity work.<ref name=tribune>{{Cite news
column15: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> He died of [[lung cancer]] in 1999.<ref name=tribune/> Gaffigan's father was the first in his family to attend college<ref name=stern/> and he encouraged his children to seek careers that promised job security.<ref name=steinberg>{{cite news
column25: access-date= July 17, 2016}}</ref> However, at about the age of five, Jim announced that when he grew up, he wanted to be an \"actor.\"<ref name=suewhite>{{cite news
column30: title= Inner voice is the secret of Jim Gaffigan's comedy, coming soon to Mount Pleasant

column1: As a teenager, Gaffigan watched ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref name=stern/>  He attended [[La Lumiere School]] in [[La Porte, Indiana]], where he starred on the school's [[American football
column2: football]] team. He attended [[Purdue University]] for one year, where he was a member of the [[Phi Gamma Delta]] fraternity, then transferred to [[Georgetown University]]'s [[McDonough School of Business]], where he graduated in 1988 with a degree in Finance.<ref name=steinberg/><ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Versatile comic Jim Gaffigan adds 'author' to his resume
column18: title= RT @HisAndHers Throwback to the days @JimGaffigan played college football for @georgetownhoyas
column23: title=Comedian Jim Gaffigan once walked-on to a Big Ten football team
column26: publisher=}}</ref> Although Gaffigan had hated studying finance, he worked as a litigation consultant for a short time after graduating and \"was horrible at it\".<ref name=cbs>{{Cite web
column28: title=Jim Gaffigan: Standing up to fatherhood

column1: Gaffigan moved to New York in 1990 to pursue comedy,<ref name=UTSanD /> a move that was inspired by his admiration for fellow [[Hoosier]] [[David Letterman]].<ref name=bigbreak/> He found a job in advertising,<ref name=steinberg/> and he would work during the day and take acting classes at night.<ref name=spin/><ref name=bigbreak/> His career began in earnest when a friend from the class dared him to take a [[stand-up comedy
column2: stand-up]] seminar that required a live set at the end.<ref name=spin>{{cite web
column11: df= }}</ref><ref name= suewhite/>  He fell in love with stand-up,<ref name=spin/> and began to play comedy clubs nightly—after his evening acting classes—until the wee hours of the morning.<ref name=bigbreak>{{cite news
column14: title= From Adman To Stand-Up: Jim Gaffigan's Transition Took A Few Good Naps
column17: access-date= July 28, 2015}}</ref> He was often found sleeping on the job; his boss had to wake him up to fire him.<ref name=bigbreak/>

column1: For the first seven years of his career, he tried various styles, ranging from angry comedy to impressions and voices. Also, live comedy was in decline following its peak of the 1980s, further affected by the increased popularity of [[cable television]].<ref name=spin/>  After periodically auditioning for ''[[The Late Show with David Letterman]]'' for six years,<ref>{{cite AV media
column15: quote=I had auditioned for Lettermen for, I don’t know, six years}}</ref> he then had a successful stand-up routine on the show, and his career took off.<ref name=bigbreak/>

column2: observational]], and his principal topics relate to laziness, eating, and parenthood.  He is famous for his [[Hot Pocket]] routine, which was inspired by a commercial he saw that he mistook for a ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' sketch.<ref name=suewhite/>  Also, during his routines, he will sometimes perform [[soliloquy
column3: soliloquies]] by using a high-pitched voice and—in the third-person—deliver negative feedback on his own performance, such as after making a diarrhea joke in his 2012 special \"Mr. Universe\" using the voice and saying \"Really, he’s using diarrhea jokes?\"<ref name=stevens/> He says \"that inside voice is my connection with the audience\".<ref name=suewhite/>

column1: In an interview with the ''[[Duluth News-Tribune]]'', he explained that the voice was developed over time, beginning as a teenager when he would disarm people by talking for them in their presence.<ref name=bellamy/>  He also used it as a way to fend off hecklers earlier in his career, when he says that comedy clubs were more combative.<ref name=bellamy/> He cursed early in his career, and he added cursing to his comedy album ''Doing My Time'', at the request of his label, in the hopes of drawing more teenagers.<ref name=Schmidt>{{cite news
column6: title= The 10 Trials of Jim Gaffigan
column9: access-date=July 29, 2015}}</ref> However, he has largely removed profanity from his routine, as he feels that his subject matter doesn't lend itself to cursing and that it reduced the effort he put into crafting his jokes.<ref name=Schmidt/><ref>{{cite news
column13: title= Jim Gaffigan returns to his old stomping grounds, Purdue

column1: In 2004, Gaffigan's stand up material was featured in [[Comedy Central]]'s animated series ''Shorties Watchin' Shortie.'' October 2005, he filmed a live [[Comedy Central]] special that aired for the following January,<ref name=spin/> and became the comedy album/DVD ''[[Beyond the Pale (Jim Gaffigan album)
column2: Beyond the Pale]]''.  The routine consisted primarily of material regarding food and American eating habits, and the comedian unknowingly predicted a future menu item at [[Dunkin Donuts]]—the 'glazed donut breakfast sandwich'—while commenting on the future of America's eating habits.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Jim Gaffigan Predicted The Dunkin' Donuts Donut Sandwich
column9: last=McGlynn}}</ref> His 2009 album ''[[King Baby (Jim Gaffigan album)
column10: King Baby]]'' was also a television special filmed in [[Austin, Texas
column11: Austin]], [[Texas]], at the end of his \"The Sexy Tour\". Comedy Central released ''King Baby'' on DVD. In a March 2009 interview on ''[[Anytime with Bob Kushell]]'', Gaffigan defended his naming of the tour, stating that he thought it would be funny that parents would be unsure about whether to bring their teenage children to the show.<ref>{{cite episode
column12: title = Anytime with Bob Kushell feat. Jim Gaffigan
column16: number = 2}}</ref> Four years later, on March 14, 2013, Gaffigan was named the \"King of Clean\" by the ''Wall Street Journal''.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title= Jim Gaffigan Is the King of (Clean) Comedy

column1: On February 25, 2012, Gaffigan taped a one-hour stand-up special—''[[Jim Gaffigan: Mr. Universe
column8: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref> it was nominated for a Grammy.<ref name=steinberg/> He announced that, based on the business model used by [[Louis C.K.]]'s ''[[Live at the Beacon Theater]]'', the stand-up would be available online through his website for $5, with 20% of the total proceeds going to the [[Bob Woodruff
column13: title=Louis C.K. inspires Jim Gaffigan to distribute own special
column16: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref> an organization that provides support to military veterans.<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=Comedian Jim Gaffigan Supports Veterans Through Woodruff Foundation
column26: title=Randi Kaye speaks to comedian, Jim Gaffigan, who's supporting veterans' foundation with $5 stand-up special.
column30: access-date=January 29, 2015 }}</ref>  In 2012, he was among the top-ten grossing comics in the US, according to Pollstar.<ref name=steinberg/>

column1: Gaffigan filmed his 2014 comedy special titled ''[[Jim Gaffigan: Obsessed]]'' at [[Boston]]'s [[Wilbur Theater]] on January 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Comedy Central to premiere new standup special Jim Gaffigan: Obsessed, 4/27
column5: accessdate= May 12, 2014}}</ref> ''Obsessed'' premiered on [[Comedy Central]] on April 27 becoming the most watched stand-up comedy special of the year for the network.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title= Jim Gaffigan Obsessed is Comedy Centrals Most Watched Standup Special Since April 2013
column9: accessdate= May 12, 2014}}</ref> The accompanying album, also titled ''Obsessed'', debuted at number 11 on the [[Billboard 200
column10: ''Billboard'' 200]] and number 1 on the Billboard Comedy Album charts.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Chart Moves: Grateful Dead Notch Highest-Charting Album Since 1987, Jim Gaffigan's Stand-Up Sales Sizzle
column14: accessdate= May 12, 2014}}</ref> 2015 saw him embark on a headlining tour, culminating in a winter show at [[Madison Square Garden]].<ref name=stern/>

column1: Gaffigan has performed stand-up to support charitable causes as well. In 2002, he was part of a [[United Service Organization]] event at [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=GTMO Troops Get Comic Relief Courtesy Of 'Comedy Central'
column8: accessdate=January 29, 2015}}</ref> Gaffigan performed at the 2013 Stand Up for Heroes charity event benefitting the Bob Woodruff Foundation alongside fellow stand-up comedians [[Jerry Seinfeld]], [[Bill Cosby]] and [[Jon Stewart]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Stand Up for Heroes 2013 Raises a Record Breaking 5 Million
column14: title=Springsteen, Waters, comics honor veterans at benefit
column18: access-date=January 29, 2015 }}</ref>  Gaffigan also performed at the 2013 [[CNN Heroes]] event, which celebrates everyday heroes doing extraordinary work around the world.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Celebrity Lineup Announced for 2013 CNN Heroes All Star Tribute
column22: accessdate=May 13, 2014}}</ref>  In May 2014, Gaffigan performed at the [[Make It Right Foundation
column23: Make It Right]] Gala, an organization founded by [[Brad Pitt]], which builds sustainable homes and buildings for communities in need.<ref>{{cite web
column25: title= Inside Brad Pitt's Star-Studded Party in New Orleans
column28: accessdate=June 25, 2014}}</ref> On September 26, 2015, he performed at the Festival of Families, a Catholic event held in [[Philadelphia]]. Gaffigan was the only comedian on the bill at the festival, and the event was visited by [[Pope Francis]]. The event had more than one million attendees.

column1: As of June 2016, Gaffigan was the most popular comic on all of [[Pandora.com]] with over 647 million spins.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Guess Who Is the Most Played Comedian On Pandora

column1: In 2016, Gaffigan embarked on his [[Fully Dressed Tour]], performing in the United States, Canada, and the UK.
Gaffigan has appeared at the \"[[Just for Laughs]]\" comedy festival in [[Montreal

Gaffigan credits [[David Letterman]] and [[Bill Murray]] as influences, and he has asserted that [[Richard Pryor]] was the greatest stand-up comedian ever.<ref name=stern/> His comedy mentor was [[Dave Attell]], who he asserted was the only person who thought he was funny in his early stand-up years.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Stand-Up Guy Jim Gaffigan on His New TV Land Show (INTERVIEW)

column1: On the episode of ''[[Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee]]'' which featured Gaffigan, he admitted that the show's host [[Jerry Seinfeld]] was a big influence for him.

Gaffigan is widely noted for being an [[everyman]] and a clean comic,<ref name=steinberg/><ref name=bellamy2/> and signature routines regard [[Hot Pockets]],<ref name=wait/><ref name=bellamy2>{{cite news
column2: title=Everyone's in on the joke at Gaffigan show
column11: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> cake, and [[bacon]].<ref name=stevens/>  His tendency to avoid profanity has drawn mixed responses from audiences and critics.  One critic compared him to ''Full House''-era [[Bob Saget]] (who starred in the 1990s family show), which Gaffigan took as an insult.<ref name=Schmidt/>  However, Hampton Stevens in ''[[The Atlantic]]'' wrote that the comic champions \"a vital element to standup that [[Lenny Bruce
column12: [Lenny] Bruce]] had taken away—the indispensable, but apparently forgotten idea that comedians have no obligation to be provocative, topical, socially conscious, or anything else but funny.\"<ref name=stevens>>{{cite web
column15: title=The Radical Averageness of Jim Gaffigan's Stand-Up lo

column4: quote=I did my set, I walked off stage and they said the executive producer wants to meet you up in his office. I thought maybe it was going to be something good. I thought maybe Dave wants me to be a writer. But they wanted me to develop my own ''show''.

column1: As Gaffigan's comedy career stalled in the 1990s, a friend suggested he audition for commercials, a move which turned out to be profitable.<ref name=spin/> He has appeared in over 200 TV commercials,<ref name=Schmidt/> ranging from [[Rolling Rock]] to [[Saturn Corporation
column2: Saturn]] to [[Chrysler]] and [[ESPN]]. His ubiquity earned him the title of 'Salesman of the Year' by ''[[BusinessWeek]]'' in 1999.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate= January 30, 2014}}</ref> He also performed in a trio of Sierra Mist commercials for the [[Super Bowl XLI
column7: 2007 Super Bowl]] as part of the Sierra Mist comedy ensemble \"The Mis-Takes\".<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Sierra Mist Takes Karate Combover to Hospital
column14: title=Sierra Mist's Ensemble Cast is at it Again for Super Bowl 2007
column21: df= }}</ref>  He appeared in an ad series for [[Sierra Mist]] alongside fellow comedian [[Michael Ian Black]].<ref>{{cite magazine
column25: title=The Best & Worst Super Bowl Commercials 2007: Sierra Mist Free

column1: After his first appearance on ''[[The Late Show with David Letterman]]'' in 1999, Gaffigan was tapped by the host to develop a sitcom called ''[[Welcome to New York (TV series)
column2: Welcome to New York]]'' in which he also co-starred alongside [[Christine Baranski]].<ref name=stern/> The show was cancelled after its first season despite receiving positive reviews.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Meet Jim Gaffigan. No, Seriously. Stay After the Show and Meet Him
column9: last=Steinberg}}</ref> During the 2000/2001 television season, he was a cast member of ''[[The Ellen Show]]'' on CBS, [[Ellen DeGeneres]]' second sitcom. He appeared in two movies chosen for the 2001 [[Sundance Film Festival]]: ''[[Super Troopers]]'' and ''[[30 Years to Life]]''. He appeared on ''[[That '70s Show]]''. He was a regular cast member of the [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)
column10: TBS]] original sitcom ''[[My Boys]]''. He left the show at the end of the third season.{{citation needed

column1: In 2008, he appeared in the movie ''[[The Love Guru]]'' starring [[Mike Myers]].<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Why 'The Love Guru' can't possibly suck

column1: In 2009, Gaffigan guest starred as the best friend of [[Murray Hewitt]] in one episode of the [[HBO]] comedy series ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)
column2: Flight of the Conchords]]''. Later that same year, he appeared in the [[Sam Mendes]]-directed [[comedy-drama
column4: Away We Go]]'' and the teen comedy ''[[17 Again (film)
column5: 17 Again]]''. On June 11, 2009, Gaffigan appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]''. He appeared on ''Law & Order'' episodes \"Flight\" and \"Reality Bites\", as well as an episode titled \"Smile\" on ''Law and Order: Criminal Intent''.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=TV Land picks up Jim Gaffigan's CBS sitcom pilot

column1: He was in an episode of ''[[The Daily Show]]'' as a man posing as a ''Daily Show'' correspondent who knows nothing about the show (he refers to it as \"The John Daily Show\") and simply wants to be seen with Jon Stewart. This was meant to be a parody of the [[2009 White House gatecrash incident]].{{citation needed
Gaffigan appeared on Broadway in ''[[That Championship Season]]'', which opened in March 2011, opposite [[Brian Cox (actor)
column2: Brian Cox]], [[Chris Noth]], [[Kiefer Sutherland]], and [[Jason Patric]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Cox, Gaffigan, Noth, Patric & Sutherland to Star in THE CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON
column7: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref> Gaffigan's performance was praised by [[ABC News]] correspondent Sandy Kenyon as the most moving and that he may \"steal the show\".<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Sandy talks to the cast of 'That Championship Season'
column12: accessdate=January 28, 2014}}</ref>  He called being on Broadway \"an amazing experience, really hard but really fun.\"<ref name=suewhite/>

column1: Gaffigan starred in [[Shia LaBeouf]]'s 2013 short film ''[[Howard Cantour.com]]'', the content of which was later revealed to be mostly plagiarized from Daniel Clowes' 2007 graphic novella ''[[Justin M. Damiano]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Hot Short Film: Shia LaBeouf Takes On Film Critics In 'HowardCantour.com'
column6: accessdate= December 16, 2013}}</ref>  Reflecting on the incident in an interview for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', Gaffigan said, \"There's no greater sin in the stand-up world than thievery...So you do not want to be associated with thievery,\" but added, \"I don't have any hard feelings about it because I don't think people think I had anything to do with it.\"<ref name=stern>Stern, Marlow (July 15, 2015), [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/07/15/jim-gaffigan-s-time-is-now-the-comic-on-his-new-show-bill-cosby-s-fall-and-donald-trump.html \"Jim Gaffigan's Time Is Now: The Comic on His New Show, Bill Cosby's Fall, and Donald Trump\"]. ''The Daily Beast''. Retrieved July 28, 2015.</ref>

column1: In the 2010s, Gaffigan, his wife, and [[Peter Tolan]] began to develop material for a show based loosely on their own life.  CBS agreed to shoot a pilot of their show in March 2013, with casting by Marc Hirschfeld,<ref>{{cite news
column9: page=10}}</ref> and [[Mira Sorvino]] playing his wife;<ref name=steinberg/> but ultimately passed on the project.<ref name=katz>{{cite news
column16: access-date= September 26, 2019}}</ref> When the cable network [[TV Land]] began efforts to broadcast original material and attract younger audiences, it offered the Gaffigans complete creative control.  The result was ''[[The Jim Gaffigan Show]]'', a sitcom about a couple raising their five kids in a two-bedroom New York City apartment.  After the release of two online-only episodes in June 2015, the [[television pilot
column17: pilot episode]] aired on July 15, 2015.  The show stars Gaffigan as a fictionalized version of himself,<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=TV Land releases extended scene from new comedy \"Younger\" featuring Sutton Foster and Hilary Duff
column26: df= }}</ref> with his wife Jeannie played by Ashley Williams. Other characters include their real-estate agent (and Jeannie's best friend) Daniel (played by [[Michael Ian Black]]), Jim's fellow comic and best friend Dave ([[Adam Goldberg]]), and their priest, Father Nicholas ([[Tongayi Chirisa]]). After 2 seasons of the show, in 2016 Jim and his wife Jeannie decided not to continue with a third season so they could spend more time with their kids.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=TV Land cancels 'The Jim Gaffigan Show'

column2: Experimenter]]'', a fictionalized account of the experiments of the Yale professor [[Dr. Stanley Milgram]].<ref name=hughes>Hughes, William (July 24, 2015), [http://www.avclub.com/article/jim-gaffigan-fakes-electrocution-trailer-experimen-222862 \"Jim Gaffigan fakes electrocution in the trailer for Experimenter\"]. The AV Club. Retrieved July 28, 2015.</ref>  Gaffigan plays an actor hired to collaborate in the experiments.<ref name=hughes/>

column1: In February 2016, Gaffigan began appearing in [[KFC]] commercials as [[Colonel Sanders]],<ref name=KFC>{{cite news
column6: title= KFC just revealed the newest star of its polarizing Colonel Sanders ads

column1: Since April 8, 2016, Gaffigan has appeared with his family in a marketing campaign for the [[Chrysler Pacifica (RU)
column4: title=Jim Gaffigan stars in Chrysler brand's 'Dad Brand' marketing campaign for the all-new 2017 Chrysler Pacifica

column1: In October 2016, it was announced Gaffigan would be joining the cast of the third season of the [[anthology series
column6: title='Fargo' Adds Jim Gaffigan to Season 3 Cast
column8: accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref> However, he was ultimately forced to drop out due to scheduling difficulties; he was replaced by [[Mark Forward]]. In 2018, he portrayed [[Paul F. Markham
column9: Paul Markham]] in the biographical drama ''[[Chappaquiddick (film)
column10: Chappaquiddick]]'', starring [[Jason Clarke]] and [[Kate Mara]], to positive reviews.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Kennedy clan and comedian Jim Gaffigan drive ‘Chappaquiddick’
column17: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> Gaffigan next took on the lead role in the 2018 [[neo-noir]] film ''[[American Dreamer (2018 film)
column18: American Dreamer]]'', which was released on September 20, 2019. Gaffigan's dark portrayal of a broken man driven to desperate actions was very well received by critics,<ref>{{Citation
column23: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> with the [[Chicago Sun-Times]] review calling it \"a career-best dramatic performance\" by Gaffigan.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=‘American Dreamer’: The best proof yet that, as a dramatic actor, Jim Gaffigan is ready for his closeup
column33: title=Jim Gaffigan goes dark in his new movie, but the darkness was already there

column1: Gaffigan is also notable for his [[voice-over]] work. He voiced an animated version of himself on ''[[Pale Force]]'' with [[Conan O'Brien]] from 2005 to 2008. He has also voiced characters on the animated shows ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'', ''[[Shorty McShorts' Shorts]]'', ''[[WordGirl]]'', ''[[Star vs. the Forces of Evil]]'', and the animated feature ''[[Duck Duck Goose (film)

column2: alt=Gaffigan standing next to a car reading \"JIM GAFFIGAN / FOR PRESIDENT\"

column1: Gaffigan produced a series of animated shorts for ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', titled ''[[Pale Force]]'' (2005–2008).  The animated sketches featured Gaffigan and O'Brien as superheroes who fight crime with their extremely pale skin.<ref name=stevens/> The series was nominated for a Daytime Emmy in 2007 in the category of \"Outstanding Broadband Program – Comedy\".<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Nominees for the Emmy Award For Broadband Announced; Winners to be Named June 14

column1: Gaffigan's humorous quips have earned him over two and a half million followers on [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=January 23, 2014}}</ref> He was listed by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as one of the \"25 funniest people on Twitter\" in 2012.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title= The 25 Funniest People on Twitter

column1: In 2013, Gaffigan released ''Dad Is Fat'', a title derived from the first complete sentence his eldest son wrote on a dry-erase board at the age of four or five.  \"He showed it to me,\" Gaffigan recalled in an interview, \"and I laughed, and then I put him up for adoption.\"<ref name=wait/>  The book is a collection of essays dealing with the raising of his children, as well as reminiscences from his own childhood.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Jim Gaffigan's \"Dad Is Fat\" is packed with dark parental humor
column8: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref>  In support of the volume, he appeared on NPR's ''[[Weekend Edition]]'', ABC's ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)
column9: The View]]'', and MSNBC's ''Morning Joe'', spoke at BEA in New York, embarked on a nine-stop bus tour that ended on Father's Day.<ref>{{cite news

column1: It debuted at number five on ''[[The New York Times]]'' Best Seller's list, remaining on the list for three months.<ref>{{cite news
column15: last=Cowles}}</ref> The book received tepid reviews from critics.  ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' said of the book that it's \"hardly groundbreaking comedy material, but the book will appeal to Gaffigan's fans.\"<ref>(April 15, 2013), \"DAD IS FAT\". ''Kirkus Reviews''. '''81''' (8):50</ref> Lou Harry of the Indianapolis Business Journal said that while \"no new ground is broken in Jim Gaffigan's book...'Dad is Fat' should be a fun [[intermezzo]] in your summer reading pile.\"<ref>Harry, Lou (May 27, 2013), \"Notes on parenting from a funnyman father.\" ''Indianapolis Business Journal''. ''34'' (13):3</ref>  Regarding the audiobook, which Gaffigan read, ''Audiofile'' said his \"performance strikes the right balance between his near-deadpan comedy delivery and the energy needed to keep a beleaguered parent engaged.\"<ref>(October/November 2013), [http://www.audiofilemagazine.com/reviews/read/80864/ \"DAD IS FAT\"]. ''AudioFile''. '''22''' (3):51</ref>

column1: Gaffigan signed with [[Crown Publishing]] in June 2013 to write a second book of comic essays. The book, ''[[Food: A Love Story]]'', which was released in Fall 2014.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Jim Gaffigan to Publish Second Book of Essays
column10: title=Jim Gaffigan Signs a Deal to Write a Second Book
column24: language=English}}</ref> ''Publisher's Weekly'' said the book \"packs plenty of laughs.\"<ref>{{cite news
column32: page=19}}</ref>  ''Kirkus Reviews'' remarked that \"Gaffigan somehow manages to work 'clean' without ever becoming sickeningly [[saccharine]],\" and that 'laughs [are] served up just right on every page.\"<ref>{{cite news
column38: page= 1}}</ref>  Of the accompanying audiobook, the ''Library Journal'' said, \"The witty commentary is peppered with jokes and funny stories that will have listeners smiling throughout and occasionally laughing out loud.\"<ref>{{cite news

column1: Prior to meeting his wife, actress Jeannie Noth, Gaffigan largely wrote alone.  However, while working on his first show, ''Welcome to New York'', he was overwhelmed and asked for input from her (then his friend). Although initially hesitant to have a collaborator, as their relationship grew, so did Noth's ability to write material for him.  Once they married, she left behind her work with her youth theater project (Shakespeare on the Playground) to devote herself to raising their expanding brood, and after a joke she wrote drew big laughs at a show, she and Jim began to collaborate more.{{citation needed
column2: date=July 2015}}  She gradually transferred into the position of Jim's chief co-writer, and they are now full writing partners.  She has been a credited writer and/or executive producer on all his comedy endeavors since ''Beyond the Pale'', including his two books and television show.<ref name=katz/>  He also credits her with \"coaching\" him through his performance in ''That Championship Season''.<ref name=suewhite/>

column1: Gaffigan participated on the [[NPR]] radio quiz program ''[[Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me!]]'' in 2013.<ref name=wait>(July 26, 2013), [https://www.npr.org/2013/07/27/205793645/not-my-job-jim-gaffigan-takes-a-quiz-on-gwyneth-paltrow \"Not My Job: Jim Gaffigan Take a Quiz on Gwyneth Paltrow\"]. ''Wait Wait...Don't Tell Me!'' [[National Public Radio
column2: NPR]]. Retrieved July 28, 2015.</ref> Gaffigan is also a regular commentator on ''[[CBS Sunday Morning]]'', for which he won a Daytime Emmy in 2016.

column1: Gaffigan is married to actress [[Jeannie Gaffigan]] (née Noth),<ref name=steinberg/> with whom he has five children: daughters Marre (born 2005) and Katie Louise (born 2009) and sons Jack (born 2006), Michael (born 2011), and Patrick (born 2012). The family of seven famously lived in a two-bedroom apartment in [[New York City]],<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Fat' Dad Jim Gaffigan On Kids, Comedy And Apartment Living
column6: accessdate=January 6, 2014}}</ref> before moving to a larger home in 2015. To stay connected to his family, Gaffigan tries to \"maintain bedtime rituals while working in the city\";<ref name=\"bellamy\">{{cite news
column7: title=Funny story: Jim Gaffigan talks tour, life
column17: url-status=dead}}</ref> when on tour, he reportedly takes his family with him. Gaffigan has stated that he avoids working on Sundays.<ref name=bellamy/>

column1: Gaffigan has stated, on stage and elsewhere, that he is a practicing Catholic (although he jokes that his wife is a \"Shiite Catholic\" compared to him).<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Comedian Jim Gaffigan Takes Sundays Off From Stand-Up
column9: title=Is comic Jim Gaffigan the Catholic Church's newest evangelizer?
column15: title=Jim Gaffigan's deadpan humor to heat up Western Michigan University's Miller Auditorium
column18: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref>  He and his family attend [[Mass in the Catholic Church
column19: Mass]] at the [[St. Patrick's Old Cathedral
column20: Basilica of St. Patrick's Old Cathedral]] in Manhattan, where Gaffigan and his wife Jeannie were married in 2003 and where their children were baptized.<ref>LaPlante, Joseph R. (July 5, 2015), \"Comedy ties faith, family\". ''[[Our Sunday Visitor]]''. '''104''' (10):8</ref><ref>{{Cite news
column29: title=Family Is at the Heart of Comedian Jim Gaffigan
column34: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> In May 2016, the Gaffigans delivered the [[commencement address]] at the [[Catholic University of America]].<ref>{{Cite web
column41: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> The Gaffigans also delivered the commencement address at Jeannie's [[alma mater]] [[Marquette University]] on 20 May 2018. They were both awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Humane Letters]] degree as part of the graduation ceremony.<ref>{{Cite web
column43: title=Jeannie and Jim Gaffigan to serve as Marquette's spring Commencement speakers

column1: In April 2017, Jeannie was diagnosed with a benign brain tumor known as [[Choroid plexus papilloma
column2: papilloma of the choroid plexus]], which was successfully removed in a nine-hour operation performed by surgeon [[Joshua B. Bederson]].<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Jim Gaffigan's Wife, Jeannie, Recovering From Life-Threatening Brain Tumor
column13: title=Jim Gaffigan's Wife Jeannie on Discovering She Had a Brain Tumor the Size of an Apple: 'I Was a Ticking Time Bomb'

column2: ''Shoot First and Pray You Live (Because Luck Has Nothing to Do with It)''

column3: It's Kind of a Funny Story]]''

column2: Episode: \"How Florrie Got Her Groove Back\"
Episode: \"Murray Takes It to the Next Level\"

column1: On April 26, 2014, Gaffigan received the award for Concert Comedian at the [[American Comedy Awards]] for his work.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Winners of the 2014 American Comedy Awards

column1: In 2007, \"Pale Force\" was nominated for a Daytime Emmy for Outstanding Broadband Program in the Comedy category. Gaffigan served as executive producer, writer, and lead actor.
In 2016, he won the [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Morning Program]] for his contributions as a commentator to ''CBS Sunday Morning''.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences Announces Winners For The 43rd Annual Daytime Emmy Awards
column4: publisher=The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences

column1: The [[Grammy Award]]s are awarded annually by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]]. Gaffigan has been nominated four times.

column4: title=Weird Al, Sarah Silverman, Patton Oswalt, Jim Gaffigan Are All Grammy Nominees

column2: American stand-up comedian, actor, writer, and producer}}

column1: {{Infobox comedian <!-- for individuals - see Template:Infobox comedian for usage -->

column2: image                = Jim Gaffigan making a goofy excited face, Jan 2014, NYC (cropped).jpg

column1: '''James Christopher Gaffigan''' (born July 7, 1966) is an American stand-up comedian, actor, writer and producer. He was raised in [[Chesterton, Indiana]]. His material is often about fatherhood, observations, laziness, and food. He is also regarded as a \"clean\" comic, using little profanity in his routines. He has had several successful comedy specials, including ''[[Jim Gaffigan: Mr. Universe
column2: Mr. Universe]],'' ''Obsessed'', ''Cinco,'' and ''Quality Time'', all of which have received Grammy nominations.

column1: His memoir, ''Dad Is Fat'' (2013) and his most recent book, ''Food: A Love Story'' (2014), are both published by [[Crown Publishers]]. He co-created and starred in a [[TV Land]] television series based on his life called ''[[The Jim Gaffigan Show]]''.
He collaborates extensively with his wife, actress [[Jeannie Gaffigan]],<ref name= NYTwedding>{{cite news
column3: title= WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Jeannie Noth, Jim Gaffigan
column6: work= The New York Times}}</ref> and together they have five children. They are [[Catholic Church in the United States
column7: Catholic]], a topic that comes up in his comedy, and live in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]].

column1: Gaffigan was born on July 7, 1966<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Celeb birthdays for the week of July 7–13
column4: agency= Associated Press}}</ref> in [[Elgin, Illinois]],<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Jim Gaffigan brings 'sexy dad mind' to Northerly Island on Thursday
column9: publisher=}}</ref> the son of Marcia Mitchell and Michael A. Gaffigan.<ref name= NYTwedding /> He grew up in [[Chesterton, Indiana]], the youngest of six children, and often jokes about growing up in a large family.<ref name=spin/> His mother Marcia was a charity worker and fundraiser; she was also accomplished at [[needlework]], for which she received a national award for original design and craftsmanship from the American Needlepoint Guild in 1985.<ref name=NWI>{{Cite news
column11: title=Marcia Mitchell Gaffigan, 53, loses battle with cancer
column15: location=[[Chesterton, Indiana]]}}</ref> She died of cancer in 1990, aged 53.<ref name=NWI/>

column1: His father Michael, a banker, was the president and CEO of the Mercantile National Bank of Indiana for fifteen years until his retirement in 1991.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Mercantile National CEO retires this year
column7: location=[[Hammond, Indiana]]}}</ref> A former [[seminarian]], he was also actively involved in local charity work.<ref name=tribune>{{Cite news
column15: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> He died of [[lung cancer]] in 1999.<ref name=tribune/> Gaffigan's father was the first in his family to attend college<ref name=stern/> and he encouraged his children to seek careers that promised job security.<ref name=steinberg>{{cite news
column25: access-date= July 17, 2016}}</ref> However, at about the age of five, Jim announced that when he grew up, he wanted to be an \"actor.\"<ref name=suewhite>{{cite news
column30: title= Inner voice is the secret of Jim Gaffigan's comedy, coming soon to Mount Pleasant

column1: As a teenager, Gaffigan watched ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref name=stern/>  He attended [[La Lumiere School]] in [[La Porte, Indiana]], where he starred on the school's [[American football
column2: football]] team. He attended [[Purdue University]] for one year, where he was a member of the [[Phi Gamma Delta]] fraternity, then transferred to [[Georgetown University]]'s [[McDonough School of Business]], where he graduated in 1988 with a degree in Finance.<ref name=steinberg/><ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Versatile comic Jim Gaffigan adds 'author' to his resume
column18: title= RT @HisAndHers Throwback to the days @JimGaffigan played college football for @georgetownhoyas
column23: title=Comedian Jim Gaffigan once walked-on to a Big Ten football team
column26: publisher=}}</ref> Although Gaffigan had hated studying finance, he worked as a litigation consultant for a short time after graduating and \"was horrible at it\".<ref name=cbs>{{Cite web
column28: title=Jim Gaffigan: Standing up to fatherhood

column1: Gaffigan moved to New York in 1990 to pursue comedy,<ref name=UTSanD /> a move that was inspired by his admiration for fellow [[Hoosier]] [[David Letterman]].<ref name=bigbreak/> He found a job in advertising,<ref name=steinberg/> and he would work during the day and take acting classes at night.<ref name=spin/><ref name=bigbreak/> His career began in earnest when a friend from the class dared him to take a [[stand-up comedy
column2: stand-up]] seminar that required a live set at the end.<ref name=spin>{{cite web
column11: df= }}</ref><ref name= suewhite/>  He fell in love with stand-up,<ref name=spin/> and began to play comedy clubs nightly—after his evening acting classes—until the wee hours of the morning.<ref name=bigbreak>{{cite news
column14: title= From Adman To Stand-Up: Jim Gaffigan's Transition Took A Few Good Naps
column17: access-date= July 28, 2015}}</ref> He was often found sleeping on the job; his boss had to wake him up to fire him.<ref name=bigbreak/>

column1: For the first seven years of his career, he tried various styles, ranging from angry comedy to impressions and voices. Also, live comedy was in decline following its peak of the 1980s, further affected by the increased popularity of [[cable television]].<ref name=spin/>  After periodically auditioning for ''[[The Late Show with David Letterman]]'' for six years,<ref>{{cite AV media
column15: quote=I had auditioned for Lettermen for, I don’t know, six years}}</ref> he then had a successful stand-up routine on the show, and his career took off.<ref name=bigbreak/>

column2: observational]], and his principal topics relate to laziness, eating, and parenthood.  He is famous for his [[Hot Pocket]] routine, which was inspired by a commercial he saw that he mistook for a ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' sketch.<ref name=suewhite/>  Also, during his routines, he will sometimes perform [[soliloquy
column3: soliloquies]] by using a high-pitched voice and—in the third-person—deliver negative feedback on his own performance, such as after making a diarrhea joke in his 2012 special \"Mr. Universe\" using the voice and saying \"Really, he’s using diarrhea jokes?\"<ref name=stevens/> He says \"that inside voice is my connection with the audience\".<ref name=suewhite/>

column1: In an interview with the ''[[Duluth News-Tribune]]'', he explained that the voice was developed over time, beginning as a teenager when he would disarm people by talking for them in their presence.<ref name=bellamy/>  He also used it as a way to fend off hecklers earlier in his career, when he says that comedy clubs were more combative.<ref name=bellamy/> He cursed early in his career, and he added cursing to his comedy album ''Doing My Time'', at the request of his label, in the hopes of drawing more teenagers.<ref name=Schmidt>{{cite news
column6: title= The 10 Trials of Jim Gaffigan
column9: access-date=July 29, 2015}}</ref> However, he has largely removed profanity from his routine, as he feels that his subject matter doesn't lend itself to cursing and that it reduced the effort he put into crafting his jokes.<ref name=Schmidt/><ref>{{cite news
column13: title= Jim Gaffigan returns to his old stomping grounds, Purdue

column1: In 2004, Gaffigan's stand up material was featured in [[Comedy Central]]'s animated series ''Shorties Watchin' Shortie.'' October 2005, he filmed a live [[Comedy Central]] special that aired for the following January,<ref name=spin/> and became the comedy album/DVD ''[[Beyond the Pale (Jim Gaffigan album)
column2: Beyond the Pale]]''.  The routine consisted primarily of material regarding food and American eating habits, and the comedian unknowingly predicted a future menu item at [[Dunkin Donuts]]—the 'glazed donut breakfast sandwich'—while commenting on the future of America's eating habits.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Jim Gaffigan Predicted The Dunkin' Donuts Donut Sandwich
column9: last=McGlynn}}</ref> His 2009 album ''[[King Baby (Jim Gaffigan album)
column10: King Baby]]'' was also a television special filmed in [[Austin, Texas
column11: Austin]], [[Texas]], at the end of his \"The Sexy Tour\". Comedy Central released ''King Baby'' on DVD. In a March 2009 interview on ''[[Anytime with Bob Kushell]]'', Gaffigan defended his naming of the tour, stating that he thought it would be funny that parents would be unsure about whether to bring their teenage children to the show.<ref>{{cite episode
column12: title = Anytime with Bob Kushell feat. Jim Gaffigan
column16: number = 2}}</ref> Four years later, on March 14, 2013, Gaffigan was named the \"King of Clean\" by the ''Wall Street Journal''.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title= Jim Gaffigan Is the King of (Clean) Comedy

column1: On February 25, 2012, Gaffigan taped a one-hour stand-up special—''[[Jim Gaffigan: Mr. Universe
column8: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref> it was nominated for a Grammy.<ref name=steinberg/> He announced that, based on the business model used by [[Louis C.K.]]'s ''[[Live at the Beacon Theater]]'', the stand-up would be available online through his website for $5, with 20% of the total proceeds going to the [[Bob Woodruff
column13: title=Louis C.K. inspires Jim Gaffigan to distribute own special
column16: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref> an organization that provides support to military veterans.<ref>{{cite news
column19: title=Comedian Jim Gaffigan Supports Veterans Through Woodruff Foundation
column26: title=Randi Kaye speaks to comedian, Jim Gaffigan, who's supporting veterans' foundation with $5 stand-up special.
column30: access-date=January 29, 2015 }}</ref>  In 2012, he was among the top-ten grossing comics in the US, according to Pollstar.<ref name=steinberg/>

column1: Gaffigan filmed his 2014 comedy special titled ''[[Jim Gaffigan: Obsessed]]'' at [[Boston]]'s [[Wilbur Theater]] on January 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title= Comedy Central to premiere new standup special Jim Gaffigan: Obsessed, 4/27
column5: accessdate= May 12, 2014}}</ref> ''Obsessed'' premiered on [[Comedy Central]] on April 27 becoming the most watched stand-up comedy special of the year for the network.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title= Jim Gaffigan Obsessed is Comedy Centrals Most Watched Standup Special Since April 2013
column9: accessdate= May 12, 2014}}</ref> The accompanying album, also titled ''Obsessed'', debuted at number 11 on the [[Billboard 200
column10: ''Billboard'' 200]] and number 1 on the Billboard Comedy Album charts.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Chart Moves: Grateful Dead Notch Highest-Charting Album Since 1987, Jim Gaffigan's Stand-Up Sales Sizzle
column14: accessdate= May 12, 2014}}</ref> 2015 saw him embark on a headlining tour, culminating in a winter show at [[Madison Square Garden]].<ref name=stern/>

column1: Gaffigan has performed stand-up to support charitable causes as well. In 2002, he was part of a [[United Service Organization]] event at [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=GTMO Troops Get Comic Relief Courtesy Of 'Comedy Central'
column8: accessdate=January 29, 2015}}</ref> Gaffigan performed at the 2013 Stand Up for Heroes charity event benefitting the Bob Woodruff Foundation alongside fellow stand-up comedians [[Jerry Seinfeld]], [[Bill Cosby]] and [[Jon Stewart]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Stand Up for Heroes 2013 Raises a Record Breaking 5 Million
column14: title=Springsteen, Waters, comics honor veterans at benefit
column18: access-date=January 29, 2015 }}</ref>  Gaffigan also performed at the 2013 [[CNN Heroes]] event, which celebrates everyday heroes doing extraordinary work around the world.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Celebrity Lineup Announced for 2013 CNN Heroes All Star Tribute
column22: accessdate=May 13, 2014}}</ref>  In May 2014, Gaffigan performed at the [[Make It Right Foundation
column23: Make It Right]] Gala, an organization founded by [[Brad Pitt]], which builds sustainable homes and buildings for communities in need.<ref>{{cite web
column25: title= Inside Brad Pitt's Star-Studded Party in New Orleans
column28: accessdate=June 25, 2014}}</ref> On September 26, 2015, he performed at the Festival of Families, a Catholic event held in [[Philadelphia]]. Gaffigan was the only comedian on the bill at the festival, and the event was visited by [[Pope Francis]]. The event had more than one million attendees.

column1: As of June 2016, Gaffigan was the most popular comic on all of [[Pandora.com]] with over 647 million spins.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title= Guess Who Is the Most Played Comedian On Pandora

column1: In 2016, Gaffigan embarked on his [[Fully Dressed Tour]], performing in the United States, Canada, and the UK.
Gaffigan has appeared at the \"[[Just for Laughs]]\" comedy festival in [[Montreal

Gaffigan credits [[David Letterman]] and [[Bill Murray]] as influences, and he has asserted that [[Richard Pryor]] was the greatest stand-up comedian ever.<ref name=stern/> His comedy mentor was [[Dave Attell]], who he asserted was the only person who thought he was funny in his early stand-up years.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Stand-Up Guy Jim Gaffigan on His New TV Land Show (INTERVIEW)

column1: On the episode of ''[[Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee]]'' which featured Gaffigan, he admitted that the show's host [[Jerry Seinfeld]] was a big influence for him.

Gaffigan is widely noted for being an [[everyman]] and a clean comic,<ref name=steinberg/><ref name=bellamy2/> and signature routines regard [[Hot Pockets]],<ref name=wait/><ref name=bellamy2>{{cite news
column2: title=Everyone's in on the joke at Gaffigan show
column11: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> cake, and [[bacon]].<ref name=stevens/>  His tendency to avoid profanity has drawn mixed responses from audiences and critics.  One critic compared him to ''Full House''-era [[Bob Saget]] (who starred in the 1990s family show), which Gaffigan took as an insult.<ref name=Schmidt/>  However, Hampton Stevens in ''[[The Atlantic]]'' wrote that the comic champions \"a vital element to standup that [[Lenny Bruce
column12: [Lenny] Bruce]] had taken away—the indispensable, but apparently forgotten idea that comedians have no obligation to be provocative, topical, socially conscious, or anything else but funny.\"<ref name=stevens>>{{cite web
column15: title=The Radical Averageness of Jim Gaffigan's Stand-Up lo

column4: quote=I did my set, I walked off stage and they said the executive producer wants to meet you up in his office. I thought maybe it was going to be something good. I thought maybe Dave wants me to be a writer. But they wanted me to develop my own ''show''.

column1: As Gaffigan's comedy career stalled in the 1990s, a friend suggested he audition for commercials, a move which turned out to be profitable.<ref name=spin/> He has appeared in over 200 TV commercials,<ref name=Schmidt/> ranging from [[Rolling Rock]] to [[Saturn Corporation
column2: Saturn]] to [[Chrysler]] and [[ESPN]]. His ubiquity earned him the title of 'Salesman of the Year' by ''[[BusinessWeek]]'' in 1999.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate= January 30, 2014}}</ref> He also performed in a trio of Sierra Mist commercials for the [[Super Bowl XLI
column7: 2007 Super Bowl]] as part of the Sierra Mist comedy ensemble \"The Mis-Takes\".<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Sierra Mist Takes Karate Combover to Hospital
column14: title=Sierra Mist's Ensemble Cast is at it Again for Super Bowl 2007
column21: df= }}</ref>  He appeared in an ad series for [[Sierra Mist]] alongside fellow comedian [[Michael Ian Black]].<ref>{{cite magazine
column25: title=The Best & Worst Super Bowl Commercials 2007: Sierra Mist Free

column1: After his first appearance on ''[[The Late Show with David Letterman]]'' in 1999, Gaffigan was tapped by the host to develop a sitcom called ''[[Welcome to New York (TV series)
column2: Welcome to New York]]'' in which he also co-starred alongside [[Christine Baranski]].<ref name=stern/> The show was cancelled after its first season despite receiving positive reviews.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Meet Jim Gaffigan. No, Seriously. Stay After the Show and Meet Him
column9: last=Steinberg}}</ref> During the 2000/2001 television season, he was a cast member of ''[[The Ellen Show]]'' on CBS, [[Ellen DeGeneres]]' second sitcom. He appeared in two movies chosen for the 2001 [[Sundance Film Festival]]: ''[[Super Troopers]]'' and ''[[30 Years to Life]]''. He appeared on ''[[That '70s Show]]''. He was a regular cast member of the [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)
column10: TBS]] original sitcom ''[[My Boys]]''. He left the show at the end of the third season.{{citation needed

column1: In 2008, he appeared in the movie ''[[The Love Guru]]'' starring [[Mike Myers]].<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Why 'The Love Guru' can't possibly suck

column1: In 2009, Gaffigan guest starred as the best friend of [[Murray Hewitt]] in one episode of the [[HBO]] comedy series ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)
column2: Flight of the Conchords]]''. Later that same year, he appeared in the [[Sam Mendes]]-directed [[comedy-drama
column4: Away We Go]]'' and the teen comedy ''[[17 Again (film)
column5: 17 Again]]''. On June 11, 2009, Gaffigan appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]''. He appeared on ''Law & Order'' episodes \"Flight\" and \"Reality Bites\", as well as an episode titled \"Smile\" on ''Law and Order: Criminal Intent''.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=TV Land picks up Jim Gaffigan's CBS sitcom pilot

column1: He was in an episode of ''[[The Daily Show]]'' as a man posing as a ''Daily Show'' correspondent who knows nothing about the show (he refers to it as \"The John Daily Show\") and simply wants to be seen with Jon Stewart. This was meant to be a parody of the [[2009 White House gatecrash incident]].{{citation needed
Gaffigan appeared on Broadway in ''[[That Championship Season]]'', which opened in March 2011, opposite [[Brian Cox (actor)
column2: Brian Cox]], [[Chris Noth]], [[Kiefer Sutherland]], and [[Jason Patric]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Cox, Gaffigan, Noth, Patric & Sutherland to Star in THE CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON
column7: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref> Gaffigan's performance was praised by [[ABC News]] correspondent Sandy Kenyon as the most moving and that he may \"steal the show\".<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Sandy talks to the cast of 'That Championship Season'
column12: accessdate=January 28, 2014}}</ref>  He called being on Broadway \"an amazing experience, really hard but really fun.\"<ref name=suewhite/>

column1: Gaffigan starred in [[Shia LaBeouf]]'s 2013 short film ''[[Howard Cantour.com]]'', the content of which was later revealed to be mostly plagiarized from Daniel Clowes' 2007 graphic novella ''[[Justin M. Damiano]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Hot Short Film: Shia LaBeouf Takes On Film Critics In 'HowardCantour.com'
column6: accessdate= December 16, 2013}}</ref>  Reflecting on the incident in an interview for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', Gaffigan said, \"There's no greater sin in the stand-up world than thievery...So you do not want to be associated with thievery,\" but added, \"I don't have any hard feelings about it because I don't think people think I had anything to do with it.\"<ref name=stern>Stern, Marlow (July 15, 2015), [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/07/15/jim-gaffigan-s-time-is-now-the-comic-on-his-new-show-bill-cosby-s-fall-and-donald-trump.html \"Jim Gaffigan's Time Is Now: The Comic on His New Show, Bill Cosby's Fall, and Donald Trump\"]. ''The Daily Beast''. Retrieved July 28, 2015.</ref>

column1: In the 2010s, Gaffigan, his wife, and [[Peter Tolan]] began to develop material for a show based loosely on their own life.  CBS agreed to shoot a pilot of their show in March 2013, with casting by Marc Hirschfeld,<ref>{{cite news
column9: page=10}}</ref> and [[Mira Sorvino]] playing his wife;<ref name=steinberg/> but ultimately passed on the project.<ref name=katz>{{cite news
column16: access-date= September 26, 2019}}</ref> When the cable network [[TV Land]] began efforts to broadcast original material and attract younger audiences, it offered the Gaffigans complete creative control.  The result was ''[[The Jim Gaffigan Show]]'', a sitcom about a couple raising their five kids in a two-bedroom New York City apartment.  After the release of two online-only episodes in June 2015, the [[television pilot
column17: pilot episode]] aired on July 15, 2015.  The show stars Gaffigan as a fictionalized version of himself,<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=TV Land releases extended scene from new comedy \"Younger\" featuring Sutton Foster and Hilary Duff
column26: df= }}</ref> with his wife Jeannie played by Ashley Williams. Other characters include their real-estate agent (and Jeannie's best friend) Daniel (played by [[Michael Ian Black]]), Jim's fellow comic and best friend Dave ([[Adam Goldberg]]), and their priest, Father Nicholas ([[Tongayi Chirisa]]). After 2 seasons of the show, in 2016 Jim and his wife Jeannie decided not to continue with a third season so they could spend more time with their kids.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=TV Land cancels 'The Jim Gaffigan Show'

column2: Experimenter]]'', a fictionalized account of the experiments of the Yale professor [[Dr. Stanley Milgram]].<ref name=hughes>Hughes, William (July 24, 2015), [http://www.avclub.com/article/jim-gaffigan-fakes-electrocution-trailer-experimen-222862 \"Jim Gaffigan fakes electrocution in the trailer for Experimenter\"]. The AV Club. Retrieved July 28, 2015.</ref>  Gaffigan plays an actor hired to collaborate in the experiments.<ref name=hughes/>

column1: In February 2016, Gaffigan began appearing in [[KFC]] commercials as [[Colonel Sanders]],<ref name=KFC>{{cite news
column6: title= KFC just revealed the newest star of its polarizing Colonel Sanders ads

column1: Since April 8, 2016, Gaffigan has appeared with his family in a marketing campaign for the [[Chrysler Pacifica (RU)
column4: title=Jim Gaffigan stars in Chrysler brand's 'Dad Brand' marketing campaign for the all-new 2017 Chrysler Pacifica

column1: In October 2016, it was announced Gaffigan would be joining the cast of the third season of the [[anthology series
column6: title='Fargo' Adds Jim Gaffigan to Season 3 Cast
column8: accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref> However, he was ultimately forced to drop out due to scheduling difficulties; he was replaced by [[Mark Forward]]. In 2018, he portrayed [[Paul F. Markham
column9: Paul Markham]] in the biographical drama ''[[Chappaquiddick (film)
column10: Chappaquiddick]]'', starring [[Jason Clarke]] and [[Kate Mara]], to positive reviews.<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Kennedy clan and comedian Jim Gaffigan drive ‘Chappaquiddick’
column17: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> Gaffigan next took on the lead role in the 2018 [[neo-noir]] film ''[[American Dreamer (2018 film)
column18: American Dreamer]]'', which was released on September 20, 2019. Gaffigan's dark portrayal of a broken man driven to desperate actions was very well received by critics,<ref>{{Citation
column23: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> with the [[Chicago Sun-Times]] review calling it \"a career-best dramatic performance\" by Gaffigan.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=‘American Dreamer’: The best proof yet that, as a dramatic actor, Jim Gaffigan is ready for his closeup
column33: title=Jim Gaffigan goes dark in his new movie, but the darkness was already there

column1: Gaffigan is also notable for his [[voice-over]] work. He voiced an animated version of himself on ''[[Pale Force]]'' with [[Conan O'Brien]] from 2005 to 2008. He has also voiced characters on the animated shows ''[[Bob's Burgers]]'', ''[[Shorty McShorts' Shorts]]'', ''[[WordGirl]]'', ''[[Star vs. the Forces of Evil]]'', and the animated feature ''[[Duck Duck Goose (film)

column2: alt=Gaffigan standing next to a car reading \"JIM GAFFIGAN / FOR PRESIDENT\"

column1: Gaffigan produced a series of animated shorts for ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', titled ''[[Pale Force]]'' (2005–2008).  The animated sketches featured Gaffigan and O'Brien as superheroes who fight crime with their extremely pale skin.<ref name=stevens/> The series was nominated for a Daytime Emmy in 2007 in the category of \"Outstanding Broadband Program – Comedy\".<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Nominees for the Emmy Award For Broadband Announced; Winners to be Named June 14

column1: Gaffigan's humorous quips have earned him over two and a half million followers on [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=January 23, 2014}}</ref> He was listed by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as one of the \"25 funniest people on Twitter\" in 2012.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title= The 25 Funniest People on Twitter

column1: In 2013, Gaffigan released ''Dad Is Fat'', a title derived from the first complete sentence his eldest son wrote on a dry-erase board at the age of four or five.  \"He showed it to me,\" Gaffigan recalled in an interview, \"and I laughed, and then I put him up for adoption.\"<ref name=wait/>  The book is a collection of essays dealing with the raising of his children, as well as reminiscences from his own childhood.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Jim Gaffigan's \"Dad Is Fat\" is packed with dark parental humor
column8: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref>  In support of the volume, he appeared on NPR's ''[[Weekend Edition]]'', ABC's ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)
column9: The View]]'', and MSNBC's ''Morning Joe'', spoke at BEA in New York, embarked on a nine-stop bus tour that ended on Father's Day.<ref>{{cite news

column1: It debuted at number five on ''[[The New York Times]]'' Best Seller's list, remaining on the list for three months.<ref>{{cite news
column15: last=Cowles}}</ref> The book received tepid reviews from critics.  ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' said of the book that it's \"hardly groundbreaking comedy material, but the book will appeal to Gaffigan's fans.\"<ref>(April 15, 2013), \"DAD IS FAT\". ''Kirkus Reviews''. '''81''' (8):50</ref> Lou Harry of the Indianapolis Business Journal said that while \"no new ground is broken in Jim Gaffigan's book...'Dad is Fat' should be a fun [[intermezzo]] in your summer reading pile.\"<ref>Harry, Lou (May 27, 2013), \"Notes on parenting from a funnyman father.\" ''Indianapolis Business Journal''. ''34'' (13):3</ref>  Regarding the audiobook, which Gaffigan read, ''Audiofile'' said his \"performance strikes the right balance between his near-deadpan comedy delivery and the energy needed to keep a beleaguered parent engaged.\"<ref>(October/November 2013), [http://www.audiofilemagazine.com/reviews/read/80864/ \"DAD IS FAT\"]. ''AudioFile''. '''22''' (3):51</ref>

column1: Gaffigan signed with [[Crown Publishing]] in June 2013 to write a second book of comic essays. The book, ''[[Food: A Love Story]]'', which was released in Fall 2014.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Jim Gaffigan to Publish Second Book of Essays
column10: title=Jim Gaffigan Signs a Deal to Write a Second Book
column24: language=English}}</ref> ''Publisher's Weekly'' said the book \"packs plenty of laughs.\"<ref>{{cite news
column32: page=19}}</ref>  ''Kirkus Reviews'' remarked that \"Gaffigan somehow manages to work 'clean' without ever becoming sickeningly [[saccharine]],\" and that 'laughs [are] served up just right on every page.\"<ref>{{cite news
column38: page= 1}}</ref>  Of the accompanying audiobook, the ''Library Journal'' said, \"The witty commentary is peppered with jokes and funny stories that will have listeners smiling throughout and occasionally laughing out loud.\"<ref>{{cite news

column1: Prior to meeting his wife, actress Jeannie Noth, Gaffigan largely wrote alone.  However, while working on his first show, ''Welcome to New York'', he was overwhelmed and asked for input from her (then his friend). Although initially hesitant to have a collaborator, as their relationship grew, so did Noth's ability to write material for him.  Once they married, she left behind her work with her youth theater project (Shakespeare on the Playground) to devote herself to raising their expanding brood, and after a joke she wrote drew big laughs at a show, she and Jim began to collaborate more.{{citation needed
column2: date=July 2015}}  She gradually transferred into the position of Jim's chief co-writer, and they are now full writing partners.  She has been a credited writer and/or executive producer on all his comedy endeavors since ''Beyond the Pale'', including his two books and television show.<ref name=katz/>  He also credits her with \"coaching\" him through his performance in ''That Championship Season''.<ref name=suewhite/>

column1: Gaffigan participated on the [[NPR]] radio quiz program ''[[Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me!]]'' in 2013.<ref name=wait>(July 26, 2013), [https://www.npr.org/2013/07/27/205793645/not-my-job-jim-gaffigan-takes-a-quiz-on-gwyneth-paltrow \"Not My Job: Jim Gaffigan Take a Quiz on Gwyneth Paltrow\"]. ''Wait Wait...Don't Tell Me!'' [[National Public Radio
column2: NPR]]. Retrieved July 28, 2015.</ref> Gaffigan is also a regular commentator on ''[[CBS Sunday Morning]]'', for which he won a Daytime Emmy in 2016.

column1: Gaffigan is married to actress [[Jeannie Gaffigan]] (née Noth),<ref name=steinberg/> with whom he has five children: daughters Marre (born 2005) and Katie Louise (born 2009) and sons Jack (born 2006), Michael (born 2011), and Patrick (born 2012). The family of seven famously lived in a two-bedroom apartment in [[New York City]],<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Fat' Dad Jim Gaffigan On Kids, Comedy And Apartment Living
column6: accessdate=January 6, 2014}}</ref> before moving to a larger home in 2015. To stay connected to his family, Gaffigan tries to \"maintain bedtime rituals while working in the city\";<ref name=\"bellamy\">{{cite news
column7: title=Funny story: Jim Gaffigan talks tour, life
column17: url-status=dead}}</ref> when on tour, he reportedly takes his family with him. Gaffigan has stated that he avoids working on Sundays.<ref name=bellamy/>

column1: Gaffigan has stated, on stage and elsewhere, that he is a practicing Catholic (although he jokes that his wife is a \"Shiite Catholic\" compared to him).<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Comedian Jim Gaffigan Takes Sundays Off From Stand-Up
column9: title=Is comic Jim Gaffigan the Catholic Church's newest evangelizer?
column15: title=Jim Gaffigan's deadpan humor to heat up Western Michigan University's Miller Auditorium
column18: accessdate=July 31, 2013}}</ref>  He and his family attend [[Mass in the Catholic Church
column19: Mass]] at the [[St. Patrick's Old Cathedral
column20: Basilica of St. Patrick's Old Cathedral]] in Manhattan, where Gaffigan and his wife Jeannie were married in 2003 and where their children were baptized.<ref>LaPlante, Joseph R. (July 5, 2015), \"Comedy ties faith, family\". ''[[Our Sunday Visitor]]''. '''104''' (10):8</ref><ref>{{Cite news
column29: title=Family Is at the Heart of Comedian Jim Gaffigan
column34: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> In May 2016, the Gaffigans delivered the [[commencement address]] at the [[Catholic University of America]].<ref>{{Cite web
column41: access-date=2019-09-26}}</ref> The Gaffigans also delivered the commencement address at Jeannie's [[alma mater]] [[Marquette University]] on 20 May 2018. They were both awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Humane Letters]] degree as part of the graduation ceremony.<ref>{{Cite web
column43: title=Jeannie and Jim Gaffigan to serve as Marquette's spring Commencement speakers

column1: In April 2017, Jeannie was diagnosed with a benign brain tumor known as [[Choroid plexus papilloma
column2: papilloma of the choroid plexus]], which was successfully removed in a nine-hour operation performed by surgeon [[Joshua B. Bederson]].<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Jim Gaffigan's Wife, Jeannie, Recovering From Life-Threatening Brain Tumor
column13: title=Jim Gaffigan's Wife Jeannie on Discovering She Had a Brain Tumor the Size of an Apple: 'I Was a Ticking Time Bomb'

column2: ''Shoot First and Pray You Live (Because Luck Has Nothing to Do with It)''

column3: It's Kind of a Funny Story]]''

column2: Episode: \"How Florrie Got Her Groove Back\"
Episode: \"Murray Takes It to the Next Level\"

column1: On April 26, 2014, Gaffigan received the award for Concert Comedian at the [[American Comedy Awards]] for his work.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Winners of the 2014 American Comedy Awards

column1: In 2007, \"Pale Force\" was nominated for a Daytime Emmy for Outstanding Broadband Program in the Comedy category. Gaffigan served as executive producer, writer, and lead actor.
In 2016, he won the [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Morning Program]] for his contributions as a commentator to ''CBS Sunday Morning''.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences Announces Winners For The 43rd Annual Daytime Emmy Awards
column4: publisher=The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences

column1: The [[Grammy Award]]s are awarded annually by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]]. Gaffigan has been nominated four times.

column4: title=Weird Al, Sarah Silverman, Patton Oswalt, Jim Gaffigan Are All Grammy Nominees

column1: '''Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) stations''' are the bases for the [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution
column2: RNLI]]'s fleet of search and rescue [[Lifeboat (rescue)
column3: lifeboats]] that cover the coastal waters around the entire [[British Isles]], as well as major inland waterways.

column1: The service was established in 1824 and is operated largely by volunteers. Its headquarters are at [[Poole]], [[Dorset]] and it is a registered charity in both the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Republic of Ireland]].

The types of boats provided at each station and the launching methods vary depending on local needs. If more than one boat is provided they are sometimes stationed in separate buildings at different locations in the same town. Current RNLI boats fall into three broad groups:

column3: 'Tooltrack' tractor launching an inshore lifeboat at {{lbs

column1: * Carriage – an ALB or ILB is pushed into the water on a carriage by a tractor
* Davit – an ILB is lowered into the water by a crane
* Launchway – an ILB is pushed into the water on a carriage by hand
* Moored afloat – an ALB or ILB is kept in the water alongside the lifeboat station or nearby, in which case a small boarding boat is provided so that the crew can reach it
* Slipway – an ALB slides down a slipway straight into the water
* Transporter – hovercraft are kept on the rear of trucks that can transport and offload them anywhere
The following lists do not include the lifeguard patrolled beaches which also have their own equipment including [[Arancia-class lifeboat
column2: inflatable boats]] and [[jetski]]s. The information is correct to 2009 unless noted otherwise,<ref>{{cite book
column9: pages= 66–71 }}</ref> and is set out like the RNLI's divisional model. As far as possible it follows a clockwise route around the coast.

column1: * East Division – [[East Anglia]] and South East England
* South Division – South West England and the [[Channel Islands]]
* West Division – [[Wales]] and the [[Isle of Man]]
* North Division – East and west coasts of northern England
* Ireland Division – [[Republic of Ireland]] and [[Northern Ireland]]

column2: high-level]], high-performance, dynamic [[programming language]]. While it is a general purpose language and can be used to write any application, many of its features are well-suited for high-performance [[numerical analysis]] and [[computational science]].<ref>{{cite web
title      = Matlab, R, and Julia: Languages for data analysis
title      = Julia Programming Language – A True Python Alternative
title      = New Julia language seeks to be the C for scientists
title      = Out in the Open: Man Creates One Programming Language to Rule Them All

column1: Distinctive aspects of Julia's design include a type system with [[parametric polymorphism]] in a [[dynamic programming language]]; with [[multiple dispatch]] as its core [[programming paradigm]]. Julia supports [[Concurrent computing
column3: parallel]] and [[distributed computing]] (with or without using [[Message Passing Interface
column5: title=GitHub - JuliaParallel/MPI.jl: MPI wrappers for Julia.
column8: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> and/or the built-in corresponding<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Questions about getting started with parallel computing
column24: just-in-time]] compiler that is referred to as \"just-[[Ahead-of-time compilation
column30: title=Growing a Compiler - Getting to Machine Learning from a General Purpose Compiler
column33: accessdate=11 April 2019}}</ref> in the Julia community is used.

column4: title=Suspending Garbage Collection for Performance...good idea or bad idea?
column7: accessdate=2017-05-31}} uses [[eager evaluation]], and includes efficient libraries for [[floating-point]] calculations, [[linear algebra]], [[random number generation]], and [[regular expression]] matching. Many libraries are available, including some (e.g., for [[fast Fourier transform]]s) that were previously bundled with Julia and are now separate.now available with using [[FFTW]] in current versions (That dependency, is one of many which, was moved out of the standard library to a package because it is GPL licensed, and thus is not included in Julia 1.0 by default.) {{Cite web
column9: title=Remove the FFTW bindings from Base by ararslan · Pull Request #21956 · JuliaLang/julia

column1: Tools available for Julia include, not just many widely used editors, such as [[Vim (text editor)
column2: Vim]] and [[Emacs]], but also [[integrated development environment
column3: IDEs]] (e.g. Juno, and Microsoft's [[Visual Studio Code]], with [[Plug-in (computing)
column4: extensions]] adding Julia support, both providing debugging support); with integrated tools, e.g. a [[lint (software)
column7: title=ANN: linter-julia plugin for Atom / Juno
