column24: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> for the built-in one), debugger,<ref>{{Cite web
column28: access-date=2019-04-10}}</ref> and the Rebugger.jl package \"supports [[interactive programming

column1: * test different modifications to the code or arguments as many times as you want; you are never forced to exit “debug mode” and save your file

* run the same chosen block of code repeatedly (perhaps trying out different ways of fixing a bug) without needing to repeat any of the “setup” work that might have been necessary to get to some deeply nested method in the original call stack.<ref name=\"Rebugger\">{{Cite web
column3: title=[ANN] Rebugger: interactive debugging for Julia 0.7/1.0

column1: Work on Julia was started in 2009, by Jeff Bezanson, [[Stefan Karpinski]], [[Viral B. Shah]], and [[Alan Edelman]], who set out to create a free language that was both high-level and fast. On 14 February 2012, the team launched a website with a blog post explaining the language's mission.<ref>{{cite web
column2: last1=Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral Shah, Alan Edelman
column6: accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref>  In an interview with InfoWorld in April 2012, Karpinski said of the name \"Julia\": \"There's no good reason, really. It just seemed like a pretty name.\"<ref>[[Stefan Karpinski]], [https://www.infoworld.com/article/2616709/application-development/new-julia-language-seeks-to-be-the-c-for-scientists.html New Julia language seeks to be the C for scientists], [[InfoWorld]], 18 April 2012</ref> Bezanson said he chose the name on the recommendation of a friend.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Stefan Karpinski and Jeff Bezanson on Julia

column1: Since the 2012 launch, the Julia community has grown, with over 13,000,000 downloads {{as of
column4: lc=y}} (and is used at more than 1,500 universities),<ref>{{Cite web
column18: access-date=2019-02-11}}</ref> The Official Julia Docker images, at [[Docker, Inc.
column19: Docker Hub]], have seen over 4,000,000 downloads as of January 2019.<ref>{{Cite web
column28: accessdate=2018-05-10}}</ref> [[academic conference]] for Julia users and developers has been held annually since 2014.

column1: Version 0.3 was released in August 2014, version 0.4 in October 2015, version 0.5 in October 2016,<ref>[https://julialang.org/blog/ The Julia Blog]</ref> and version 0.6 in June 2017.<ref>https://julialang.org/blog/2017/06/julia-0.6-release</ref>  Both Julia 0.7 (a useful release for testing packages, and for knowing how to upgrade them for 1.0<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=What is Julia 0.7? How does it relate to 1.0?
column6: access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref>) and version 1.0 were released on 8 August 2018. Work on Julia 0.7 was a \"huge undertaking\" (e.g., because of \"entirely new optimizer\"), and some changes were made to semantics, e.g. the [[iteration]] interface was simplified;<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref> and the syntax changed a little (with the syntax now stable, and same for 1.x and 0.7).

column1: The release candidate for Julia 1.0 (Julia 1.0.0-rc1) was released on 7 August 2018, and the final version a day later (and by now, Julia 1.0.x are the oldest versions still supported, having [[long-term support]]; for at least a year). Julia 1.1 was released in January 2019 with, e.g., a new \"exception stack\" language feature. Bugfix releases are expected roughly monthly, for 1.4.x and 1.0.x and Julia 1.0.1 up to 1.0.5 have followed that schedule. Julia 1.2 was released in August 2019, and it has e.g. some built-in support for web browsers (for testing if running in [[JavaScript]] VM),<ref>{{Cite web
column5: quote=Predicate for testing if Julia is running in a JavaScript VM (JSVM), including e.g. a WebAssembly JavaScript embedding in a web browser.
column7: access-date=2019-08-20}}</ref> and Julia 1.4 in March 2020 (and with it Julia 1.3.x, 1.2.x and Julia 1.1.x releases are no longer maintained). Julia 1.3 added e.g. composable multi-threaded parallelism and a binary artifacts system for Julia packages.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: others=Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral Shah, Alan Edelman, et al <!--

column1: Julia 1.4 allowed better syntax for array indexing to handle e.g. [[zero-based_numbering#Usage_in_programming_languages
column3: A[begin+1]}} for '''second''' element of array A.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=support a[begin] for a[firstindex(a)] by stevengj · Pull Request #33946 · JuliaLang/julia
column8: access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref> It also changed the memory model.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=For structs with all isbits or isbitsunion fields, allow them to be s<!--…-->tored inline in arrays <!--by quinnj--> · Pull Request #32448 · JuliaLang/julia
column12: quote=I still keep running into problems that this causes internally because it was a breaking change that changes assumptions made by some users and inference/codegen.

column1: Most packages that work in Julia 1.0.x also work in 1.1.x or newer, enabled by the [[forward compatibility
column2: forward compatible]] syntax guarantee. A major exception was, for interacting with non-Julia code, the JavaCall.jl package (however calling other languages, e.g. [[R (programming language)
column3: R language]] works, with the package for R fixed<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Fix for C stack checking issues on 1.1 by simonbyrne · Pull Request #293 · JuliaInterop/RCall.jl
column8: access-date=2019-08-10}}</ref>) to call Java, Scala etc. This was fixed by Java 11,<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=StackOverflowError in `JavaCall.init` for Julia 1.1.0 · Issue #96 · JuliaInterop/JavaCall.jl
column13: access-date=2019-10-21}}</ref> or alternatively to use those languages with Julia (on older JVM), for e.g. [[Java Database Connectivity
column14: JDBC]].jl or [[Apache Spark]] (through Spark.jl), users could choose to stay with the LTS version of Julia.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: title=JVM fails to load in 1.1 (JavaCall.jl) · Issue #31104 · JuliaLang/julia
column20: access-date=2019-08-18}}</ref> <!--A milestone was set for a fix in Julia 1.4 (while there's already a workaround in Julia 1.3.0<ref>{{Cite web
column25: access-date=2019-08-18}}</ref>), to support older Java, which has-->  Julia 1.4 had a milestone set for 15 December 2019 and for Julia 1.5 the due date is 15 April 2020. Milestones for Julia 2.0 (and later, e.g. 3.0) currently have no set due dates.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Julia has attracted some high-profile users, from investment manager [[BlackRock]], which uses it for [[time-series analytics]], to the British insurer [[Aviva]], which uses it for [[risk calculations]]. In 2015, the [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York]] used Julia to make models of the United States economy, noting that the language made model estimation \"about 10 times faster\" than its previous [[MATLAB]] implementation. Julia's co-founders established Julia Computing in 2015 to provide paid support, training, and consulting services to clients, though Julia remains free to use. At the 2017 JuliaCon<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2017-06-04}}</ref> conference, Jeffrey Regier, [[Keno Fischer]] and others announced<ref>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=24 June 2017}}</ref> that the Celeste project<ref>{{Cite arXiv
column25: title=Learning an Astronomical Catalog of the Visible Universe through Scalable Bayesian Inference
column28: year=2016}}</ref> used Julia to achieve \"peak performance of 1.54 [[FLOPS
column29: petaFLOPS]] using 1.3 million threads\"<ref>{{Cite press release
column36: quote=Celeste is written entirely in Julia, and the Celeste team loaded an aggregate of 178 terabytes of image data to produce the most accurate catalog of 188 million [[astronomical object]]s in just 14.6 minutes [..] a performance improvement of 1,000x in single-threaded execution.}}</ref> on 9300 <!-- on 9,300 (vs. 8192 Xeon cores\") possibly \"optional nVidia\" GPU cards of Cori are used (or not), unclear conflated with lower numbers? --> [[Knights Landing (microarchitecture)
column37: Knights Landing]] (KNL) nodes of the [[Cray XC40#United States
column38: Cori II (Cray XC40)]] supercomputer (then 6th fastest computer in the world).<ref>{{Cite web
column40: title=. @KenoFischer is speaking on Celeste in the @Intel theatre at @Supercomputing. 0.65M cores, 56 TB of data, Cori - world's 6th largest supecomputer.pic.twitter.com/21nLHo1qty
column46: access-date=2019-09-15}}</ref> Julia thus joins C, C++, and Fortran as high-level languages in which petaFLOPS computations have been achieved.

column1: Three of the Julia co-creators are the recipients of the 2019 [[J. H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software
column2: James H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software]] (awarded every four years) \"for the creation of Julia, an innovative environment for the creation of high-performance tools that enable the analysis and solution of computational science problems.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Julia language co-creators win James H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software
column6: access-date=2019-01-22}}</ref>  Also, Alan Edelman, professor of applied mathematics at MIT, has been selected to receive the 2019 IEEE Computer Society Sidney Fernbach Award \"for outstanding breakthroughs in high-performance computing, linear algebra, and computational science and for contributions to the Julia programming language.\"<ref>{{Cite press release
column8: title=Alan Edelman of MIT Recognized with Prestigious 2019 IEEE Computer Society Sidney Fernbach Award {{!}} IEEE Computer Society

column1: Julia Computing and [[NVIDIA]] announce \"the availability of the Julia programming language as a pre-packaged container on the NVIDIA GPU Cloud (NGC) container registry\"<ref name=\"Julia_Nvidia\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Julia Computing and NVIDIA Bring Julia GPU Computing to Arm
column6: access-date=2019-12-03}}</ref> with NVIDIA stating \"Easily Deploy Julia on x86 and Arm [..] Julia offers a package for a comprehensive HPC ecosystem covering machine learning, data science, various scientific domains and visualization.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=NVIDIA Expands Support for Arm with HPC, AI, Visualization Containers on NGC {{!}} NVIDIA Blog

column1: Additionally, \"Julia was selected by the [https://clima.caltech.edu/ Climate Modeling Alliance] as the sole implementation language for their next generation global climate model. This multi-million dollar project aims to build an earth-scale climate model providing insight into the effects and challenges of climate change.\"<ref name=\"Julia_Nvidia\"/>
Julia has received contributions from over 870 developers worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title=JuliaLang/julia: The Julia Language: A fresh approach to technical computing.
column6: access-date=2019-01-26}}</ref> Dr. Jeremy Kepner at [[MIT Lincoln Laboratory]] was the founding sponsor of the Julia project in its early days. In addition, funds from the [[Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation]], the [[Alfred P. Sloan Foundation]], [[Intel]], and agencies such as [[National Science Foundation
column9: FAA]] have been essential to the development of Julia.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> [[Mozilla]], the maker of Firefox Web browser, with its research grants for H1 2019, sponsored \"a member of the official Julia team\" for the project \"Bringing Julia to the Browser\",<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title=Mozilla is funding a way to support Julia in Firefox
column20: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> meaning to Firefox <!-- \"and the general browser environment--> and other web browsers.<ref>{{Cite web
column33: quote=running language interpreters in WebAssembly. To further increase access to leading data science tools, we’re looking for someone to port R or Julia to WebAssembly and to attempt to provide a level 3 language plugin for Iodide: automatic conversion of data basic types between R/Julia and Javascript, and the ability to share class instances between R/Julia and Javascript.
column35: title=Literate scientific computing and communication for the web: iodide-project/iodide
column39: quote=We envision a future workflow that allows you to do your data munging in Python, fit a quick model in R or JAGS, solve some differential equations in Julia, and then display your results with a live interactive d3+JavaScript visualization ... and all that within within a single, portable, sharable, and hackable file.

column1: Julia Computing, Inc. was founded in 2015 by [[Viral B. Shah]], Deepak Vinchhi, [[Alan Edelman]], Jeff Bezanson, [[Stefan Karpinski]] and Keno Fischer.<ref>{{Cite web
In June 2017, Julia Computing raised $4.6M in seed funding from [[General Catalyst]] and [[Founder Collective]].<ref>https://juliacomputing.com/communication/2017/06/19/seed-funding.html</ref>
Though designed for numerical computing, Julia is a [[general-purpose programming language]].<ref>{{cite web

column2: quote      = General Purpose [..] Julia lets you write UIs, statically compile your code, or even deploy it on a webserver.

column1: It is also useful for low-level [[system programming

column3: title=How to create a multi-threaded HTTP server in Julia
column10: quote=In summary, even though Julia lacks a multi-threaded server solution currently out of box, we can easily take advantage of its process distribution features and a highly popular load balancing tech to get full CPU utilization for HTTP handling.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web
column18: title=Getting Started with Node Julia · Node Julia
column21: accessdate=2017-05-31}}</ref> --> and client<ref name=\"JSExpr\"/><ref name=\"WebAssembly\"/> side.

column1: According to the official website, the main features of the language are:
* [[Multiple dispatch]]: providing ability to define function behavior across many combinations of argument types
* [[Dynamic type]] system: types for documentation, optimization, and dispatch
* Good performance, approaching that of [[Type system

column2: Python]] functions: use the PyCall package{{Efn
column3: For calling the newer [[Python 3]] (the older default to call Python 2, is also still supported)<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Using PyCall in julia on Ubuntu with python3
column11: quote=to import modules (e.g., python3-numpy)}}</ref> <!--([[PyPy]] and e.g. [[PHP]] was/is supported<ref name=\"Polyglot\">{{cite web
column16: access-date=2019-07-25}}</ref> for Julia 0.5 (PyPy should work; supported by python-bond that Polyglot.jl is based on); [[Jython]] support is not confirmed, but since JavaCall.jl allows calling Java (and thus Scala) I assume also Jython.)--> and calling in the other direction, from Python to Julia, is also supported with ''pyjulia''.<ref>{{cite web

column1: It is not like Polyglot. jl does not support this for older Julia (and also interesting project to support other languages, e.g., PHP), but it has not been upgraded for Julia 1.0: Even calling [[recursive]]ly (back and forth) between these languages is possible, without (or with) using ''Polyglot.jl'',<ref name=\"Polyglot\"/> that supports additional languages to Python.

column2: C]] functions directly: no wrappers or special [[application programming interface
shell]]-like abilities to manage other processes

column1: * User-defined types are as fast and compact as built-ins
* Automatic generation of efficient, specialized code for different argument types
* Elegant and extensible conversions and promotions for numeric and other types
* Efficient support for [[Unicode]], including but not limited to [[UTF-8]]

column2: source=JuliaLang.org}} Only part missing it the MIT part, that is better explained elsewhere.-->

column1: Multiple dispatch (also termed [[multimethod]]s in Lisp) is a [[generalization]] of [[single dispatch]] — the [[Polymorphism (computer science)
column2: polymorphic mechanism]] used in common [[object-oriented programming]] (OOP) languages — that uses [[Inheritance (object-oriented programming)
column3: inheritance]]. In Julia, all concrete types are [[subtyping
column4: subtypes]] of abstract types, directly or indirectly subtypes of the ''Any'' type, which is the top of the type hierarchy. Concrete types can not themselves be subtyped the way they can in other languages; composition is used instead (see also [[Inheritance (object-oriented programming)#Inheritance vs subtyping

column1: Julia draws significant inspiration from various dialects of Lisp<!-- Karpinski: \"In short, I would describe it as a Lisp with Matlab-like syntax\" https://www.reddit.com/r/programming/comments/pv3k9/why_we_created_julia_a_new_programming_language/ -->, including [[Scheme (programming language)
column2: Scheme]] and [[Common Lisp]], and it shares many features with [[Dylan (programming language)
column3: Dylan]], also a multiple-dispatch-oriented dynamic language (which features an [[ALGOL]]-like [[Free-form language
column5: infix]] syntax rather than a Lisp-like prefix syntax, while in Julia \"everything\"<ref name=\"Learn Julia in Y\">{{cite web
column12: Fortress]], another numerical programming language (which features multiple dispatch and a sophisticated parametric type system). While [[Common Lisp Object System]] (CLOS) adds multiple dispatch to Common Lisp, not all functions are generic functions.

column1: In Julia, Dylan, and Fortress extensibility is the default, and the system's built-in functions are all generic and extensible. In Dylan, multiple dispatch is as fundamental as it is in Julia: all user-defined functions and even basic built-in operations like + are generic. Dylan's type system, however, does not fully support parametric types, which are more typical of the [[Generational list of programming languages#ML based
column2: ML lineage of languages]]. By default, CLOS does not allow for dispatch on Common Lisp's parametric types; such extended dispatch semantics can only be added as an extension through the [[Common Lisp Object System#Metaobject Protocol
column3: CLOS Metaobject Protocol]]. By convergent design, Fortress also features multiple dispatch on parametric types; unlike Julia, however, Fortress is statically rather than dynamically typed, with separate compiling and executing phases. The language features are summarized in the following table:

column1: By default, the Julia runtime must be pre-installed as user-provided source code is run. Alternatively, a standalone [[executable]] that needs no Julia source code can be built with ''ApplicationBuilder.jl''<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=GitHub - NHDaly/ApplicationBuilder.jl: Compile, bundle, and release julia software.
column8: title=GitHub - JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl: Compile your Julia Package.

column3: title=Build a standalone executables from a Julia script}}</ref><ref>{{cite newsgroup

column2: syntactic macros]] (used for [[metaprogramming]]), like Lisp macros, are more powerful than [[Macro (computer science)#Text-substitution macros
column3: text-substitution macros]] used in the [[preprocessor]] of some other languages such as C, because they work at the level of [[abstract syntax tree]]s (ASTs). Julia's macro system is [[hygienic macro
column4: hygienic]], but also supports deliberate capture when desired (like for [[anaphoric macro]]s) using the esc construct.

column1: The Julia official distribution includes a \"full-featured interactive command-line REPL\" ([[read–eval–print loop]]),<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Julia REPL · The Julia Language
column5: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> with a searchable history, [[tab-completion]], many helpful keybindings, and dedicated help and [[shell (computing)
column8: title=Introducing Julia/The REPL - Wikibooks, open books for an open world
column10: quote=you can install the Julia package OhMyREPL.jl (https://github.com/KristofferC/OhMyREPL.jl) which lets you customize the REPL's appearance and behaviour
column11: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> which can be used to experiment and test code quickly.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: access-date=2018-08-15}} The following fragment represents a sample session example where strings are concatenated automatically by println:See also: https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/strings/ for string interpolation and the string(greet, \", \", whom, \".\\n\") example for preferred ways to concatenate strings. Julia has the println and print functions, but also a @printf macro (i.e., not in function form) to eliminate run-time overhead of formatting (unlike the same function in C).

column1: julia> println(\"Hello world!\", \" I'm on cloud \", f(0, 4), \" as Julia supports recognizable syntax!\")
Hello world! I'm on cloud 9 as Julia supports recognizable syntax!

The REPL gives user access to the system shell and to help mode, by pressing ; or ? after the prompt (preceding each command), respectively. It also keeps the history of commands, including between sessions.{{cite web
column5: accessdate=18 November 2014}} Code that can be tested inside the Julia's interactive section or saved into a file with a .jl extension and run from the command line by typing:

column1: Julia is supported by [[Jupyter]], an online interactive \"notebooks\" environment.<ref>{{cite web

column2: interoperable]] with many languages. Julia's <source lang=\"julia\" inline>ccall</source> keyword is used to call C-exported or Fortran shared library functions individually.

column1: Julia has support for [[Unicode 12.1]] (support for current Unicode 13.0 has been implemented<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Unicode 13 support by stevengj · Pull Request #179 · JuliaStrings/utf8proc
column6: access-date=2020-03-29}}</ref> for Julia 1.5), which added only one letter since Unicode 12.0,<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=support for Unicode 12.1.0 by stevengj · Pull Request #32002 · JuliaLang/julia
column11: access-date=2019-05-12}} with [[UTF-8]] used for strings (by default) and for Julia source code (only allowing legal UTF-8 in the latest version), meaning also allowing as an option common math symbols for many operators, such as ∈ for the in operator.

column1: Julia has packages supporting markup languages such as [[HTML]] (and also for [[HTTP]]), [[XML]], [[JSON]] and [[BSON]], and for [[database]]s and Web use in general.

column3: Knet]] implement complete machine-learning frameworks written completely in Julia. [[Apache MXNet]] and [[TensorFlow]] are also available through wrapper libraries. [[Turing (probabilistic programming)
column5: Gen]] implement general-purpose [[probabilistic programming]] languages into Julia. [[Pharmacokinetics
column6: Pharmacokinetic]] modeling and simulations are made available through the [[Pumas (pharmaceutical modeling)

column1: Julia's core is implemented in Julia and [[C (programming language)
column2: C]]<!--C99, except for 0.4 needing C11 because of static asserts-->, together with [[C++]] for the [[LLVM]] dependency. The parsing and code-lowering are implemented in FemtoLisp, a [[Scheme (programming language)
column9: access-date=June 16, 2019}}</ref> The LLVM compiler infrastructure project is used as the [[Compiler#Back end
column10: back end]] for generation of [[64-bit computing
column11: 64-bit]] or [[32-bit]] optimized [[machine code]] depending on the platform Julia runs on. With some exceptions (e.g., [[PCRE]]), the [[standard library]] is implemented in Julia. The most notable aspect of Julia's implementation is its speed, which is often within a factor of two relative to fully optimized C code (and thus often an order of magnitude faster than Python or [[R (programming language)

column2: title        = Julia: A Fast Dynamic Language for Technical Computing
title        = How To Make Python Run As Fast As Julia
title        = Basic Comparison of Python, Julia, R, Matlab and IDL

column1: }}</ref> Development of Julia began in 2009 and an [[Open-source software
column2: open-source]] version was publicized in February 2012.<ref name=\"announcement\">{{cite web
title        = Pure and Julia are cool languages worth checking out

column1: While Julia uses JIT,<!-- Viral states \"Julia no longer uses the MCJIT in LLVM\" so this link is probably misleading:

}}</ref> --> Julia generates native machine code directly, before a function is first run (not [[bytecode]]s that are run on a [[virtual machine]] (VM) or translated as the bytecode is running, as with, ''e.g.'', Java; the [[JVM]] or [[Dalvik (software)
Julia has four support tiers,<ref>{{cite web
column5: access-date=2019-05-17}}</ref> and currently supports all [[x86-64]] processors, that are [[64-bit computing
column7: optimized]] for the latest generations) and all [[IA-32]] (\"x86\") processors except for decades old ones, i.e., in [[32-bit]] mode (\"i686\", excepting CPUs from the pre-[[Pentium 4]]-era); and supports more in lower tiers, e.g., ARM has tier 2 support: Julia \"fully supports ARMv8 (AArch64) processors, and supports ARMv7 and ARMv6 (AArch32) with some caveats.\"<ref>{{cite web
column12: quote=A list of [https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/labels/arm known issues] for ARM is available.
column13: access-date=2019-11-29}}</ref> [[CUDA]] (i.e. Nvidia GPUs; implementing [[Parallel Thread Execution
column14: PTX]]) has tier 1 support, with the help of an [https://github.com/JuliaGPU/CUDAnative.jl external package]. There are also additionally packages supporting other accelerators, such as Google's [[tensor processing unit
column20: access-date=2019-11-29}}</ref> and AMD's GPUs also have support with e.g. [[OpenCL]]. Julia's downloads page provides [[executable]]s (and source) for all the officially supported platforms.

column1: On some platforms, Julia may need to be compiled from [[source code]] (e.g., the original [[Raspberry Pi]]), with specific build options. Julia has been \"successfully built\" <!--on the following ARMv8 devices:

on several ARM platforms, up to, e.g., \"ARMv8 Data Center & Cloud Processors\", such as [https://www.cavium.com/ThunderX_ARM_Processors.html Cavium ThunderX] (first ARM with 48 cores). PowerPC (64-bit) has tier 3 support, meaning it \"may or may not build\".

column2: high-level]], high-performance, dynamic [[programming language]]. While it is a general purpose language and can be used to write any application, many of its features are well-suited for high-performance [[numerical analysis]] and [[computational science]].<ref>{{cite web
title      = Matlab, R, and Julia: Languages for data analysis
title      = Julia Programming Language – A True Python Alternative
title      = New Julia language seeks to be the C for scientists
title      = Out in the Open: Man Creates One Programming Language to Rule Them All

column1: Distinctive aspects of Julia's design include a type system with [[parametric polymorphism]] in a [[dynamic programming language]]; with [[multiple dispatch]] as its core [[programming paradigm]]. Julia supports [[Concurrent computing
column3: parallel]] and [[distributed computing]] (with or without using [[Message Passing Interface
column5: title=GitHub - JuliaParallel/MPI.jl: MPI wrappers for Julia.
column8: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> and/or the built-in corresponding<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Questions about getting started with parallel computing
column24: just-in-time]] compiler that is referred to as \"just-[[Ahead-of-time compilation
column30: title=Growing a Compiler - Getting to Machine Learning from a General Purpose Compiler
column33: accessdate=11 April 2019}}</ref> in the Julia community is used.

column4: title=Suspending Garbage Collection for Performance...good idea or bad idea?
column7: accessdate=2017-05-31}} uses [[eager evaluation]], and includes efficient libraries for [[floating-point]] calculations, [[linear algebra]], [[random number generation]], and [[regular expression]] matching. Many libraries are available, including some (e.g., for [[fast Fourier transform]]s) that were previously bundled with Julia and are now separate.now available with using [[FFTW]] in current versions (That dependency, is one of many which, was moved out of the standard library to a package because it is GPL licensed, and thus is not included in Julia 1.0 by default.) {{Cite web

column1: * test different modifications to the code or arguments as many times as you want; you are never forced to exit “debug mode” and save your file

* run the same chosen block of code repeatedly (perhaps trying out different ways of fixing a bug) without needing to repeat any of the “setup” work that might have been necessary to get to some deeply nested method in the original call stack.<ref name=\"Rebugger\">{{Cite web
column3: title=[ANN] Rebugger: interactive debugging for Julia 0.7/1.0

column1: Work on Julia was started in 2009, by Jeff Bezanson, [[Stefan Karpinski]], [[Viral B. Shah]], and [[Alan Edelman]], who set out to create a free language that was both high-level and fast. On 14 February 2012, the team launched a website with a blog post explaining the language's mission.<ref>{{cite web
column2: last1=Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral Shah, Alan Edelman
column6: accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref>  In an interview with InfoWorld in April 2012, Karpinski said of the name \"Julia\": \"There's no good reason, really. It just seemed like a pretty name.\"<ref>[[Stefan Karpinski]], [https://www.infoworld.com/article/2616709/application-development/new-julia-language-seeks-to-be-the-c-for-scientists.html New Julia language seeks to be the C for scientists], [[InfoWorld]], 18 April 2012</ref> Bezanson said he chose the name on the recommendation of a friend.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Stefan Karpinski and Jeff Bezanson on Julia

column1: Since the 2012 launch, the Julia community has grown, with over 13,000,000 downloads {{as of
column4: lc=y}} (and is used at more than 1,500 universities),<ref>{{Cite web
column18: access-date=2019-02-11}}</ref> The Official Julia Docker images, at [[Docker, Inc.
column19: Docker Hub]], have seen over 4,000,000 downloads as of January 2019.<ref>{{Cite web
column28: accessdate=2018-05-10}}</ref> [[academic conference]] for Julia users and developers has been held annually since 2014.

column1: Version 0.3 was released in August 2014, version 0.4 in October 2015, version 0.5 in October 2016,<ref>[https://julialang.org/blog/ The Julia Blog]</ref> and version 0.6 in June 2017.<ref>https://julialang.org/blog/2017/06/julia-0.6-release</ref>  Both Julia 0.7 (a useful release for testing packages, and for knowing how to upgrade them for 1.0<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=What is Julia 0.7? How does it relate to 1.0?
column6: access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref>) and version 1.0 were released on 8 August 2018. Work on Julia 0.7 was a \"huge undertaking\" (e.g., because of \"entirely new optimizer\"), and some changes were made to semantics, e.g. the [[iteration]] interface was simplified;<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref> and the syntax changed a little (with the syntax now stable, and same for 1.x and 0.7).

column1: The release candidate for Julia 1.0 (Julia 1.0.0-rc1) was released on 7 August 2018, and the final version a day later (and by now, Julia 1.0.x are the oldest versions still supported, having [[long-term support]]; for at least a year). Julia 1.1 was released in January 2019 with, e.g., a new \"exception stack\" language feature. Bugfix releases are expected roughly monthly, for 1.4.x and 1.0.x and Julia 1.0.1 up to 1.0.5 have followed that schedule. Julia 1.2 was released in August 2019, and it has e.g. some built-in support for web browsers (for testing if running in [[JavaScript]] VM),<ref>{{Cite web
column5: quote=Predicate for testing if Julia is running in a JavaScript VM (JSVM), including e.g. a WebAssembly JavaScript embedding in a web browser.
column7: access-date=2019-08-20}}</ref> and Julia 1.4 in March 2020 (and with it Julia 1.3.x, 1.2.x and Julia 1.1.x releases are no longer maintained). Julia 1.3 added e.g. composable multi-threaded parallelism and a binary artifacts system for Julia packages.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: others=Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral Shah, Alan Edelman, et al <!--

column1: Julia 1.4 allowed better syntax for array indexing to handle e.g. [[zero-based_numbering#Usage_in_programming_languages
column3: A[begin+1]}} for '''second''' element of array A.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=support a[begin] for a[firstindex(a)] by stevengj · Pull Request #33946 · JuliaLang/julia
column8: access-date=2020-04-07}}</ref> It also changed the memory model.<ref>{{Cite web

column12: quote=I still keep running into problems that this causes internally because it was a breaking change that changes assumptions made by some users and inference/codegen.

column1: Most packages that work in Julia 1.0.x also work in 1.1.x or newer, enabled by the [[forward compatibility
column2: forward compatible]] syntax guarantee. A major exception was, for interacting with non-Julia code, the JavaCall.jl package (however calling other languages, e.g. [[R (programming language)
column3: R language]] works, with the package for R fixed<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=Fix for C stack checking issues on 1.1 by simonbyrne · Pull Request #293 · JuliaInterop/RCall.jl
column8: access-date=2019-08-10}}</ref>) to call Java, Scala etc. This was fixed by Java 11,<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=StackOverflowError in `JavaCall.init` for Julia 1.1.0 · Issue #96 · JuliaInterop/JavaCall.jl

column25: access-date=2019-08-18}}</ref>), to support older Java, which has-->  Julia 1.4 had a milestone set for 15 December 2019 and for Julia 1.5 the due date is 15 April 2020. Milestones for Julia 2.0 (and later, e.g. 3.0) currently have no set due dates.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: Julia has attracted some high-profile users, from investment manager [[BlackRock]], which uses it for [[time-series analytics]], to the British insurer [[Aviva]], which uses it for [[risk calculations]]. In 2015, the [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York]] used Julia to make models of the United States economy, noting that the language made model estimation \"about 10 times faster\" than its previous [[MATLAB]] implementation. Julia's co-founders established Julia Computing in 2015 to provide paid support, training, and consulting services to clients, though Julia remains free to use. At the 2017 JuliaCon<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2017-06-04}}</ref> conference, Jeffrey Regier, [[Keno Fischer]] and others announced<ref>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=24 June 2017}}</ref> that the Celeste project<ref>{{Cite arXiv
column25: title=Learning an Astronomical Catalog of the Visible Universe through Scalable Bayesian Inference
column28: year=2016}}</ref> used Julia to achieve \"peak performance of 1.54 [[FLOPS
column29: petaFLOPS]] using 1.3 million threads\"<ref>{{Cite press release
column36: quote=Celeste is written entirely in Julia, and the Celeste team loaded an aggregate of 178 terabytes of image data to produce the most accurate catalog of 188 million [[astronomical object]]s in just 14.6 minutes [..] a performance improvement of 1,000x in single-threaded execution.}}</ref> on 9300 <!-- on 9,300 (vs. 8192 Xeon cores\") possibly \"optional nVidia\" GPU cards of Cori are used (or not), unclear conflated with lower numbers? --> [[Knights Landing (microarchitecture)
column37: Knights Landing]] (KNL) nodes of the [[Cray XC40#United States
column38: Cori II (Cray XC40)]] supercomputer (then 6th fastest computer in the world).<ref>{{Cite web
column40: title=. @KenoFischer is speaking on Celeste in the @Intel theatre at @Supercomputing. 0.65M cores, 56 TB of data, Cori - world's 6th largest supecomputer.pic.twitter.com/21nLHo1qty
column46: access-date=2019-09-15}}</ref> Julia thus joins C, C++, and Fortran as high-level languages in which petaFLOPS computations have been achieved.

column1: Three of the Julia co-creators are the recipients of the 2019 [[J. H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software
column2: James H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software]] (awarded every four years) \"for the creation of Julia, an innovative environment for the creation of high-performance tools that enable the analysis and solution of computational science problems.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Julia language co-creators win James H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software
column6: access-date=2019-01-22}}</ref>  Also, Alan Edelman, professor of applied mathematics at MIT, has been selected to receive the 2019 IEEE Computer Society Sidney Fernbach Award \"for outstanding breakthroughs in high-performance computing, linear algebra, and computational science and for contributions to the Julia programming language.\"<ref>{{Cite press release
column8: title=Alan Edelman of MIT Recognized with Prestigious 2019 IEEE Computer Society Sidney Fernbach Award {{!}} IEEE Computer Society

column33: quote=running language interpreters in WebAssembly. To further increase access to leading data science tools, we’re looking for someone to port R or Julia to WebAssembly and to attempt to provide a level 3 language plugin for Iodide: automatic conversion of data basic types between R/Julia and Javascript, and the ability to share class instances between R/Julia and Javascript.
column35: title=Literate scientific computing and communication for the web: iodide-project/iodide
column39: quote=We envision a future workflow that allows you to do your data munging in Python, fit a quick model in R or JAGS, solve some differential equations in Julia, and then display your results with a live interactive d3+JavaScript visualization ... and all that within within a single, portable, sharable, and hackable file.

column1: Julia Computing, Inc. was founded in 2015 by [[Viral B. Shah]], Deepak Vinchhi, [[Alan Edelman]], Jeff Bezanson, [[Stefan Karpinski]] and Keno Fischer.<ref>{{Cite web
In June 2017, Julia Computing raised $4.6M in seed funding from [[General Catalyst]] and [[Founder Collective]].<ref>https://juliacomputing.com/communication/2017/06/19/seed-funding.html</ref>
Though designed for numerical computing, Julia is a [[general-purpose programming language]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: According to the official website, the main features of the language are:
* [[Multiple dispatch]]: providing ability to define function behavior across many combinations of argument types
* [[Dynamic type]] system: types for documentation, optimization, and dispatch
* Good performance, approaching that of [[Type system

column1: It is not like Polyglot. jl does not support this for older Julia (and also interesting project to support other languages, e.g., PHP), but it has not been upgraded for Julia 1.0: Even calling [[recursive]]ly (back and forth) between these languages is possible, without (or with) using ''Polyglot.jl'',<ref name=\"Polyglot\"/> that supports additional languages to Python.

shell]]-like abilities to manage other processes

column1: * User-defined types are as fast and compact as built-ins
* Automatic generation of efficient, specialized code for different argument types
* Elegant and extensible conversions and promotions for numeric and other types
* Efficient support for [[Unicode]], including but not limited to [[UTF-8]]

column2: source=JuliaLang.org}} Only part missing it the MIT part, that is better explained elsewhere.-->

column1: Multiple dispatch (also termed [[multimethod]]s in Lisp) is a [[generalization]] of [[single dispatch]] — the [[Polymorphism (computer science)
column2: polymorphic mechanism]] used in common [[object-oriented programming]] (OOP) languages — that uses [[Inheritance (object-oriented programming)
column3: inheritance]]. In Julia, all concrete types are [[subtyping
column4: subtypes]] of abstract types, directly or indirectly subtypes of the ''Any'' type, which is the top of the type hierarchy. Concrete types can not themselves be subtyped the way they can in other languages; composition is used instead (see also [[Inheritance (object-oriented programming)#Inheritance vs subtyping

column1: Julia draws significant inspiration from various dialects of Lisp<!-- Karpinski: \"In short, I would describe it as a Lisp with Matlab-like syntax\" https://www.reddit.com/r/programming/comments/pv3k9/why_we_created_julia_a_new_programming_language/ -->, including [[Scheme (programming language)
column2: Scheme]] and [[Common Lisp]], and it shares many features with [[Dylan (programming language)
column3: Dylan]], also a multiple-dispatch-oriented dynamic language (which features an [[ALGOL]]-like [[Free-form language
column5: infix]] syntax rather than a Lisp-like prefix syntax, while in Julia \"everything\"<ref name=\"Learn Julia in Y\">{{cite web
column12: Fortress]], another numerical programming language (which features multiple dispatch and a sophisticated parametric type system). While [[Common Lisp Object System]] (CLOS) adds multiple dispatch to Common Lisp, not all functions are generic functions.

column1: In Julia, Dylan, and Fortress extensibility is the default, and the system's built-in functions are all generic and extensible. In Dylan, multiple dispatch is as fundamental as it is in Julia: all user-defined functions and even basic built-in operations like + are generic. Dylan's type system, however, does not fully support parametric types, which are more typical of the [[Generational list of programming languages#ML based
column2: ML lineage of languages]]. By default, CLOS does not allow for dispatch on Common Lisp's parametric types; such extended dispatch semantics can only be added as an extension through the [[Common Lisp Object System#Metaobject Protocol
column3: CLOS Metaobject Protocol]]. By convergent design, Fortress also features multiple dispatch on parametric types; unlike Julia, however, Fortress is statically rather than dynamically typed, with separate compiling and executing phases. The language features are summarized in the following table:

column1: By default, the Julia runtime must be pre-installed as user-provided source code is run. Alternatively, a standalone [[executable]] that needs no Julia source code can be built with ''ApplicationBuilder.jl''<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=GitHub - NHDaly/ApplicationBuilder.jl: Compile, bundle, and release julia software.
column8: title=GitHub - JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl: Compile your Julia Package.

column3: title=Build a standalone executables from a Julia script}}</ref><ref>{{cite newsgroup

column2: syntactic macros]] (used for [[metaprogramming]]), like Lisp macros, are more powerful than [[Macro (computer science)#Text-substitution macros
column3: text-substitution macros]] used in the [[preprocessor]] of some other languages such as C, because they work at the level of [[abstract syntax tree]]s (ASTs). Julia's macro system is [[hygienic macro
column4: hygienic]], but also supports deliberate capture when desired (like for [[anaphoric macro]]s) using the esc construct.

column1: The Julia official distribution includes a \"full-featured interactive command-line REPL\" ([[read–eval–print loop]]),<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=The Julia REPL · The Julia Language
column5: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> with a searchable history, [[tab-completion]], many helpful keybindings, and dedicated help and [[shell (computing)
column8: title=Introducing Julia/The REPL - Wikibooks, open books for an open world
column10: quote=you can install the Julia package OhMyREPL.jl (https://github.com/KristofferC/OhMyREPL.jl) which lets you customize the REPL's appearance and behaviour
column11: access-date=2019-09-22}}</ref> which can be used to experiment and test code quickly.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: access-date=2018-08-15}} The following fragment represents a sample session example where strings are concatenated automatically by println:See also: https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/strings/ for string interpolation and the string(greet, \", \", whom, \".\\n\") example for preferred ways to concatenate strings. Julia has the println and print functions, but also a @printf macro (i.e., not in function form) to eliminate run-time overhead of formatting (unlike the same function in C).

column1: julia> println(\"Hello world!\", \" I'm on cloud \", f(0, 4), \" as Julia supports recognizable syntax!\")
Hello world! I'm on cloud 9 as Julia supports recognizable syntax!

The REPL gives user access to the system shell and to help mode, by pressing ; or ? after the prompt (preceding each command), respectively. It also keeps the history of commands, including between sessions.{{cite web
column5: accessdate=18 November 2014}} Code that can be tested inside the Julia's interactive section or saved into a file with a .jl extension and run from the command line by typing:

column1: Julia is supported by [[Jupyter]], an online interactive \"notebooks\" environment.<ref>{{cite web

column2: interoperable]] with many languages. Julia's <source lang=\"julia\" inline>ccall</source> keyword is used to call C-exported or Fortran shared library functions individually.

column1: Julia has support for [[Unicode 12.1]] (support for current Unicode 13.0 has been implemented<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Unicode 13 support by stevengj · Pull Request #179 · JuliaStrings/utf8proc
column6: access-date=2020-03-29}}</ref> for Julia 1.5), which added only one letter since Unicode 12.0,<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=support for Unicode 12.1.0 by stevengj · Pull Request #32002 · JuliaLang/julia
column11: access-date=2019-05-12}} with [[UTF-8]] used for strings (by default) and for Julia source code (only allowing legal UTF-8 in the latest version), meaning also allowing as an option common math symbols for many operators, such as ∈ for the in operator.

column1: Julia has packages supporting markup languages such as [[HTML]] (and also for [[HTTP]]), [[XML]], [[JSON]] and [[BSON]], and for [[database]]s and Web use in general.

column3: Knet]] implement complete machine-learning frameworks written completely in Julia. [[Apache MXNet]] and [[TensorFlow]] are also available through wrapper libraries. [[Turing (probabilistic programming)
column5: Gen]] implement general-purpose [[probabilistic programming]] languages into Julia. [[Pharmacokinetics
column6: Pharmacokinetic]] modeling and simulations are made available through the [[Pumas (pharmaceutical modeling)

column1: Julia's core is implemented in Julia and [[C (programming language)
column2: C]]<!--C99, except for 0.4 needing C11 because of static asserts-->, together with [[C++]] for the [[LLVM]] dependency. The parsing and code-lowering are implemented in FemtoLisp, a [[Scheme (programming language)
column9: access-date=June 16, 2019}}</ref> The LLVM compiler infrastructure project is used as the [[Compiler#Back end
column10: back end]] for generation of [[64-bit computing
column11: 64-bit]] or [[32-bit]] optimized [[machine code]] depending on the platform Julia runs on. With some exceptions (e.g., [[PCRE]]), the [[standard library]] is implemented in Julia. The most notable aspect of Julia's implementation is its speed, which is often within a factor of two relative to fully optimized C code (and thus often an order of magnitude faster than Python or [[R (programming language)

column2: title        = Julia: A Fast Dynamic Language for Technical Computing
title        = How To Make Python Run As Fast As Julia
title        = Basic Comparison of Python, Julia, R, Matlab and IDL

column1: }}</ref> Development of Julia began in 2009 and an [[Open-source software
column2: open-source]] version was publicized in February 2012.<ref name=\"announcement\">{{cite web
title        = Pure and Julia are cool languages worth checking out

column1: While Julia uses JIT,<!-- Viral states \"Julia no longer uses the MCJIT in LLVM\" so this link is probably misleading:

}}</ref> --> Julia generates native machine code directly, before a function is first run (not [[bytecode]]s that are run on a [[virtual machine]] (VM) or translated as the bytecode is running, as with, ''e.g.'', Java; the [[JVM]] or [[Dalvik (software)
Julia has four support tiers,<ref>{{cite web
column5: access-date=2019-05-17}}</ref> and currently supports all [[x86-64]] processors, that are [[64-bit computing
column7: optimized]] for the latest generations) and all [[IA-32]] (\"x86\") processors except for decades old ones, i.e., in [[32-bit]] mode (\"i686\", excepting CPUs from the pre-[[Pentium 4]]-era); and supports more in lower tiers, e.g., ARM has tier 2 support: Julia \"fully supports ARMv8 (AArch64) processors, and supports ARMv7 and ARMv6 (AArch32) with some caveats.\"<ref>{{cite web
column12: quote=A list of [https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/labels/arm known issues] for ARM is available.
column13: access-date=2019-11-29}}</ref> [[CUDA]] (i.e. Nvidia GPUs; implementing [[Parallel Thread Execution
column14: PTX]]) has tier 1 support, with the help of an [https://github.com/JuliaGPU/CUDAnative.jl external package]. There are also additionally packages supporting other accelerators, such as Google's [[tensor processing unit
column20: access-date=2019-11-29}}</ref> and AMD's GPUs also have support with e.g. [[OpenCL]]. Julia's downloads page provides [[executable]]s (and source) for all the officially supported platforms.

column1: On some platforms, Julia may need to be compiled from [[source code]] (e.g., the original [[Raspberry Pi]]), with specific build options. Julia has been \"successfully built\" <!--on the following ARMv8 devices:

on several ARM platforms, up to, e.g., \"ARMv8 Data Center & Cloud Processors\", such as [https://www.cavium.com/ThunderX_ARM_Processors.html Cavium ThunderX] (first ARM with 48 cores). PowerPC (64-bit) has tier 3 support meaning \"may or may not build\".

column2: POWER8]] (little-endian) has been added recently as of 0.5.1 is available too.<ref>{{cite web

\"only supports ARMv7\" text dropped on master (may apply on older, meaning possibly only for ARMv6?:

\"[[Nightly build]]s are available for ARMv7-A. [..] Note that OpenBLAS only supports ARMv7. For older ARM variants, using the reference BLAS may be the simplest thing to do. [..] Note: These [Raspberry Pi] chips use ARMv6, which is not well supported at the moment. However it is possible to get a working Julia build. [e.g., supported] [[Tegra#Tegra P1
column2: nVidia Jetson TX2]] [with] CUDA functionality\"<ref>{{cite web

column1: The [[Raspberry Pi]] support also includes limited support for [[Raspberry Pi]] 1 (since it has [[ARMv6]]),<ref>{{cite web

column1: Julia is now supported in [[Raspbian]]<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Julia available in Raspbian on the Raspberry Pi
column4: quote=Julia works on all the Pi variants, we recommend using the Pi 3.}}</ref> while support is better for newer Pis, e.g. those with ARMv7 or newer; the Julia support is promoted by the [[Raspberry Pi Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: work=[[Raspberry Pi Foundation]]}}</ref> There's also support for web browsers/[[JavaScript]] through JSExpr.jl;<ref name=\"JSExpr\">{{Cite web
column12: access-date=2019-07-25}}</ref> and the alternative language of web browsers, [[WebAssembly]], has support<ref name=\"WebAssembly\">{{Cite web
column18: access-date=2019-07-25}}</ref> through minimal support in Julia, that supports several upcoming external Julia projects.

column3: ARM]] and [[PowerPC]] and \"fully supports [[ARMv8]] ([[AArch64]]) processors, and supports ARMv7 and ARMv6 (AArch32) with some caveats\"<ref>https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/blob/master/README.arm.md</ref><ref>https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/10791#issuecomment-91735439</ref> and [[PowerPC]] being worked on, with almost no open specific issues,<ref>https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/labels/Power</ref><ref>{{cite web
column6: quote=Wow, the latest git allows me to build to completion.
column8: binaries]] available for [[POWER7]] (\"due to some small support from [[IBM]]\") and [[POWER8]], that are expected to have official beta support as of 0.5 (at least for non-parallel support).<ref>{{cite web
column11: quote=I am hoping we can have beta support from the 0.5 release onwards for sequential julia. We were able to do this work due to some small support from IBM.}}</ref>

column1: Support for [[GNU/kFreeBSD]] and [[GNU Hurd]] is being worked on (in JuliaLang's [[C mathematical functions#libm
column4: title=Fix building tests on GNU/kFreeBSD and GNU/Hurd by ginggs · Pull Request #129 · JuliaLang/openlibm

column1: Yes, openlibm, is not Julia, but is a dependency of it-->

An unofficial Julia-lite,<ref>https://github.com/ScottPJones/julia/tree/spj/lite</ref>a trimmed down fork (by now outdated) is a available. Officially Julia has been dropping dependencies and features from the standard library, to make GPL-free (one left), so it's also the official plan.
Julia can compile to ARM; thus, in theory, [[Android app]]s can be made, but for now only Julia (and most packages) has been made to run under [[Android (operating system)
column2: Android]] indirectly, ''i.e.'', in Ubuntu on Android.<ref>{{Cite web

known_for    = Calculating trajectories for NASA missions

column1: '''Katherine Johnson''' (August 26, 1918 – February 24, 2020) was an American mathematician whose calculations of [[orbital mechanics]] as a [[NASA]] employee were critical to the success of the first and subsequent U.S. crewed spaceflights.<ref name=\"Smith\">{{Cite web
column3: title = Katherine Johnson: The Girl Who Loved to Count
column9: quote = Her calculations proved as critical to the success of the Apollo Moon landing program and the start of the Space Shuttle program, as they did to those first steps on the country's journey into space.
column12: url-status = live}}</ref> During her 35-year career at NASA and its [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics
column13: predecessor]], she earned a reputation for mastering complex manual calculations and helped pioneer the use of computers to perform the tasks. The space agency noted her \"historical role as one of the first [[African-American]] women to work as a NASA scientist\".<ref name=hftmf /><!--\"African American\" should be in the lead, per Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Biographies#Context; it is a part of her WP:Notability.-->

column1: Johnson's work included calculating trajectories, [[launch window]]s, and emergency return paths for [[Project Mercury]] spaceflights, including those for astronauts [[Alan Shepard]], the first American in space, and [[John Glenn]], the first American in orbit, and rendezvous paths for the [[Apollo program
column4: command module]] on flights to the Moon. Her calculations were also essential to  the beginning of the [[Space Shuttle program]], and she worked on plans for [[Exploration of Mars

column1: In 2015, President [[Barack Obama]] awarded Johnson the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]]. In 2016, she was presented the [[Silver Snoopy award
column2: Silver Snoopy Award]] by NASA astronaut [[Leland D. Melvin]] and a [[NASA Group Achievement Award]]. She was portrayed by [[Taraji P. Henson]] as a lead character in the 2016 film ''[[Hidden Figures]]''. In 2019, Johnson was awarded the [[Congressional Gold Medal]].

column1: Johnson was born as Creola Katherine Coleman on August 26, 1918, in [[White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia
column2: White Sulphur Springs]], West Virginia, to Joylette and Joshua Coleman.<ref name=\"NYT\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Katherine Johnson Dies at 101; Mathematician Broke Barriers at NASA
column14: newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name=\"Katherine Johnson - Oral History\">{{Cite web
column22: url-status = live}}</ref> She was the youngest of four children.<ref>{{cite news
column25: title=The Woman the Mercury Astronauts Couldn't Do Without
column33: url-status=live}}</ref> Her mother was a teacher and her father was a lumberman, farmer, and handyman, and worked at the [[The Greenbrier
column34: Greenbrier Hotel]].<ref name=\"Katherine Johnson - Oral History\" /><ref name=\"Gutman\">{{Cite web
column36: title = West Virginian of the Year: Katherine G. Johnson

column1: Coleman showed strong mathematical abilities from an early age. Because [[Greenbrier County, West Virginia
column2: Greenbrier County]] did not offer public schooling for African-American students past the eighth grade, the Colemans arranged for their children to attend high school in [[Institute, West Virginia
column3: Institute]], West Virginia. This school was on the campus of [[West Virginia State University
column6: title=From Hidden to Modern Figures – Katherine Johnson Biography
column14: url-status=live }}</ref> Johnson was enrolled when she was ten years old.<ref name=\"NASA feature\">{{cite web
column16: title=Katherine Johnson: The Girl Who Loved to Count
column21: quote=Fascinated by numbers and smart to boot, for by the time she was 10 years old, she was a high school freshman – a truly amazing feat in an era when school for African-Americans normally stopped at eighth grade for those who could indulge in that luxury. Katherine skipped several grades to graduate from high school at 14 and from college at 18.
column24: url-status=live }}</ref> The family split their time between Institute during the school year and White Sulphur Springs in the summer.<ref>{{Cite web

column3: video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?462474-2/national-history-day-katherine-johnson-quiet-triumph-white-mans-world Interview with West Virginia State University President Anthony Jenkins on Johnson's studies and career, October 21, 2019], [[C-SPAN]]}}

column1: After graduating from high school at 14, Johnson enrolled at West Virginia State, a [[historically black college]].<ref name=\"NASA bio\">{{Cite news
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> As a student, she took every math course offered by the college. Multiple professors mentored her, including the chemist and mathematician [[Angie Turner King]], who had mentored Coleman throughout high school, and [[W. W. Schieffelin Claytor]], the third African-American to receive a Ph.D. in mathematics. Claytor added new mathematics courses just for Johnson.<ref>{{Cite book
column17: title=Hidden Figures: The American Dream and the Untold Story of the Black Women Mathematicians Who Helped Win the Space Race
column23: summa cum laude]]'' in 1937, with degrees in mathematics and French, at age 18.<ref name=\"WVGazetteMail\">{{Cite web
column25: title=WV native, NASA mathematician to receive Presidential Medal of Freedom
column35: title=Katherine G. Johnson – Presidential Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters
column41: quote=Katherine Johnson graduated from high school at age 14 and from college at 18.
column44: url-status=dead }}</ref> Johnson was a member of [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]].<ref>{{Cite web
column46: title=These Two Famous Alpha Kappa Alpha Members Are Getting Their Own Legos
column53: url-status=live}}</ref> She took on a teaching job at a black public school in [[Marion, Virginia
column59: title=Council honors one-time Marion teacher Katherine Johnson of 'Hidden Figures'

column1: In 1939, after marrying her first husband, James Goble, she left her teaching job and enrolled in a graduate math program. She quit after one year after becoming pregnant and choosing to focus on her family.<ref name=\"NASA bio\" /> She was the first African-American woman to attend graduate school at [[West Virginia University]] in [[Morgantown, West Virginia
column2: Morgantown]], West Virginia. Through WVSC's president, Dr. John W. Davis, she became one of three African-American students,<ref name=\"NASA bio\" /> and the only woman, selected to integrate the graduate school after the 1938 United States Supreme Court ruling ''[[Missouri ex rel. Gaines v. Canada]]''. The court ruled that states that provided public higher education to white students also had to provide it to black students, to be satisfied either by establishing black colleges and universities or by admitting black students to previously white-only universities.<ref name=\"Gutman\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column4: title = Missouri ex rel. Gaines v. Canada 305 U.S. 337 (1938)

column3: alt=Photograph of Johnson sitting at a desk
column4: Johnson working as a \"computer\" at NASA in 1966]]

column1: Johnson decided on a career as a research mathematician, although this was a difficult field for African Americans and women to enter. The first jobs she found were in teaching. At a family gathering in 1952, a relative mentioned that the [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics]] (NACA) was hiring mathematicians.<ref name=\"NASA bio\" /> At the [[Langley Research Center
column2: Langley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory]], based in [[Hampton, Virginia
column3: Hampton]], Virginia, near [[Langley Field]], NACA hired African-American mathematicians as well as whites for their Guidance and Navigation Department. Johnson accepted a job offer from the agency in June 1953.<ref name=\"Katherine Johnson - Oral History\" />

column1: According to an oral history archived by the National Visionary Leadership Project:

<blockquote>At first she [Johnson] worked in a pool of women performing math calculations. Katherine has referred to the women in the pool as virtual \"computers who wore skirts\". Their main job was to read the data from the black boxes of planes and carry out other precise mathematical tasks. Then one day, Katherine (and a colleague) were temporarily assigned to help the all-male flight research team. Katherine's knowledge of [[analytic geometry]] helped make quick allies of male bosses and colleagues to the extent that, \"they forgot to return me to the pool\".  While the racial and gender barriers were always there, Katherine says she ignored them. Katherine was assertive, asking to be included in editorial meetings (where no women had gone before). She simply told people she had done the work and that she belonged.<ref name=\"Katherine Johnson - Oral History\" />
From 1953 to 1958, Johnson worked as a [[Human computer
column3: title=She Was a Computer When Computers Wore Skirts
column13: url-status=live }}</ref> analyzing topics such as gust alleviation for aircraft. Originally assigned to the [[West Area Computers]] section supervised by mathematician [[Dorothy Vaughan]], Johnson was reassigned to the Guidance and Control Division of Langley's Flight Research Division. It was staffed by white male engineers.<ref name=\"buckley\" /> In keeping with state racial segregation laws, and federal workplace segregation introduced under President [[Woodrow Wilson]] in the early 20th century, Johnson and the other African-American women in the computing pool were required to work, eat, and use restrooms that were separate from those of their white peers. Their office was labeled as \"Colored Computers\". In an interview with [[WHRO-TV]], Johnson stated that she \"didn't feel the segregation at NASA, because everybody there was doing research. You had a mission and you worked on it, and it was important to you to do your job ... and play bridge at lunch.\" She added: \"I didn't feel any segregation. I knew it was there, but I didn't feel it.\"<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Katherine Johnson Interview: NASA's Human Computer

column1: NACA disbanded the colored computing pool in 1958 when the agency was superseded by NASA, which adopted digital computers. Although the installation was desegregated,<ref name=\"buckley\">{{Cite news
column3: title=On Being a Black Female Math Whiz During the Space Race
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> forms of discrimination were still pervasive. Johnson recalled that era:

column1: <blockquote>We needed to be assertive as women in those days – assertive and aggressive – and the degree to which we had to be that way depended on where you were. I had to be. In the early days of NASA women were not allowed to put their names on the reports – no woman in my division had had her name on a report. I was working with Ted Skopinski and he wanted to leave and go to Houston ... but Henry Pearson, our supervisor – he was not a fan of women – kept pushing him to finish the report we were working on. Finally, Ted told him, \"Katherine should finish the report, she's done most of the work anyway.\" So Ted left Pearson with no choice; I finished the report and my name went on it, and that was the first time a woman in our division had her name on something.<ref>{{Cite book
column6: title=Black Women Scientists in the United States

column1: From 1958 until her retirement in 1986, Johnson worked as an aerospace technologist, moving during her career to the Spacecraft Controls Branch. She calculated the trajectory for the May 5, 1961 space flight of [[Alan Shepard]], the first American in space.<ref name=\"Smith\" /> She also calculated the [[launch window]] for his 1961 [[Project Mercury
column4: title=The Black Female Mathematicians Who Sent Astronauts to Space
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> She plotted backup [[navigation]] [[chart]]s for [[astronaut]]s in case of electronic failures.<ref name=\"Katherine Johnson - Oral History\" /> When NASA used electronic computers for the first time to calculate [[John Glenn]]'s orbit around [[Earth]], officials called on Johnson to verify the computer's numbers; Glenn had asked for her specifically and had refused to fly unless Johnson verified the calculations.<ref name=\"Smith\" /><ref name=\"MakersBio\">{{cite web
column23: title='Hidden Figures' Gives NASA Mathematicians Long Overdue Movie
column29: Biography.com]] states these were \"far more difficult calculations, to account for the gravitational pulls of celestial bodies\".<ref name=\"biography.com\">{{Cite web
column38: url-status=live}}</ref> Author [[Margot Lee Shetterly]] stated, \"So the astronaut who became a hero, looked to this black woman in the still-segregated South at the time as one of the key parts of making sure his mission would be a success.\" She added that, in a time where computing was \"women's work\" and engineering was left to men, \"it really does have to do with us over the course of time sort of not valuing that work that was done by women, however necessary, as much as we might. And it has taken history to get a perspective on that.\"<ref>{{cite web
column40: title='Hidden Figures': How Black Women Did The Math That Put Men on the Moon

column1: Johnson later worked directly with digital [[computer]]s. Her ability and reputation for accuracy helped to establish confidence in the new technology.<ref name=\"biography.com\" /> In 1961, her work helped to ensure that Alan Shepard's ''[[Freedom 7]]'' Mercury capsule would be found quickly after landing, using the accurate trajectory that had been established.<ref name=businside />

column3: alt=Johnson seated in a chair looking to her right

column1: She also helped to calculate the trajectory for the 1969 [[Apollo 11]] flight to the Moon.<ref name=\"Smith\" /><ref name=\"biography.com\" /> During the Moon landing, Johnson was at a meeting in the [[Pocono Mountains]]. She and a few others crowded around a small [[television]] screen watching the first steps on the Moon. In 1970, Johnson worked on the [[Apollo 13]] Moon mission. When the mission was aborted, her work on backup procedures and charts helped set a safe path for the crew's return to Earth,<ref name=\"biography.com\" /> creating a one-star observation system that would allow astronauts to determine their location with accuracy. In a 2010 interview, Johnson recalled, \"Everybody was concerned about them getting there. We were concerned about them getting back.\"<ref name=businside>{{cite web
column3: title=The unbelievable life of the forgotten genius who turned Americans' space dreams into reality
column12: url-status=live }}</ref> Later in her career, Johnson worked on the [[Space Shuttle program]], the Earth Resources Satellite,<ref name=\"Smith\" /><ref name=\"biography.com\" /> and on plans for a [[Exploration of Mars
column16: title=Katherine Johnson, Legendary Mathematician and Inspiration for the Upcoming Film Hidden Figures, Turns 98

column1: Johnson spent her later years encouraging students to enter the fields of [[science, technology, engineering, and mathematics]] (STEM).<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Mathematics pioneer Katherine Johnson, portrayed in 'Hidden Figures,' dies at 101

column1: Katherine and James Francis Goble had three daughters: Constance, Joylette, and Katherine. The family lived in [[Newport News, Virginia
column2: Newport News]], Virginia, from 1953. James died of an inoperable [[brain tumor]] in 1956 and, three years later, Katherine married James A. \"Jim\" Johnson, a [[United States Army]] officer and veteran of the [[Korean War]]; the pair were married for 60 years until his death in March 2019 at the age of 93.<ref name=\"NYT\" /><ref name=\"St Andrews\">{{cite web
column8: website=School of Mathematics & Statistics University of St Andrews, UK
column9: publisher=School of Mathematics & Statistics University of St Andrews, UK
column18: publisher=O.H. Smith & Son Funeral Home}}</ref> Johnson, who had six grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren, lived in [[Hampton, Virginia
column31: url-status=live}}</ref> She encouraged her grandchildren and students to pursue careers in science and technology.<ref>{{Cite web
column33: title=The Untold History of Women in Science and Technology: Katherine Johnson

column1: She was a member of Carver Memorial [[Presbyterian Church (USA)
column4: title=Real life 'Hidden Figures' mathematician is longtime Presbyterian

column1: Johnson died at a retirement home in Newport News on February 24, 2020, at age 101.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title = Local hero, NASA mathematician Katherine Johnson dies at 101
column9: url-status = live}}</ref><ref name=\"NYT\"/> Following her death, [[Jim Bridenstine]], NASA's administrator, described her as \"an American hero\" and stated that \"her pioneering legacy will never be forgotten.\"<ref>{{Cite tweet
column17: title=Our @NASA family is sad to learn the news that Katherine Johnson passed away this morning at 101 years old. She was an American hero and her pioneering legacy will never be forgotten. https://www.nasa.gov/content/katherine-johnson-biography}}</ref>

column3: alt=Johnson seated wearing her Presidential Medal of Freedom
column4: The [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] was awarded to Johnson in 2015.]]

column1: Johnson co-authored 26 scientific papers.<ref name=\"Katherine Johnson - Oral History\" /><ref name=\"NASAHistory\">{{cite web
column8: url-status=live}}</ref> Her social influence as a pioneer in [[Outline of space science
column9: space science]] and [[computing]] is demonstrated by the [[honour
column10: honors]] she received and her status as a [[role model]] for a life in science.<ref name=\"NASAHistory\" /><ref name=\"SCIENCEYEAR\">{{cite web
column12: title=Black history... Katherine G Johnson (1918 – retired)\"
column19: title=Katherine G. Johnson: Physicist, Space Scientist, Mathematician
column24: publisher=Oracle}}</ref> Johnson was named West Virginia State College Outstanding Alumnus of the Year in 1999. President [[Barack Obama]] presented her with the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]], one of 17 Americans so honored on November 24, 2015. She was cited as a pioneering example of African-American women in STEM.<ref>{{cite news
column38: url-status=live}}</ref> President Obama said at the time, \"Katherine G. Johnson refused to be limited by society's expectations of her gender and race while expanding the boundaries of humanity's reach.\"<ref name=\"NYT\" /> NASA noted her \"historical role as one of the first [[African-American]] women to work as a NASA scientist.\"<ref name=\"hftmf\">{{cite web
column40: title=Hidden Figures To Modern Figures: Students See SLS Rocket at Michoud

column5: adj=on}} building was named the \"Katherine G. Johnson Computational Research Facility\" and formally dedicated at the agency's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia. The facility officially opened its doors on September 22, 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Katherine G. Johnson Computational Research Facility Ribbon Cutting
column14: url-status=live}}</ref> Johnson attended this event, which also marked the 55th anniversary of astronaut Alan Shepard's historic rocket launch and splashdown, a success Johnson helped achieve.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=NASA Dedicates Facility to Mathematician, Presidential Medal Winner
column25: url-status=live}}</ref> At the ceremony, deputy director Lewin said this about Johnson: \"Millions of people around the world watched Shepard's flight, but what they didn't know at the time was that the calculations that got him into space and safely home were done by today's guest of honor, Katherine Johnson\". During the event, Johnson also received a [[Silver Snoopy]] award; often called the astronaut's award, NASA stated it is given to those \"who have made outstanding contributions to flight safety and mission success\".<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=Katherine Johnson at NASA Langley Research Center

column1: Johnson was included on the [[BBC]]'s list of [[100 Women (BBC)
column2: 100 Women]] of influence worldwide in 2016.<ref name=\"list2016\">{{cite web
column4: title=BBC 100 Women 2016: Who is on the list?
column10: url-status=live}}</ref> In a 2016 video NASA stated, \"Her calculations proved as critical to the success of the Apollo Moon landing program and the start of the Space Shuttle program, as they did to those first steps on the country's journey into space.\"<ref name=\"Smith\" />

column4: video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?414833-1/margot-lee-shetterly-discusses-hidden-figures Presentation by Margot Lee Shetterly on ''Hidden Figures'' at the Hampton History Museum, September 8, 2016], [[C-SPAN]]
column5: video2 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?432540-28/hidden-figures Discussion with Shetterly on ''Hidden Figures'' at the National Book Festival, September 2, 2017], [[C-SPAN]]}}

column1: The highly acclaimed film ''[[Hidden Figures]]'', released in December 2016, was based on the [[Hidden Figures (book)
column2: non-fiction book]] of the same title by Margot Lee Shetterly, which was published earlier that year. It follows Johnson and other female African-American mathematicians ([[Mary Jackson (engineer)
column3: Mary Jackson]] and Dorothy Vaughan) who worked at NASA. [[Taraji P. Henson]] plays Johnson in the film.<ref name=\"Sloat\" /> Appearing alongside Henson at the [[89th Academy Awards]], Johnson received a standing ovation from the audience.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Katherine Johnson, real-life subject of 'Hidden Figures' receives standing ovation at Oscars
column13: url-status=live }}</ref> In an earlier interview, Johnson offered the following comment about the movie: \"It was well-done. The three leading ladies did an excellent job portraying us.\"<ref>{{cite news
column17: title=Q&A: Our interview with Katherine G. Johnson, the real-life mathematician who inspired 'Hidden Figures'
