column8: n}}) is a city in [[Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column9: Ozaukee County]], [[Wisconsin]], United States. Located on [[Interstate 43]], the community is a [[suburb]] in the [[Milwaukee metropolitan area]]. It [[Municipal corporation
column10: incorporated]] as a [[Administrative divisions of Wisconsin#City
column11: city]] in 1957 to avoid annexation by the City of [[Milwaukee]]. At the time of the [[2010 United States Census

column1: \"Mequon\" may have come from the [[Ojibwe language
column2: Ojibwe]] word \"Emikwaan\" or \"Miguan\", meaning ladle, referring to the shape of the river in the area.<ref>\"[http://www.co.ozaukee.wi.us/history/YankeeSettler.htm \"Yankee Settler's Cottage.\"] {{webarchive
column4: date=2006-04-20}} [[Ozaukee County, Wisconsin]] website</ref> Alternatively, the name may come from an [[Algonquian languages
column5: Algonquin]] word meaning \"feather\", as suggested by the current [[Menominee]] name of the town: ''Mēkon''.<ref>{{Cite web

column4: The 1839 [[Isham Day House]] is now a museum located in Settlers Park.]]

column1: The area was originally inhabited by Native Americans, including the [[Menominee]], [[Potawatomi]], and [[Sauk people]]. In the early 19th century, the   Potawatomi had a village in present-day [[Thiensville, Wisconsin
column2: Thiensville]] located on Pigeon Creek, north of Freistadt Road. In 1831, The Menominee surrendered the land between the [[Milwaukee River]] and [[Lake Michigan]] to the United States Federal Government through the [[Treaty of Washington, with Menominee (1831)
column3: Treaty of Washington]].<ref name= \"corrigan\">Walter D. Corrigan, ''History of the Town of Mequon, Ozaukee County, Wisconsin, Brought Down to about 1870''. Mequon: Mequon Club, 1950.</ref> The Potawatomi surrendered the area of Mequon west of the Milwaukee River in 1833 through the [[Treaty of Chicago]], which required them to leave the area by 1838.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column7: accessdate=2020-01-03}}</ref> While many Native people moved west of the Mississippi River to [[Kansas]], some chose to remain, and were known as \"strolling Potawatomi\" because they were migrant [[Squatting
column8: squatters]]. Eventually the Potawatomi who evaded forced removal gathered in northern Wisconsin, where they formed the [[Forest County Potawatomi Community]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: White trappers, explorers, and traders used the Milwaukee River through the middle of what is now Mequon as a means of transportation. The first permanent white settlers arrived in the mid-1830s from New York, England, and Ireland. One of the first settlers was John Weston, who settled near present-day Thiensville in 1837 and served as the first postmaster of the Town of Mequon. One of the oldest surviving buildings from this period is the [[Isham Day House]], constructed in 1839 on the west bank of the river. The first [[Germans]] arrived in 1839, and in the 1840s Germans became the largest ethnic group in Mequon and Ozaukee County.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin

column1: In October 1839, a party of twenty German families from [[Province of Pomerania (1815–1945)
column2: Pomerania]], [[Prussia]], settled the Freistadt community in the western part of the Town of Mequon. They were [[Old Lutherans]] who had resisted the Prussian government's attempts to take control over the Protestant churches through the [[Prussian Union of Churches]].<ref>Ozaukee County. [http://www.co.ozaukee.wi.us/777/Trinity-Evangelical-Lutheran-Church---Fr Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church - Freistadt]</ref> In German, \"Freistadt\" means \"Free City\".<ref>*[http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/dictionary/index.asp?action=view&term_id=5544 Freistadt] in ''Dictionary of Wisconsin History''</ref>

column1: In 1840, they built a log cabin church, which they named Trinity Lutheran Church. It was the first Lutheran church in Wisconsin. In 1845, what would become the [[Lutheran Synod of Buffalo]] was organized in Freistadt. However, the Freistadt church became a part of the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] in 1848.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column5: accessdate=2020-01-03}}</ref> The wooden church was replaced with a limestone building in 1884.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Joachim Heinrich Thien moved to the area in 1842 from [[Oldenburg]], [[Prussia]], and helped design a plan for the settlement that would become [[Thiensville, Wisconsin
column2: Thiensville]]. A year later he employed a group of Native American laborers to construct a dam and a canal. He then built a sawmill and a store. Thien hosted the first town meeting for the Town of Mequon in 1846,<ref name= \"corrigan\"/> and in 1857 he established the volunteer fire department and served as its first captain.

freethinker]], as were many of the early German settlers. The influence of the freethinker societies kept formal churches out of the village until 1919, when St. Cecilia Catholic Church was built.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Encyclopedia of Milwaukee: Village of Thiensville

column1: Thiensville grew in part because of its location on the [[Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad
column2: Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railway]], which was constructed in the early 1870s. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Thiensville was one of the most concentrated communities in the Town of Mequon. While most of Mequon was quite rural, Theinsville functioned as a downtown area with stores, mills, and professional services. The village of Theinsville incorporated in 1910.

prisoners of war]] from Camp Fredonia in [[Little Kohler, Wisconsin]] were contracted to work at the Herbert A. Nieman Canning Company in the village to make up for the loss of labor due to local men fighting in [[World War II]].<ref>{{Cite book
column4: title=Stalag Wisconsin: Inside WW II Prisoner-of-war Camps
column11: language=en}}</ref> German prisoners from Camp Rockfield in [[Rockfield, Wisconsin]], (located in present-day [[Germantown, Wisconsin
column12: Germantown]]) also worked at the Fromm Bros., Nieman & Co. Fox Ranch in northern Mequon.<ref>{{Cite book
column14: title=Stalag Wisconsin: Inside WW II Prisoner-of-war Camps

column1: In the 20th century, Mequon and the village of Theinsville developed a close relationship,<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=City of Mequon and Village of Thiensville Community Gateway Features {{!}} Mequon Wisconsin
column7: title=Mequon-Thiensville School District {{!}} The Launchpad to Success
column16: title=Frank L. Weyenberg Library of Mequon-Thiensville {{!}} Official Website

column1: The Town of Mequon experienced significant population growth during the [[suburbanization]] that followed World War II. Between 1950 and 1960, the population increased by roughly 110%, from 4,065 to 8,543. With growth came the risk that municipalities such as Thiensville or [[Milwaukee]] would try to annex land from the Town of Mequon, as happened to the Milwaukee County's [[Lake, Milwaukee County, Wisconsin
column2: Town of Lake]] in 1954 and [[Granville, Milwaukee
column3: Town of Granville]] in 1956. With a 1957 population of about 7,500, Mequon incorporated as a city under the terms of Wisconsin statute 66.0215, also known as \"The Oak Creek Law,\" which had been crafted to prevent suburban towns from being annexed by other municipalities.<ref>[http://nxt.legis.state.wi.us/nxt/gateway.dll?f=templates&fn=default.htm&vid=WI:Default&d=stats&jd=66.0215 Wisconsin Legislature Data<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=\"Encyclopedia\">{{cite web
column4: title=Encyclopedia of Milwaukee: City of Mequon

column1: The city continued to grow with the construction of [[Interstate 43]] in the mid-1960s, making travel to Milwaukee easier. Despite being a city, much of Mequon remains rural, and nearly half of the land in the community in undeveloped.

column12: mi}} north of Milwaukee and is part of the [[Milwaukee–Racine–Waukesha Metropolitan Area
column18: title=US Gazetteer files: 2010, 2000, and 1990}}</ref> According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert
column37: archivedate=2012-01-24}}</ref> As of 2005, Mequon was the third-largest city in terms of land area in the state of [[Wisconsin]].<ref>[http://www.lwm-info.org/vertical/Sites/%7B92F7D640-E25A-4317-90AD-4976378A8F8D%7D/uploads/%7B3468C14F-4B58-4594-9571-E14499B23DD9%7D.PDF Estimated Population per Square Mile of Land Area, Wisconsin Municipalities] {{webarchive
column39: date=2011-10-05 }}. The cities of [[Milwaukee]] (96.14 sq mi) and [[Madison, Wisconsin
column40: Madison]] (75.40 sq mi) are larger. Green Bay (45.53 sq mi) is the next largest city. The village of [[Kronenwetter, Wisconsin
column41: Kronenwetter]] is also larger, as are more than 200 [[Political subdivisions of Wisconsin#Town
column42: towns]].</ref> Though much of the population lives in residential areas, approximately half of the land within the city's boundaries is undeveloped or farmed.<ref name=Citywebsite>{{cite web

column2: Village of Thiensville]] is an [[Enclave and exclave
column3: enclave]] in central Mequon. The city is also bordered by the [[Cedarburg (town), Wisconsin
column6: Town of Grafton]] to the north; [[Lake Michigan]] to the east; the [[Bayside, Wisconsin
column8: Village of River Hills]], [[Brown Deer, Wisconsin
column10: City of Milwaukee]] to the south; and the [[Germantown, Wisconsin
column11: Village of Germantown]] to the west.

column3: The clay bluffs in Virmond Park along Lake Michigan]]

column1: The city is located on the western shore of [[Lake Michigan]], and the coastline is characterized by clay [[Cliff
column2: bluffs]] ranging from 80 feet (24 meters) to 140 feet (43 meters) in height with deep [[ravine]]s where streams flow into the lake. Clay bluffs are a geological formation characteristic of the Lake Michigan shoreline, and are found in few other areas of the world. Much of the coast has mixed gravel and sand beaches.<ref name=\"Resources\">{{cite web
column3: title=Inventory of Agricultural, Natural, and Cultural Resources
column7: title=Central Lake Michigan Coastal Ecological Landscape

column1: The city is located in the [[Southeastern Wisconsin Till Plains (ecoregion)
column2: Southeastern Wisconsin glacial till plains]] that were created by the [[Wisconsin glaciation]] during the most recent ice age. The soil is clayey glacial [[till]] with a thin layer of [[loess]] on the surface. The town has some [[limestone]] deposits, including the [[Devonian]] Thiensville formation in north-central Mequon and the [[Silurian]] Little Menomonee River Reef District, which contains [[Dolomite (rock)
column3: dolomite]] marine fossils. The [[Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources]] considers the eastern part of the city along the lake to be in the Central Lake Michigan Coastal ecological landscape, while the western part of the city is in the Southern Lake Michigan Coastal ecological landscape.<ref name=\"Resources\"/>

column1: The [[Milwaukee River]] and its [[tributary]] Pigeon Creek flow through the eastern part of the city. Little Menomonee Creek and the Little Menomonee River, which are tributaries of the [[Menomonee River]], flow through western Mequon.<ref name=\"GR3\"/>
Before white settlers arrived in the area, the Mequon was an upland forest dominated by [[Fagus grandifolia
column3: sugar maple]] trees. There is also a large [[Larix laricina
column4: tamarack]] swamp along the Little Menomonee River. Much of the original forest was cleared to prepare the land for agriculture.<ref name=Resources />

column1: As land development continues to reduce wild areas, wildlife is forced into closer proximity with human communities like Grafton. Large mammals, including [[white-tailed deer]], [[coyotes]], and [[red fox]]es can be seen in the city. Many birds, including [[great blue heron]]s and [[wild turkey]]s are found in the city.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=February 13, 2020}}</ref> The city is also home to many rare and notable species, including the state-designated endangered [[Pterospora
column10: yellow gentian]]; as well as [[Lithospermum latifolium
column12: twinleaf]], which are state-designated special concern plant species.<ref name=Resources />

column1: The region struggles with many invasive species, including the [[emerald ash borer]], [[common carp]], [[Phalaris arundinacea

Mequon experiences four distinct [[season]]s, with variation in precipitation and temperature being very wide. The overall climate of the city is moderated by nearby [[Lake Michigan]], which causes temperatures to be cooler in summer and especially spring, and which keeps overnight temperatures warmer in winter. In March and April, the temperature in Mequon can be 10 to 15 degrees Fahrenheit (5 to 8 degrees Celsius) cooler than temperatures in towns just 15 miles (25 kilometers) farther from the lake.{{Citation needed
column2: date=November 2012}} In December and January, the effect is reversed, with temperatures in inland towns falling much lower.

column1: In Mequon, the warmest month of the year is July, when the high temperature averages 81 °F (27 °C), with low temperatures of approximately 59 °F (15 °C). June and July are the wettest months of the year, with the majority of [[rain]] falling in short-lived [[thunderstorm]]s. January is the coldest month in Mequon, with average high temperatures averaging only 27 °F (-3 °C), and lows averaging 11 °F (-12 °C).<ref name=TWC>{{cite web
column2: title=Average Weather for Mequon, WI - Temperature and Precipitation
column6: accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> February is the driest month, with almost all precipitation falling in the form of [[snow]]. In an average winter, 47.0 in (1.3m) of snow falls. The city's proximity to Lake Michigan often [[lake-effect snow
column7: increases]] the snow received by the city. Most of the city's snowfall comes from systems such as [[Alberta clipper]]s and [[Panhandle hook]]s.{{Citation needed

column1: The highest temperature ever recorded in Mequon was 105 °F (41 °C) on July 24, 1935, and again on July 17, 1995. The coldest temperature ever recorded in the city was -40 °F (-40 °C), on January 17, 1982, also known as [[Cold Sunday]].<ref name=TWC/>

The average household size was 2.56 and the average family size was 2.97.

U.S. Census Bureau estimated the median income for a household in the city in 2009–2011 to be $106,647, and the median income for a family to be $124,422.<ref name=EconStats2011>{{cite web

column1: As of the [[census]]<ref name=\"GR2\" /> of 2000, there were 21,823 people, 7,861 households, and 6,406 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 472.5 people per square mile (182.5/km²). There were 8,162 housing units at an average density of 176.7 per square mile (68.2/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 94.16% [[White (U.S. Census)
column7: other races]], and 0.83% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column9: Latino]] of any race were 1.20% of the population.

column1: There were 7,861 households out of which 38.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.8% were [[Marriage

The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 3.09.

column1: In the city, the population was spread out with 28.1% under the age of 18, 4.2% from 18 to 24, 22.9% from 25 to 44, 31.2% from 45 to 64, and 13.6% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.8 males.

The median income for a household in the city was $90,733, and the median income for a family was $101,793 (These figures had risen to $97,797 and $113,265, respectively, as of a 2007 estimate<ref>[https://archive.today/20200210220131/http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ACSSAFFFacts?_event=Search&geo_id=16000US2735180&_geoContext=01000US%7C04000US27%7C16000US2735180&_street=&_county=mequon&_cityTown=mequon&_state=04000US55&_zip=&_lang=en&_sse=on&ActiveGeoDiv=geoSelect&_useEV=&pctxt=fph&pgsl=160&_submenuId=factsheet_1&ds_name=ACS_2007_3YR_SAFF&_ci_nbr=null&qr_name=null&reg=null:null&_keyword=&_industry= American FactFinder]</ref>). Males had a median income of $72,762 versus $40,280 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $48,333. About 1.3% of families and 1.7% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 1.2% of those under age 18 and 2.7% of those age 65 or over.

column3: Located in rural northwest Mequon, the [[O'Brien-Peuschel Farmstead]] was settled in 1846 and has extant buildings dating to as early as 1850. It is [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column4: listed]] on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].]]

column3: Farmers in eastern Mequon built [[Round barn#Octagonal
column4: octagonal barns]], believing the shape to be better suited to the winds coming off nearby Lake Michigan. The 1891 Frank Vocke barn is a surviving example of these once-common barns.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=The Clausing Octagon Barns of Ozaukee County: An In-Depth Study

column1: Mequon's economy was primarily agricultural. Some farmsteads from as early as the 1840s and 1850s still stand in the community and are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The first major businesses were hydropowered mills on the Milwaukee River and other businesses that served local farmers, many of which concentrated in Thiensville.<ref>{{cite news
Beginning in the 1920s, the Nieman and Fromm families began [[fur farming]] [[Silver fox (animal)
column2: silver foxes]] in Mequon. Several companies, including Fromm Bros., Nieman & Co.; Federal Silver Fox Farms, Inc.; Ozaukee Fur Farms Co.; Herbert A. Nieman & Co.; and Cedarburg Fox Farms, Inc. all began operating in Mequon and southern Cedarburg in the 1920s. In 1928, 6600 of the 8841 pelts sold by the New York Auction Co. came from the Fromm and Nieman operations in Wisconsin for a record-breaking sum of $1,021,000. In 1929, the Nieman and Fromm operations broke their own record with auction sales of $1,331,679, making them a leader in the national fur industry. By 1937, the farms were selling 30,000 pelts per year. After World War II, changing consumer tastes caused the farms to begin breeding [[mink]] in addition to silver fox. Fur sales declined later in the 20th century, and farms sold their last pelts in 1985.<ref>{{cite news

column1: The mid-to-late 20th century saw diversification in Mequon's economy. Retail stores opened to serve the increasingly suburban community, and manufacturers opened plants. In 1983, [[Concordia University Wisconsin]] moved from its campus in Milwaukee to a newly acquired campus in Mequon. In 1994, St. Mary's Hospital Ozaukee opened. As of 2015, the two institutions—both located in close proximity to [[Interstate 43]]—were among the largest employers in Ozaukee County. Despite the growth of new industries, half of Mequon's land remains undeveloped and agriculture continues to play a significant role in the local economy.<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\"/>

column1: The Frank L. Weyenberg Library is a public library serving Mequon and Thiensville. In addition to its collection of physical media, the library provides patrons with digital resources and meeting space. In 2018, the library made 307,796 loans to patrons. The library is a member of the Monarch Library System, comprising thirty-one libraries in Ozaukee, Sheboygan, Washington, and Dodge counties.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Frank L. Weyenberg Library: 2018 Annual Report

column1: The Rincker Memorial Library at Concordia University Wisconsin is a private research library with a collection of over 100,000 physical books and 400 scholarly journals. The Rinker library also has access to an additional 150,000 eBooks and 50,000 electronic periodicals. The university's Arnold H. and Vern L. Moeller Rare Books Room contains a collection of over 300 items dating from the 15th through 19th centuries, primarily related to the historical development of Lutheranism, including texts by [[Augustine of Hippo]], [[Francis Bacon]], [[Martin Luther]] and [[Philipp Melanchthon]].<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Concordia University Wisconsin: Rincker Memorial Library

column1: Wisconsin Lutheran Seminary hosts a private library of primarily theological materials, containing over 50,000 print books and an archive of over 400 publications from a variety of Christian denominations. The seminary owns a collection of rare antique books dating to the 16th through 18th centuries by theologians including [[Johann Wilhelm Baier]], [[Abraham Calovius]], [[Martin Chemnitz]], [[Johann Gerhard]] and Martin Luther.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=The Holy Extraordinary in the Library

column4: listed]] on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].]]

column1: Mequon has had a [[mayor–council government]] since its incorporation in 1957. The current mayor is John Wirth, who was elected to his first three-year term on April 2, 2019. The eight aldermen on the common council also serve three-year terms. The council meets on the second Tuesday of each month in Mequon City Hall at 7:30 p.m. A full-time staff of unelected administrators manage the city's day-to-day operations.<ref>https://www.ci.mequon.wi.us/commoncouncil</ref>
As part of [[Wisconsin's 6th congressional district]], Mequon is represented by [[Glenn Grothman]] (R) in the [[United States House of Representatives]], and by [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)
column2: Ron Johnson]] (R) and [[Tammy Baldwin]] (D) in the [[United States Senate]]. [[Alberta Darling]] (R) represents Mequon in the [[Wisconsin State Senate]]. Eastern Mequon is part of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]]'s 23rd District and is represented by [[Jim Ott]] (R), while western Mequon is part of the 24th District and is represented by [[Dan Knodl]] (R).<ref>{{cite web

column1: Mequon's fire department was founded in 1933. There are two active fire stations in the community: one serving the east side and the other serving the west side. Fire Chief David Bialk has served with the department since 2006 oversees a staff of approximately sixty firefighters, EMTs and paramedics.<ref>{{cite web

The Mequon Police Department was established in 1958 and is located in the City of Mequon Safety Building, which also serves as one of the city's fire stations. Police Chief Patrick Pryor has served with the department since 1999.<ref>{{cite web

column1: \"Mequon\" may have come from the [[Ojibwe language
column2: Ojibwe]] word \"Emikwaan\" or \"Miguan\", meaning ladle, referring to the shape of the river in the area.<ref>\"[http://www.co.ozaukee.wi.us/history/YankeeSettler.htm \"Yankee Settler's Cottage.\"] {{webarchive
column4: date=2006-04-20}} [[Ozaukee County, Wisconsin]] website</ref> Alternatively, the name may come from an [[Algonquian languages
column5: Algonquin]] word meaning \"feather\", as suggested by the current [[Menominee]] name of the town: ''Mēkon''.<ref>{{Cite web

column4: The 1839 [[Isham Day House]] is now a museum located in Settlers Park.]]

column1: The area was originally inhabited by Native Americans, including the [[Menominee]], [[Potawatomi]], and [[Sauk people]]. In the early 19th century, the   Potawatomi had a village in present-day [[Thiensville, Wisconsin
column2: Thiensville]] located on Pigeon Creek, north of Freistadt Road. In 1831, The Menominee surrendered the land between the [[Milwaukee River]] and [[Lake Michigan]] to the United States Federal Government through the [[Treaty of Washington, with Menominee (1831)
column3: Treaty of Washington]].<ref name= \"corrigan\">Walter D. Corrigan, ''History of the Town of Mequon, Ozaukee County, Wisconsin, Brought Down to about 1870''. Mequon: Mequon Club, 1950.</ref> The Potawatomi surrendered the area of Mequon west of the Milwaukee River in 1833 through the [[Treaty of Chicago]], which required them to leave the area by 1838.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column7: accessdate=2020-01-03}}</ref> While many Native people moved west of the Mississippi River to [[Kansas]], some chose to remain, and were known as \"strolling Potawatomi\" because they were migrant [[Squatting
column8: squatters]]. Eventually the Potawatomi who evaded forced removal gathered in northern Wisconsin, where they formed the [[Forest County Potawatomi Community]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: White trappers, explorers, and traders used the Milwaukee River through the middle of what is now Mequon as a means of transportation. The first permanent white settlers arrived in the mid-1830s from New York, England, and Ireland. One of the first settlers was John Weston, who settled near present-day Thiensville in 1837 and served as the first postmaster of the Town of Mequon. One of the oldest surviving buildings from this period is the [[Isham Day House]], constructed in 1839 on the west bank of the river. The first [[Germans]] arrived in 1839, and in the 1840s Germans became the largest ethnic group in Mequon and Ozaukee County.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin

column1: In October 1839, a party of twenty German families from [[Province of Pomerania (1815–1945)
column2: Pomerania]], [[Prussia]], settled the Freistadt community in the western part of the Town of Mequon. They were [[Old Lutherans]] who had resisted the Prussian government's attempts to take control over the Protestant churches through the [[Prussian Union of Churches]].<ref>Ozaukee County. [http://www.co.ozaukee.wi.us/777/Trinity-Evangelical-Lutheran-Church---Fr Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church - Freistadt]</ref> In German, \"Freistadt\" means \"Free City\".<ref>*[http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/dictionary/index.asp?action=view&term_id=5544 Freistadt] in ''Dictionary of Wisconsin History''</ref>

column1: In 1840, they built a log cabin church, which they named Trinity Lutheran Church. It was the first Lutheran church in Wisconsin. In 1845, what would become the [[Lutheran Synod of Buffalo]] was organized in Freistadt. However, the Freistadt church became a part of the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] in 1848.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column5: accessdate=2020-01-03}}</ref> The wooden church was replaced with a limestone building in 1884.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Joachim Heinrich Thien moved to the area in 1842 from [[Oldenburg]], [[Prussia]], and helped design a plan for the settlement that would become [[Thiensville, Wisconsin
column2: Thiensville]]. A year later he employed a group of Native American laborers to construct a dam and a canal. He then built a sawmill and a store. Thien hosted the first town meeting for the Town of Mequon in 1846,<ref name= \"corrigan\"/> and in 1857 he established the volunteer fire department and served as its first captain.

freethinker]], as were many of the early German settlers. The influence of the freethinker societies kept formal churches out of the village until 1919, when St. Cecilia Catholic Church was built.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Encyclopedia of Milwaukee: Village of Thiensville

column1: Thiensville grew in part because of its location on the [[Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad
column2: Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railway]], which was constructed in the early 1870s. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Thiensville was one of the most concentrated communities in the Town of Mequon. While most of Mequon was quite rural, Theinsville functioned as a downtown area with stores, mills, and professional services. The village of Theinsville incorporated in 1910.

prisoners of war]] from Camp Fredonia in [[Little Kohler, Wisconsin]] were contracted to work at the Herbert A. Nieman Canning Company in the village to make up for the loss of labor due to local men fighting in [[World War II]].<ref>{{Cite book

column1: In the 20th century, Mequon and the village of Theinsville developed a close relationship,<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=City of Mequon and Village of Thiensville Community Gateway Features {{!}} Mequon Wisconsin
column7: title=Mequon-Thiensville School District {{!}} The Launchpad to Success
column16: title=Frank L. Weyenberg Library of Mequon-Thiensville {{!}} Official Website

column1: The Town of Mequon experienced significant population growth during the [[suburbanization]] that followed World War II. Between 1950 and 1960, the population increased by roughly 110%, from 4,065 to 8,543. With growth came the risk that municipalities such as Thiensville or [[Milwaukee]] would try to annex land from the Town of Mequon, as happened to the Milwaukee County's [[Lake, Milwaukee County, Wisconsin
column2: Town of Lake]] in 1954 and [[Granville, Milwaukee
column3: Town of Granville]] in 1956. With a 1957 population of about 7,500, Mequon incorporated as a city under the terms of Wisconsin statute 66.0215, also known as \"The Oak Creek Law,\" which had been crafted to prevent suburban towns from being annexed by other municipalities.<ref>[http://nxt.legis.state.wi.us/nxt/gateway.dll?f=templates&fn=default.htm&vid=WI:Default&d=stats&jd=66.0215 Wisconsin Legislature Data<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=\"Encyclopedia\">{{cite web
column4: title=Encyclopedia of Milwaukee: City of Mequon

column1: The city continued to grow with the construction of [[Interstate 43]] in the mid-1960s, making travel to Milwaukee easier. Despite being a city, much of Mequon remains rural, and nearly half of the land in the community in undeveloped.

column12: mi}} north of Milwaukee and is part of the [[Milwaukee–Racine–Waukesha Metropolitan Area
column18: title=US Gazetteer files: 2010, 2000, and 1990}}</ref> According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert
column37: archivedate=2012-01-24}}</ref> As of 2005, Mequon was the third-largest city in terms of land area in the state of [[Wisconsin]].<ref>[http://www.lwm-info.org/vertical/Sites/%7B92F7D640-E25A-4317-90AD-4976378A8F8D%7D/uploads/%7B3468C14F-4B58-4594-9571-E14499B23DD9%7D.PDF Estimated Population per Square Mile of Land Area, Wisconsin Municipalities] {{webarchive
column39: date=2011-10-05 }}. The cities of [[Milwaukee]] (96.14 sq mi) and [[Madison, Wisconsin
column40: Madison]] (75.40 sq mi) are larger. Green Bay (45.53 sq mi) is the next largest city. The village of [[Kronenwetter, Wisconsin
column41: Kronenwetter]] is also larger, as are more than 200 [[Political subdivisions of Wisconsin#Town
column42: towns]].</ref> Though much of the population lives in residential areas, approximately half of the land within the city's boundaries is undeveloped or farmed.<ref name=Citywebsite>{{cite web

column2: Village of Thiensville]] is an [[Enclave and exclave
column3: enclave]] in central Mequon. The city is also bordered by the [[Cedarburg (town), Wisconsin
column6: Town of Grafton]] to the north; [[Lake Michigan]] to the east; the [[Bayside, Wisconsin

column10: City of Milwaukee]] to the south; and the [[Germantown, Wisconsin

column3: The clay bluffs in Virmond Park along Lake Michigan]]

column1: The city is located on the western shore of [[Lake Michigan]], and the coastline is characterized by clay [[Cliff
column2: bluffs]] ranging from 80 feet (24 meters) to 140 feet (43 meters) in height with deep [[ravine]]s where streams flow into the lake. Clay bluffs are a geological formation characteristic of the Lake Michigan shoreline, and are found in few other areas of the world. Much of the coast has mixed gravel and sand beaches.<ref name=\"Resources\">{{cite web
column3: title=Inventory of Agricultural, Natural, and Cultural Resources
column7: title=Central Lake Michigan Coastal Ecological Landscape

column1: The city is located in the [[Southeastern Wisconsin Till Plains (ecoregion)
column2: Southeastern Wisconsin glacial till plains]] that were created by the [[Wisconsin glaciation]] during the most recent ice age. The soil is clayey glacial [[till]] with a thin layer of [[loess]] on the surface. The town has some [[limestone]] deposits, including the [[Devonian]] Thiensville formation in north-central Mequon and the [[Silurian]] Little Menomonee River Reef District, which contains [[Dolomite (rock)
column3: dolomite]] marine fossils. The [[Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources]] considers the eastern part of the city along the lake to be in the Central Lake Michigan Coastal ecological landscape, while the western part of the city is in the Southern Lake Michigan Coastal ecological landscape.<ref name=\"Resources\"/>

column1: The [[Milwaukee River]] and its [[tributary]] Pigeon Creek flow through the eastern part of the city. Little Menomonee Creek and the Little Menomonee River, which are tributaries of the [[Menomonee River]], flow through western Mequon.<ref name=\"GR3\"/>
Before white settlers arrived in the area, the Mequon was an upland forest dominated by [[Fagus grandifolia
column3: sugar maple]] trees. There is also a large [[Larix laricina
column4: tamarack]] swamp along the Little Menomonee River. Much of the original forest was cleared to prepare the land for agriculture.<ref name=Resources />

column1: As land development continues to reduce wild areas, wildlife is forced into closer proximity with human communities like Grafton. Large mammals, including [[white-tailed deer]], [[coyotes]], and [[red fox]]es can be seen in the city. Many birds, including [[great blue heron]]s and [[wild turkey]]s are found in the city.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=February 13, 2020}}</ref> The city is also home to many rare and notable species, including the state-designated endangered [[Pterospora
column10: yellow gentian]]; as well as [[Lithospermum latifolium
column12: twinleaf]], which are state-designated special concern plant species.<ref name=Resources />

column1: The region struggles with many invasive species, including the [[emerald ash borer]], [[common carp]], [[Phalaris arundinacea

Mequon experiences four distinct [[season]]s, with variation in precipitation and temperature being very wide. The overall climate of the city is moderated by nearby [[Lake Michigan]], which causes temperatures to be cooler in summer and especially spring, and which keeps overnight temperatures warmer in winter. In March and April, the temperature in Mequon can be 10 to 15 degrees Fahrenheit (5 to 8 degrees Celsius) cooler than temperatures in towns just 15 miles (25 kilometers) farther from the lake.{{Citation needed
column2: date=November 2012}} In December and January, the effect is reversed, with temperatures in inland towns falling much lower.

column1: In Mequon, the warmest month of the year is July, when the high temperature averages 81 °F (27 °C), with low temperatures of approximately 59 °F (15 °C). June and July are the wettest months of the year, with the majority of [[rain]] falling in short-lived [[thunderstorm]]s. January is the coldest month in Mequon, with average high temperatures averaging only 27 °F (-3 °C), and lows averaging 11 °F (-12 °C).<ref name=TWC>{{cite web
column2: title=Average Weather for Mequon, WI - Temperature and Precipitation
column6: accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> February is the driest month, with almost all precipitation falling in the form of [[snow]]. In an average winter, 47.0 in (1.3m) of snow falls. The city's proximity to Lake Michigan often [[lake-effect snow
column7: increases]] the snow received by the city. Most of the city's snowfall comes from systems such as [[Alberta clipper]]s and [[Panhandle hook]]s.{{Citation needed

column1: The highest temperature ever recorded in Mequon was 105 °F (41 °C) on July 24, 1935, and again on July 17, 1995. The coldest temperature ever recorded in the city was -40 °F (-40 °C), on January 17, 1982, also known as [[Cold Sunday]].<ref name=TWC/>

The [[population density]] was 472.5 people per square mile (182.5/km²). There were 8,162 housing units at an average density of 176.7 per square mile (68.2/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 94.16% [[White (U.S. Census)

The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 3.09.

column1: In the city, the population was spread out with 28.1% under the age of 18, 4.2% from 18 to 24, 22.9% from 25 to 44, 31.2% from 45 to 64, and 13.6% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.8 males.

The median income for a household in the city was $90,733, and the median income for a family was $101,793 (These figures had risen to $97,797 and $113,265, respectively, as of a 2007 estimate<ref>[https://archive.today/20200210220131/http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ACSSAFFFacts?_event=Search&geo_id=16000US2735180&_geoContext=01000US%7C04000US27%7C16000US2735180&_street=&_county=mequon&_cityTown=mequon&_state=04000US55&_zip=&_lang=en&_sse=on&ActiveGeoDiv=geoSelect&_useEV=&pctxt=fph&pgsl=160&_submenuId=factsheet_1&ds_name=ACS_2007_3YR_SAFF&_ci_nbr=null&qr_name=null&reg=null:null&_keyword=&_industry= American FactFinder]</ref>). Males had a median income of $72,762 versus $40,280 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $48,333. About 1.3% of families and 1.7% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 1.2% of those under age 18 and 2.7% of those age 65 or over.

column3: Located in rural northwest Mequon, the [[O'Brien-Peuschel Farmstead]] was settled in 1846 and has extant buildings dating to as early as 1850. It is [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column4: listed]] on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].]]

column3: Farmers in eastern Mequon built [[Round barn#Octagonal
column4: octagonal barns]], believing the shape to be better suited to the winds coming off nearby Lake Michigan. The 1891 Frank Vocke barn is a surviving example of these once-common barns.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=The Clausing Octagon Barns of Ozaukee County: An In-Depth Study

column1: Mequon's economy was primarily agricultural. Some farmsteads from as early as the 1840s and 1850s still stand in the community and are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The first major businesses were hydropowered mills on the Milwaukee River and other businesses that served local farmers, many of which concentrated in Thiensville.<ref>{{cite news
Beginning in the 1920s, the Nieman and Fromm families began [[fur farming]] [[Silver fox (animal)
column2: silver foxes]] in Mequon. Several companies, including Fromm Bros., Nieman & Co.; Federal Silver Fox Farms, Inc.; Ozaukee Fur Farms Co.; Herbert A. Nieman & Co.; and Cedarburg Fox Farms, Inc. all began operating in Mequon and southern Cedarburg in the 1920s. In 1928, 6600 of the 8841 pelts sold by the New York Auction Co. came from the Fromm and Nieman operations in Wisconsin for a record-breaking sum of $1,021,000. In 1929, the Nieman and Fromm operations broke their own record with auction sales of $1,331,679, making them a leader in the national fur industry. By 1937, the farms were selling 30,000 pelts per year. After World War II, changing consumer tastes caused the farms to begin breeding [[mink]] in addition to silver fox. Fur sales declined later in the 20th century, and farms sold their last pelts in 1985.<ref>{{cite news

column1: The mid-to-late 20th century saw diversification in Mequon's economy. Retail stores opened to serve the increasingly suburban community, and manufacturers opened plants. In 1983, [[Concordia University Wisconsin]] moved from its campus in Milwaukee to a newly acquired campus in Mequon. In 1994, St. Mary's Hospital Ozaukee opened. As of 2015, the two institutions—both located in close proximity to [[Interstate 43]]—were among the largest employers in Ozaukee County. Despite the growth of new industries, half of Mequon's land remains undeveloped and agriculture continues to play a significant role in the local economy.<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\"/>

column1: The Frank L. Weyenberg Library is a public library serving Mequon and Thiensville. In addition to its collection of physical media, the library provides patrons with digital resources and meeting space. In 2018, the library made 307,796 loans to patrons. The library is a member of the Monarch Library System, comprising thirty-one libraries in Ozaukee, Sheboygan, Washington, and Dodge counties.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Frank L. Weyenberg Library: 2018 Annual Report

column1: The Rincker Memorial Library at Concordia University Wisconsin is a private research library with a collection of over 100,000 physical books and 400 scholarly journals. The Rinker library also has access to an additional 150,000 eBooks and 50,000 electronic periodicals. The university's Arnold H. and Vern L. Moeller Rare Books Room contains a collection of over 300 items dating from the 15th through 19th centuries, primarily related to the historical development of Lutheranism, including texts by [[Augustine of Hippo]], [[Francis Bacon]], [[Martin Luther]] and [[Philipp Melanchthon]].<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Concordia University Wisconsin: Rincker Memorial Library

column1: Wisconsin Lutheran Seminary hosts a private library of primarily theological materials, containing over 50,000 print books and an archive of over 400 publications from a variety of Christian denominations. The seminary owns a collection of rare antique books dating to the 16th through 18th centuries by theologians including [[Johann Wilhelm Baier]], [[Abraham Calovius]], [[Martin Chemnitz]], [[Johann Gerhard]] and Martin Luther.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=The Holy Extraordinary in the Library

column3: The Jonathan Clark House Museum in northern Mequon is [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column4: listed]] on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].]]

column2: Jonathan Clark House Museum]]''': Built in 1848 by an early Yankee settler from Vermont, the Jonathan Clark House has been restored and furnished to reflect what life was like for Mequon's settlers in the period from 1840 to 1860.<ref>{{cite web

column1: * '''Postal Museum''': Housed in the 1839 [[Isham Day House]] on the west bank of the Milwaukee River, the Mequon-Thiensville Historical Society maintains the building as a replica of a 19th century post office and also displays a stamp collection.<ref>{{cite web

column7: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> The museum opened to the public in 2019, and admission is free.<ref>{{cite web

column1: Mequon has had a [[mayor–council government]] since its incorporation in 1957. The current mayor is John Wirth, who was elected to his first three-year term on April 2, 2019. The eight aldermen on the common council also serve three-year terms. The council meets on the second Tuesday of each month in Mequon City Hall at 7:30 p.m. A full-time staff of unelected administrators manage the city's day-to-day operations.<ref>https://www.ci.mequon.wi.us/commoncouncil</ref>
As part of [[Wisconsin's 6th congressional district]], Mequon is represented by [[Glenn Grothman]] (R) in the [[United States House of Representatives]], and by [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)
column2: Ron Johnson]] (R) and [[Tammy Baldwin]] (D) in the [[United States Senate]]. [[Alberta Darling]] (R) represents Mequon in the [[Wisconsin State Senate]]. Eastern Mequon is part of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]]'s 23rd District and is represented by [[Jim Ott]] (R), while western Mequon is part of the 24th District and is represented by [[Dan Knodl]] (R).<ref>{{cite web

column1: Mequon's fire department was founded in 1933. There are two active fire stations in the community: one serving the east side and the other serving the west side. Fire Chief David Bialk has served with the department since 2006 oversees a staff of approximately sixty firefighters, EMTs and paramedics.<ref>{{cite web

The Mequon Police Department was established in 1958 and is located in the City of Mequon Safety Building, which also serves as one of the city's fire stations. Police Chief Patrick Pryor has served with the department since 1999.<ref>{{cite web

In 2009, Homestead was ranked by ''BusinessWeek'' magazine as the state's top high school.<ref>[http://images.businessweek.com/ss/09/01/0115_best_schools/51.htm American's Best High Schools], ''Bloomberg Businesweek''.</ref> The school's mascot is a Highlander.<ref>{{cite web

arrival_date = 29 February 2020
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days
legend1         = Confirmed COVID-19 cases per capita in [[Asturias]] by municipality as of 7 April: {{legend

column1: {{2019-20 coronavirus pandemic data/Asturias medical cases chart}}
The '''2020 coronavirus pandemic in Asturias''' is part of the [[2020 coronavirus pandemic in Spain
column2: Spanish outbreak]] of the ongoing worldwide [[2019-20 coronavirus pandemic

column1: As of 12 April 2020, there have been 1,958 confirmed cases with 434 recoveries and 149 deaths in [[Asturias]] according to authorities. 61 hospitalised people are currently in intensive care and 23,046 tests for COVID-19 have been conducted.<ref name=\"current\" />

On 24 February, a first suspected case was detected after a 25-year-old woman that came from [[Venice]] entered the San Agustín University Hospital, [[Avilés]], and was later evacuated to the Central University Hospital of Asturias (HUCA) in [[Oviedo]]. However, after that she was diagnosed with ''[[mycoplasma]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Los análisis del HUCA descartan el caso de coronavirus en una avilesina llegada de Venecia}}</ref>

column1: The first confirmed case of [[coronavirus disease 2019
column2: COVID-19]] in [[Asturias]] was found on 29 February 2020, when Chilean writer [[Luis Sepúlveda]] went to a private healthcare center in [[Gijón]] and tested positive for [[SARS-CoV-2]] following a trip to Portugal.<ref name=\"Case 1\">{{cite web
column8: title=Asturias registra el primer caso positivo de coronavirus}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
column10: title=El escritor chileno Luis Sepúlveda, primer afectado por coronavirus en Asturias

column1: The second and third confirmed cases of the disease in the region were found on 3 March. A 30-year old from [[Llanes]]<ref name=\"Case 2 and 3\">{{cite news
column3: title=Segundo caso positivo de Coronavirus en Asturias
column11: title=Salud detecta un tercer positivo de Covid-19 en Asturias

column1: The fourth case was reported on 4 March<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Asturias confirma su cuarto positivo en Coronavirus, un hombre de 48 años
column8: language=es}}</ref> and in the following days, three new cases related to the [[Torrejón de Ardoz]] cluster were reported.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Un gijonés de 48 años, quinto caso de coronavirus en Asturias
column18: title=Confirmados dos nuevos positivos en Asturias que elevan a siete los pacientes con COVID-19

column4: Fundación Masaveu school, in Oviedo, was one the first educational centers to be closed.]]

column1: On 10 March, a positive case was detected in [[Grado, Asturias
column2: Grado]], referring to a coach of one of the youth teams of football club [[CD Mosconia]] who was infected at Fundación Masaveu School in [[Oviedo]]. On this day, the Principality of Asturias ordered the closure of the four schools in [[Oviedo]] and another in Grado with positive cases detected.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=El Principado ordena el cierre de los cinco colegios afectados por los primeros casos de coronavirus en niños}}</ref> One day later, the region registered its first death due to coronavirus: a connected with the outbreak at Fundación Masaveu.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Primera muerte por coronavirus en Asturias}}</ref>

column1: On 12 March, the [[Government of the Principality of Asturias]] extended the cancellation of classes at all educational levels in the region.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=El Consejo de Gobierno acordará esta tarde el cierre temporal durante 14 días naturales de todos los centros educativos del Principado.
column6: language=Spanish}}</ref> Two days later, Asturias closed all shops except those selling food and basic necessities, and this measure was extended in all Spain on 14 March, after the imposition of a 14-day national lockdown by the Spanish government, banning all trips that are not force majeure and announcing it may intervene with companies to guarantee supplies.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Spain to impose nationwide lockdown – El Mundo | National Post
column13: title=El Gobierno prohíbe todos los viajes que no sean de fuerza mayor

column1: On 15 March it was reported that hospitals Álvarez-Buylla in [[Mieres]] and San Agustín in [[Avilés]] will support HUCA to allow positive cases, while Cabueñes in [[Gijón]] and Valle del Nalón in [[Langreo]] will house people affected by other diseases.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Los hospitales de Avilés y Mieres apoyarán al HUCA en la atención a los infectados por el virus
column6: language=es}}</ref> However, finally all Asturian hospitals hosted positives cases.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Las camas de UCI aún libres en Asturias, un \"oasis\" en un país que roza el colapso}}</ref>

column1: On 23 March, a 56-year-old woman who had recovered from the virus was the first positive case to leave the intensive care unit.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Primera paciente con coronavirus dada de alta de la UCI del HUCA}}</ref>

column1: On 24 March, a baby was born in the HUCA from a mother with the disease. He was not infected.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Nace en el HUCA el primer niño de una madre con coronavirus

column1: On 26 March, the installation of a field hospital in the central pavilion of the Asturias International Trade Fair was announced, lightening the load of the Cabueñes Hospital in Gijón. The municipality of [[Carreño]] sent 100 mattresses as help.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Carreño cede 100 colchones para el hospital de campaña de la Feria de Muestras de Gijón}}</ref>

column1: On 27 March, Asturias passed the 1,000 positive cases, with 4,125 more people with possible symptoms being tracked via the telephone.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Asturias supera el millar de casos positivos
column7: language=es}}</ref> On this day, the Ministry of Health announced massive testings in Asturian nursing homes, the main cluster of the disease in Asturias.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Salud inicia hoy pruebas masivas en los geriátricos públicos y privados de Asturias}}</ref>

column1: On 28 March, President [[Adrián Barbón]] suggested to the central government that the quarantine should be toughened. His call was answered, as all non-essential activities were thenceforth ceased until 9 April.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Cierre total: construcción e industria \"no esencial\" paran desde mañana}}</ref> However, the Asturian government was negotiating with Madrid about the continuation of the region's heavy industry, hoping to avoid its bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Asturias pacta el rescate de 30 industrias y sus auxiliares en mitad del caos
column12: language=es}}</ref> In addition, several of the town councils of Asturias, such as [[Valdés, Asturias
column13: Valdés]] or [[Cudillero]], approved their own restrictions by forbidding tourism in the whole municipality with the aim of controlling the disease.<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Ya hay bandos para todo: para limitar la compra, los paseos del perro o las visitas}}</ref>

column1: On 29 March, the second positive case left the Intensive Care Unit of the HUCA.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Segundo paciente dado de alta de la UCI del HUCA}}</ref> One day later, in Grado, a 95-year-old man became the first person to recover at a nursing home.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Primer alta en geriátricos: un hombre de 95 años de la residencia de Grado supera el coronavirus}}</ref>

column1: [[File:Edificio Histórico de la Universidad de Oviedo.JPG
column3: Historic building of the [[University of Oviedo]].]]

column1: On 1 April, the [[University of Oviedo]] offered the nursing students in the final year to finish their degree prematurely so they could work as soon as possible against the coronavirus.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Llamada a los estudiantes: \"En este momento crítico necesitamos enfermeros con ganas e ilusión\"}}</ref>

column1: On 3 April, a nursing home in [[Mallecina]], [[Salas, Asturias
column2: Salas]], was totally evacuated after two deaths and nearly all the residents testing positive. They were moved to the Referral Center for People with Neurological Disabilities in [[Barros, Asturias
column3: Barros]], [[Langreo]], and to the HUCA.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Salud desaloja una residencia privada en Salas y traslada a los ancianos a Langreo
column8: language=es}}</ref> It was also reported that about 5,500 people are being tracked via the telephone without being previously tested.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=La cifra de asturianos en seguimiento en casa por coronavirus sube a 5.500}}</ref>

column1: On 4 April, it was reported that Asturias will increase the daily tests performed to 3,000, by using the Animal Health Laboratory of Gijón and the Inter-Profession Dairy Laboratory of [[Llanera, Asturias
column7: title=Asturias triplicaría los test de COVID-19 sumando laboratorios de sanidad animal}}</ref> On the same day, Spanish Prime Minister [[Pedro Sánchez (politician)
column8: Pedro Sánchez]] announced the extension of the state of alarm, under the initial conditions, until 26 April, with the possibility to extend it for additional weeks, but relaxing some conditions.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Pedro Sánchez: \"Vamos a tener sucesivos estados de alarma hasta recuperar la cotidianidad\"}}</ref> However, industrial activities and construction could resume their activities after 9 April.<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=El día 9, fin al parón industrial decretado hace una semana

column1: 7 April was the first day that the active cases decreased since the start of the pandemic in the region. Also on this day, Asturias surpassed 100 deaths and achieved a new record of recoveries with 50.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Asturias supera las 100 muertes pero consigue récord en curaciones en un día
column6: url=https://www.elcomercio.es/sociedad/coronavirus-jornada-record-curaciones-asturias-20200407210452-nt.html}}</ref> Two days later, it was confirmed that in the nursing home of Grado, the main cluster of Asturias, 43 people recovered from the disease.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=El geriátrico de Grado, el más golpeado por el coronavirus, vive sus mejores horas con 43 curaciones}}</ref>

column1: On 8 April, José Manuel Fernández Tamargo, from [[Yernes y Tameza]], became the first mayor of Asturias to be tested positive.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=El Alcalde de Yernes y Tameza, el primer regidor a}}</ref>

column1: The installation of the field hospital at the central pavilion of the Asturias International Trade Fair, in Gijón, was finished on 10 April. It has 114 beds for mild patients. President Adrián Barbón highlighted this was prepared in advance, as in that moment the hospitals are 50% occupied.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=El pabellón central, un hospital de 144 camas

column1: On 13 April, coinciding with the come back of non-essential works, the security forces distributed [[respirator]]s for public transport users in the main stations of the region.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Normalidad en las estaciones de transporte público asturiano durante el reparto de cientos de miles de mascarillas}}</ref>

column1: The [[Asturian derby]], the football match between [[Sporting de Gijón
column2: Real Sporting]] and [[Real Oviedo]] that was to be played on 29 February at [[El Molinón]] stadium, [[Gijón]], was suspended.

column1: On 12 March, the president of the Court of Justice of Asturias announced the matter of suspending jury trials.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=El TSJA sopesa suspender juicios con jurado popular para evitar riesgos}}</ref>

column1: From 13 March, the Asturian Federation of Entrepreneurs demanded immediate measures, warning that revenue is decreasing about 25%.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=La patronal asturiana pide medidas \"inmediatas\"}}</ref> On 7 April, this federation reported that the economic activity had reduced by 60% in the whole region, especially in construction (95%), and that 600 jobs are destroyed each day.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=El crack económico del COVID-19: Asturias pierde 600 empleos y 33 millones de euros al día}}</ref>

column1: On 18 March, [[ArcelorMittal]], the biggest industry located in Asturias, announced a Record of Temporary Employment Regulation (RTER) and the halting of part of its activities.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=ArcelorMittal anuncia un ERTE y la parada de parte de sus instalaciones en Asturias}}</ref> It was reported that during the whole month of March 2,286 of the 9,170 RTERs requested were processed, concerning around 8,000 workers.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Asturias ya tiene 7.940 trabajadores en regulación de empleo

column1: On 30 March, the [[University of Oviedo]] announced that the academic year will finish by giving lessons online.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=La Universidad de Oviedo acabará el curso online}}</ref>

column1: During the month of March, 4,511 Asturians became unemployed, the worst number in a month of March for the previous 30 years.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Asturias se enfrenta al peor registro de paro en treinta años}}</ref>

column1: The University Access Tests ([[Selectividad]]) were moved and set from 30 June to 2 July.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=La prueba de acceso a la Universidad se celebrará los días 30 de junio y 1 y 2 de julio}}</ref>

column1: On 13 April, the [[Government of the Principality of Asturias]] started to pay €400 regional aids for self-employed workers and small businesses.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=10.000 autónomos están llamados a solicitar la ayuda directa del Principado de 400 euros}}</ref>

column1: [[File:Mieres. Hospital Álvarez-Buylla. Julio Vázquez. Asociación Semeya.jpg

Since 20 March, data is given daily by the Asturian Ministry of Health at 21:00. This data is published the next day by the Spanish Ministry of Health. Data about nursing homes is given by the Asturian Ministry of Social Services at 19:00.

column4: Confirmed COVID-19 cases in Asturias by day (March)}}

column5: Only one death is counted instead of three as the deaths from nursing homes are counted by the Ministry of Social Rights instead of the Ministry of Health, which only counts a death if it tested positive two times.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Asturias, en curva descendente: vuelven a bajar los contagios por coronavirus }}</ref>}} '''70'''

column4: Confirmed COVID-19 cases in nursing homes by day}}

column9: title=Las residencias geriátricas públicas ya sobrepasan el centenar de contagios}}</ref>

column8: title=Un nuevo fallecimiento en Grado eleva a once las muertes en la red geriátrica asturiana}}</ref>
title=Se eleva a 17 el numero de fallecidos en residencias asturianas}}</ref>
title=Más de una veintena de fallecidos en las residencias de mayores asturianas}}</ref>
title=Los geriátricos asturianos ya tienen 25 profesionales contagiados y suman 25 ancianos fallecidos}}</ref>

column7: title=La epidemia se sigue cebando en el geriátrico de Grado, con dos fallecidos más, y aumenta el contagio de trabajadores de las residencias, con otros diez

column8: title=La cifra de positivos en los geriátricos ya rebasa los 200 mayores}}</ref>

column9: After doing a test, it was confirmed that one of the deaths on 1 April was wrongly diagnosed by coronavirus.}} 6
title=Tres nuevos fallecimientos en las residencias del ERA eleva a 31 los muertos en la red geriátrica}}</ref>
title=La red geriátrica asturiana roza los 350 contagios}}</ref>

column8: title=Los geriátricos asturianos suman cuatro nuevas muertes, una de ellas es la primera en el Clara Ferrer, en Gijón}}</ref>

title=La red geriátrica asturiana suma dos muertes y llega a 45 fallecidos por coronavirus}}</ref>
title=La red pública geriátrica asturiana registra cinco muertes en un solo día}}</ref>

column3: All data are later verified by the Service of Epidemiology of the Ministry of Health.

column1: Since 9 April, data are registered at the official website of the Asturian Ministry of Social Services and Welfare.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Situación actual: centros de alojamiento residenciales}}</ref>

column1: On 10 April, the Government of the Principality of Asturias reported a chart of cases per municipality.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=El coronavirus, concejo a concejo: 19 municipios asturianos están libres de COVID-19 y siete tienen más de 40 casos}}</ref>

column1: [[Oviedo]], the second biggest municipality, was the city with most cases while [[Grado, Asturias
column2: Grado]] was the location with the highest ratio of infection per capita.

column1: On 15 March it was reported that hospitals Álvarez-Buylla in [[Mieres]] and San Agustín in [[Avilés]] will support HUCA to allow positive cases, while Cabueñes in [[Gijón]] and Valle del Nalón in [[Langreo]] will house people affected by other diseases.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Los hospitales de Avilés y Mieres apoyarán al HUCA en la atención a los infectados por el virus
column6: language=es}}</ref> However, finally all Asturian hospitals hosted positives cases.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Las camas de UCI aún libres en Asturias, un \"oasis\" en un país que roza el colapso}}</ref>

column1: On 23 March, a 56-year-old woman who had recovered from the virus was the first positive case to leave the intensive care unit.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Primera paciente con coronavirus dada de alta de la UCI del HUCA}}</ref>

column1: On 24 March, a baby was born in the HUCA from a mother with the disease. He was not infected.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Nace en el HUCA el primer niño de una madre con coronavirus

column1: On 26 March, the installation of a field hospital in the central pavilion of the Asturias International Trade Fair was announced, lightening the load of the Cabueñes Hospital in Gijón. The municipality of [[Carreño]] sent 100 mattresses as help.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Carreño cede 100 colchones para el hospital de campaña de la Feria de Muestras de Gijón}}</ref>

column1: On 27 March, Asturias passed the 1,000 positive cases, with 4,125 more people with possible symptoms being tracked via the telephone.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Asturias supera el millar de casos positivos
column7: language=es}}</ref> On this day, the Ministry of Health announced massive testings in Asturian nursing homes, the main cluster of the disease in Asturias.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Salud inicia hoy pruebas masivas en los geriátricos públicos y privados de Asturias}}</ref>

column1: On 28 March, President [[Adrián Barbón]] suggested to the central government that the quarantine should be toughened. His call was answered, as all non-essential activities were thenceforth ceased until 9 April.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Cierre total: construcción e industria \"no esencial\" paran desde mañana}}</ref> However, the Asturian government was negotiating with Madrid about the continuation of the region's heavy industry, hoping to avoid its bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Asturias pacta el rescate de 30 industrias y sus auxiliares en mitad del caos
column12: language=es}}</ref> In addition, several of the town councils of Asturias, such as [[Valdés, Asturias
column13: Valdés]] or [[Cudillero]], approved their own restrictions by forbidding tourism in the whole municipality with the aim of controlling the disease.<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=Ya hay bandos para todo: para limitar la compra, los paseos del perro o las visitas}}</ref>

column1: On 29 March, the second positive case left the Intensive Care Unit of the HUCA.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Segundo paciente dado de alta de la UCI del HUCA}}</ref> One day later, in Grado, a 95-year-old man became the first person to recover at a nursing home.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Primer alta en geriátricos: un hombre de 95 años de la residencia de Grado supera el coronavirus}}</ref>

column1: [[File:Edificio Histórico de la Universidad de Oviedo.JPG
column3: Historic building of the [[University of Oviedo]].]]

column1: On 1 April, the [[University of Oviedo]] offered the nursing students in the final year to finish their degree prematurely so they could work as soon as possible against the coronavirus.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Llamada a los estudiantes: \"En este momento crítico necesitamos enfermeros con ganas e ilusión\"}}</ref>

column1: On 3 April, a nursing home in [[Mallecina]], [[Salas, Asturias
column2: Salas]], was totally evacuated after two deaths and nearly all the residents testing positive. They were moved to the Referral Center for People with Neurological Disabilities in [[Barros, Asturias
column3: Barros]], [[Langreo]], and to the HUCA.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Salud desaloja una residencia privada en Salas y traslada a los ancianos a Langreo
column8: language=es}}</ref> It was also reported that about 5,500 people are being tracked via the telephone without being previously tested.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=La cifra de asturianos en seguimiento en casa por coronavirus sube a 5.500}}</ref>

column1: On 4 April, it was reported that Asturias will increase the daily tests performed to 3,000, by using the Animal Health Laboratory of Gijón and the Inter-Profession Dairy Laboratory of [[Llanera, Asturias
column7: title=Asturias triplicaría los test de COVID-19 sumando laboratorios de sanidad animal}}</ref> On the same day, Spanish Prime Minister [[Pedro Sánchez (politician)
column8: Pedro Sánchez]] announced the extension of the state of alarm, under the initial conditions, until 26 April, with the possibility to extend it for additional weeks, but relaxing some conditions.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Pedro Sánchez: \"Vamos a tener sucesivos estados de alarma hasta recuperar la cotidianidad\"}}</ref> However, industrial activities and construction could resume their activities after 9 April.<ref>{{cite web
column18: title=El día 9, fin al parón industrial decretado hace una semana

column1: 7 April was the first day that the active cases decreased since the start of the pandemic in the region. Also on this day, Asturias surpassed 100 deaths and achieved a new record of recoveries with 50.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Asturias supera las 100 muertes pero consigue récord en curaciones en un día
column6: url=https://www.elcomercio.es/sociedad/coronavirus-jornada-record-curaciones-asturias-20200407210452-nt.html}}</ref> Two days later, it was confirmed that in the nursing home of Grado, the main cluster of Asturias, 43 people recovered from the disease.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=El geriátrico de Grado, el más golpeado por el coronavirus, vive sus mejores horas con 43 curaciones}}</ref>

column1: On 8 April, José Manuel Fernández Tamargo, from [[Yernes y Tameza]], became the first mayor of Asturias to be tested positive.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=El Alcalde de Yernes y Tameza, el primer regidor a}}</ref>

column1: The installation of the field hospital at the central pavilion of the Asturias International Trade Fair, in Gijón, was finished on 10 April. It has 114 beds for mild patients. President Adrián Barbón highlighted this was prepared in advance, as in that moment the hospitals are 50% occupied.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=El pabellón central, un hospital de 144 camas

column1: On 13 April, coinciding with the come back of non-essential works, the security forces distributed [[respirator]]s for public transport users in the main stations of the region.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Normalidad en las estaciones de transporte público asturiano durante el reparto de cientos de miles de mascarillas}}</ref>

column1: The [[Asturian derby]], the football match between [[Sporting de Gijón
column2: Real Sporting]] and [[Real Oviedo]] that was to be played on 29 February at [[El Molinón]] stadium, [[Gijón]], was suspended.

column1: On 12 March, the president of the Court of Justice of Asturias announced the matter of suspending jury trials.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=El TSJA sopesa suspender juicios con jurado popular para evitar riesgos}}</ref>

column1: From 13 March, the Asturian Federation of Entrepreneurs demanded immediate measures, warning that revenue is decreasing about 25%.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=La patronal asturiana pide medidas \"inmediatas\"}}</ref> On 7 April, this federation reported that the economic activity had reduced by 60% in the whole region, especially in construction (95%), and that 600 jobs are destroyed each day.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=El crack económico del COVID-19: Asturias pierde 600 empleos y 33 millones de euros al día}}</ref>

column1: On 18 March, [[ArcelorMittal]], the biggest industry located in Asturias, announced a Record of Temporary Employment Regulation (RTER) and the halting of part of its activities.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=ArcelorMittal anuncia un ERTE y la parada de parte de sus instalaciones en Asturias}}</ref> It was reported that during the whole month of March 2,286 of the 9,170 RTERs requested were processed, concerning around 8,000 workers.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Asturias ya tiene 7.940 trabajadores en regulación de empleo

column1: On 30 March, the [[University of Oviedo]] announced that the academic year will finish by giving lessons online.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=La Universidad de Oviedo acabará el curso online}}</ref>

column1: During the month of March, 4,511 Asturians became unemployed, the worst number in a month of March for the previous 30 years.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Asturias se enfrenta al peor registro de paro en treinta años}}</ref>

column1: The University Access Tests ([[Selectividad]]) were moved and set from 30 June to 2 July.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=La prueba de acceso a la Universidad se celebrará los días 30 de junio y 1 y 2 de julio}}</ref>

column1: On 13 April, the [[Government of the Principality of Asturias]] started to pay €400 regional aids for self-employed workers and small businesses.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=10.000 autónomos están llamados a solicitar la ayuda directa del Principado de 400 euros}}</ref>

column1: [[File:Mieres. Hospital Álvarez-Buylla. Julio Vázquez. Asociación Semeya.jpg

Since 20 March, data is given daily by the Asturian Ministry of Health at 21:00. This data is published the next day by the Spanish Ministry of Health. Data about nursing homes is given by the Asturian Ministry of Social Services at 19:00.

[[Category:2020 coronavirus pandemic in Spain by autonomous community
The relations between the [[Greece]] and the [[Turkey]] states have been marked by alternating periods of mutual hostility and reconciliation ever since Greece won its [[Greek War of Independence
column2: independence]] from the [[Ottoman Empire]] in [[Treaty of Constantinople (1832)
column3: 1832]]. Since then the two countries have faced each other in four major wars—the [[Greco-Turkish War (1897)]], the [[First Balkan War]] of 1912 to 1913, the [[World War I
column4: First World War]] (1914 to 1918) and finally the [[Greco-Turkish War (1919–22)]], which were followed by the [[Greco-Turkish population exchange]] and a period of friendly relations in the 1930s and 1940s. Both countries entered [[NATO]] in 1952. Relations deteriorated again in the 1950s due to the [[Cyprus issue]], the [[1955 Istanbul pogrom]] and the expulsion of the Istanbul Greeks in the 1960s, the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus]] in 1974, and subsequent military confrontations over the [[Aegean dispute]]. A period of relative normalization began after 1999 with the so-called \"[[Greek–Turkish earthquake diplomacy
column5: earthquake diplomacy]]\", which notably led to a change in the previously firmly negative stance of the Greek government on the issue of the [[accession of Turkey to the European Union]].

column1: *Turkey has an embassy in [[Athens]] and consulates general in [[Thessaloniki]], [[Komotini]] and [[Rhodes]].
*Greece has an embassy in [[Ankara]] and consulates general in [[Istanbul]], [[İzmir]] and [[Edirne]].

column4: Byzantine territory]] (purple), Byzantine campaigns (red) and [[Great Seljuq Empire

column3: Byzantines]] (Greeks were dominant nation of the Byzantine Empire and the Empire was Hellenized) started. Many [[Byzantine–Seljuq wars
column4: wars and battles]] were fought between the Byzantine and the Seljuq armies. Also, in 1300 conflicts between [[Ottomans]] and [[Byzantine Empire

column2: conquered Constantinople]], the capital city of the Byzantine Empire. In 1460 they conquered the [[Despotate of the Morea]], in 1461 the [[Empire of Trebizond]], in 1475 the [[Principality of Theodoro]] and by 1500 most of the plains and islands were in Ottoman hands. Holdouts included [[Rhodes]], conquered in 1522, [[Cyprus]] in 1571, [[Crete]], retained by the Venetians until 1669, and the [[Ionian islands]] which remained primarily under the rule of the [[Republic of Venice]].

column1: During the [[Ottoman–Venetian Wars]] and the [[Russo-Turkish War (1768–74)]] Greece provided aid to Ottoman rivals. [[Dionysius the Philosopher]] additionally organised several uprisings. In addition, the [[Lambros Katsonis]] fleet began harassing the Ottoman fleet in the Aegean Sea.
In 1770, the Ottoman army [[Ottoman invasion of Mani (1770)

column4: 1815]] the Ottoman army invaded Mani. Also during this period, in 1803 there was a [[Souliote War (1803)
column5: final fight]] between the [[Souliotes]] and the [[Pashalik of Yanina
column6: local Ottoman]] ruler, [[Ali Pasha of Yanina
column7: Ali Pasha]], which ended the many years of conflicts between them.

column1: ===Ottoman era and the Greek state until 1913===
[[File:The Ottoman ambassador and his page at a ball at the royal residence in Athens, 1838.jpg
column5: The first Ottoman ambassador to the Greek Kingdom, the [[Phanariote]] [[Konstantinos Mousouros]], at a ball in the royal palace in Athens]]

column1: In March 1821, the [[Greek War of Independence]] from the [[Ottoman Empire]] began. The Greeks formally declared their independence in January 1822, and after the [[Battle of Navarino]] in 1827, the establishment of a Greek state was recognized in the [[London Protocol (1828)
column2: London Protocol]] of 1828. The first borders of the Greek state consisted of the Greek mainland south of a line from [[Arta, Greece
column3: Arta]] to [[Volos]] plus [[Euboea]] and the [[Cyclades]] islands in the Aegean Sea. The rest of the Greek-speaking lands, including [[Crete]], [[Cyprus]] and the rest of the [[Aegean Sea
column5: Macedonia]] and [[Thrace]], remained under Ottoman rule. Over one million Greeks also lived in what is now [[Turkey]], mainly in the [[Aegean Sea
column6: Aegean]] region of [[Asia Minor]], especially around [[Smyrna]], in the [[Pontus (region)
column7: Pontus]] region on the [[Black Sea]] coast, in the [[Gallipoli peninsula]], in [[Cappadocia]], in [[Istanbul]], in [[Imbros]] and in [[Tenedos]].

column1: Greek politicians of the 19th century were determined to include all these territories within a greatly enlarged single Greek state, based on the [[Byzantine]] model and with [[Constantinople]] ([[Istanbul]]) as its capital. This policy was called the Great Idea (''[[Megali Idea]]''). Constantinople had been the capital of the [[Byzantine Empire
column2: Eastern half of the Roman Empire]] until its fall to the Turks in 1453. The Ottomans naturally opposed these plans for a larger Greek state. The Empire was considered by the European powers as 'the [[sick man of Europe]]', but since these powers were irreconcilably divided over the fate of the Ottoman lands, the conflicts both reduced its territorial hold but also kept delaying its collapse.
Britain]] and [[France]] restrained Greece from attacking the Ottomans by occupying [[Piraeus]]. They were again prevented from taking military action during the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)
column3: Russo-Turkish War]] of 1877, in which the Greeks were keen to join in with the objective of territorial expansion, but Greece was unable to take any effective part in the war. Nevertheless, after the [[Congress of Berlin]], in 1881 Greece was given most of [[Thessaly]] and part of Epirus. Also, in 1854-1896, there were revolts in the Ottoman Empire by the Greek population in Thessaly, Macedonia, [[Epirus Revolt of 1854

column1: In 1858-1896 there were many revolts in Crete, Thessaly [[1878 Greek Macedonian rebellion
column3: Epirus]] against the Ottoman Empire by the Greek population.
Ethnic map of Asia Minor depicting the [[Ottoman Greeks]] (blue) in 1910]]

column1: In 1897, a new revolt in [[Crete]] led to the first [[Greco-Turkish War (1897)
column2: Greco-Turkish War]]. An unprepared Greek army was unable to dislodge the Ottoman troops from their fortifications along the northern border, and with the resulting Ottoman counter-attack, the war resulted in minor territorial losses for Greece.

column1: The [[Young Turks]], who seized power in the Ottoman Empire in 1908, were Turkish nationalists whose objective was to create a strong, centrally governed state. The Christian minorities of the Empire, including Greeks, saw their position in the Empire deteriorate.

The [[First Balkan War]] of 1912–1913 was a direct consequence of the mounting tension, as a result of which Greece seized Crete, the islands, the rest of Thessaly and Epirus, and coastal Macedonia from the Ottomans, in alliance with [[Serbia]] and [[Bulgaria]]. Crete was once again the flashpoint for tension between the two nations.
In 1913 an organized persecution of the Christian population of the Ottoman Empire, including the [[Greek genocide
column2: Greeks]], was started. Greece entered the [[World War I
column3: First World War]] in 1917 with the intention of seizing [[Constantinople]] ([[Istanbul]]) and [[Smyrna]] ([[İzmir]]) from the Ottomans, with the encouragement of [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
column4: Britain]] and [[France]], who also promised the Greeks [[Cyprus]] at a certain stage. The ongoing [[Greek genocide
column6: date=January 2015}} in the Ottoman Empire also played a factor in this decision{{Citation needed
column7: date=January 2015}}. Although there was little direct fighting between Greeks and Turks{{Citation needed
column8: date=January 2015}}, when the Ottoman Empire collapsed in 1918 the Greeks were quick to claim the lands the Allies had promised them. The 1920 [[Treaty of Sèvres]] gave Greece eastern [[Thrace]] and an area of about 17,000 km² in western [[Anatolia]] around Smyrna. This Treaty was signed by the Ottoman government but never went into force, not having been ratified by Parliament.

column2: Greece occupied Smyrna/İzmir]] on 15 May 1919, while [[Mustafa Kemal Pasha]] (later [[Atatürk]]), who was to become the leader of the Turkish opposition to the [[Treaty of Sèvres]], landed in [[Samsun]] on May 19, 1919, an action that is regarded as the beginning of the [[Turkish War of Independence]].
